ResponsesInList.Title: JavaScript utility to upscale images
ResponsesInList.Text: If anyone wants to try this, feedback appreciated. https://github.com/RVC-Learn-Digital-Team/moodle-javascript-upscaler Basically all background and foreground images > 100px get a hover upscale button (which ever corner of the image is closest to the mouse). Upscale is not AI. For a proper Moodle plugin (could be added to local_accessibility for example) it would need button configuration options and ability to switch on and off. But it works and can be pasted into administrator appearance extra html (with <script> tags) or downloaded.

ResponsesInList.Title: Improving Moodle for Students with ADHD: Standardization and Accessibility Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: I have studied more than twenty courses across four different Swedish universities and higher education institutions. Despite the differences between them, they all share the same weaknesses in how Moodle is structured and presented. As a student with ADHD, I often experience that perception and navigation in Moodle become barriers in themselves. To better understand my difficulties, I have also used ChatGPT to analyze how my own perception interacts with the learning platform. This showed me that the problems are not purely personal – they are systemic. Key Challenges Important details disappear in complex file structures. Key documents are sometimes reused but remain hidden in folders named after earlier modules. Unclear file names (e.g. “document1.pdf”) and inconsistent naming of resources. Long and complex course pages where crucial information gets lost. No standardized course template – every teacher organizes Moodle differently. As a result, I sometimes spend entire working days just trying to orient myself in the file structures, or contacting teachers for help. This takes away focus from learning and wastes valuable teacher time. What is Needed What we are really asking for is standardization : Clear coding and labeling of documents/resources Each file should include a code and a full “path” in the course structure (e.g. Course Geography1 → Module 1a → Assignment 2 → document2.doc ). Adopt a standardized course template across the institution Same predictable layout for every course (intro, resources, assignments, forum). Consistent naming conventions and metadata . Built-in support for time orientation A function that clearly shows how many hours/days remain until assignments are due. Why It Matters Without such standards, Moodle courses do not meet current European accessibility legislation (the Web Accessibility Directive, soon strengthened by the European Accessibility Act). For students with ADHD, this lack of structure creates unnecessary cognitive barriers. Standardizing Moodle use according to clear accessibility principles would not only help students with ADHD – it would support all learners by creating clarity, predictability, and compliance with legal requirements.

ResponsesInList.Title: Improving Moodle for Students with ADHD: Standardization and Accessibility Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: "Without such standards, Moodle courses do not meet current European accessibility" If teachers can create courses some will create inaccessible content. As you say this goes way beyond people with ADHD. I have realised recently that I have a problem with the most mundane of physical interfaces. Despite having the same cooker for about 5 years yesterday I turned on the bottom oven and five minutes later it is cold because it is not clear which button does what. I could give other examples which mystify my partner. The people at Brickfields do some interesting stuff about accessibility. Disclaimer I have known them for a long time, like them and know little beyond "interesting stuff" though I ought to. Could you expand on what you mean by "A function that clearly shows how many hours/days remain until assignments are due." it sounds interesting, the fact that time passes still comes as a surprise to me.

ResponsesInList.Title: Improving Moodle for Students with ADHD: Standardization and Accessibility Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you for your reply, but I think we should be careful not to trivialize the issue. In my experience this is not about a few individual teachers – it is a systemic problem that I have encountered at several higher education institutions where I have studied. Interestingly, I have not had the same difficulties when courses were delivered in Canvas. We should also not downplay the fact that many teachers simply do not have the time to learn the platform, do not receive sufficient training, and are often unaware that their choices in structuring Moodle can make learning virtually impossible for students with impaired working memory or selective attention. At present, students are forced to keep entire folder structures in their head to locate relevant documents. This is made worse when teachers are careless with file names, or even use different names for the same document. That is why I am suggesting a document ID system – for example added as a suffix in the filename – so that each resource can always be identified, regardless of naming. The part you found interesting – the visual “Time left bar” – is inspired by the gaming world. It could show the due date as a live countdown in days and hours until submission. Such a feature could add a useful layer of gamification, but most importantly it would provide clear temporal orientation for all students, not only those with ADHD.

ResponsesInList.Title: Improving Moodle for Students with ADHD: Standardization and Accessibility Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: This i both exciting and scary at the same time: Summary There is currently a significant lack of research and empirical evidence on how people with ADHD actually perceive and navigate digital environments. Most existing studies focus on outcomes (e.g., screen time, distraction, difficulties with self-regulation) rather than on the subjective perception and user experience of digital platforms. As a result: Knowledge gaps remain – we lack robust frameworks and systematic studies addressing ADHD-specific interactions with digital systems. Adaptations are missing – digital accessibility standards (like WCAG) focus mainly on visual, auditory, or motor impairments, while ADHD-related needs are overlooked. Responsibility shifts to the individual – instead of platforms offering built-in adaptations, people with ADHD often have to “cut and paste” together their own strategies, tools, and methods to make digital systems usable.

ResponsesInList.Title: Improving Moodle for Students with ADHD: Standardization and Accessibility Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: "but I think we should be careful not to trivialize the issue." I really really did not mean to trivialise the issue, I gave a real world example of something in my direct recent experience to illustrate this is a problem well beyond a tool like Moodle. . You are correct it is not about a few individual teachers, it is about a huge number of teachers/course creators who are unaware of the issues and "just want to get the job done". Canvas have put a great deal of effort into this area, but I am confident that it is possible to produce courses with accessibility issues with that as well. A visual indication of time left for things is a good idea and also technically not especially hard to implement. I was a teacher for 10 years and saw at first hand how easy it is to create content that leaves students lost and mystified. I cleave to the principle of "don't make me think" I have been thinking about this for a long time, but I have great deal to learn.

ResponsesInList.Title: Improving Moodle for Students with ADHD: Standardization and Accessibility Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: Thankyou for the insights here but as you say one size fits all approach will not work and most of the issues you have raised are an instructional design issue and not one that can or should be addressed in the system itself.  I have a good understanding of the challenges ADHD can bring living in a household with several members who have varying levels of ADHD, and all that brings so please understand this is where I am coming from. A long tagging system for file names is problematic as it will break a lot of teaching use cases and can be confusing for screen reader users. The timer we have past experience with them in quizzes and many students with anxiety particularly would find having a countdown to their next submission extremely stressful and would negatively impact their results.  There are some long disucssions in the quizzes forum around this.

ResponsesInList.Title: Improving Moodle for Students with ADHD: Standardization and Accessibility Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: Disclaimer: I have been recently diagnosed with Attention Deficit Disorder (by a certified psychiatrist) , which I have had since childhood. Moodle Academy has three very, very good free courses about accessibilty: * https://moodle.academy/enrol/index.php?id=58 * https://moodle.academy/enrol/index.php?id=45 * https://moodle.academy/enrol/index.php?id=54 I have added a Spanish translation of these (Creative Commons) courses to an optional complete (160 hours) 'Moodle teaching for university lecturers'  at my University (UNAM), and they have been tagged as the most important subject of all.

ResponsesInList.Title: Improving Moodle for Students with ADHD: Standardization and Accessibility Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: Thats truly a great suggestion thank you.

ResponsesInList.Title: Improving Moodle for Students with ADHD: Standardization and Accessibility Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: Summary and reflection from a student perspective I want to be clear that I approach this solely from a student perspective — focusing on how design choices affect students’ experience, cognitive load, and access to materials. I don’t fully agree with the previous comment that these issues are purely instructional. Depending on how the question is framed, they are also system problems. The way the platform is designed either increases or reduces the chances of mistakes, and that has a direct impact on students. Take file naming as an example: tagging systems sound useful in theory, but in practice they are inconsistent, confusing for screen readers, and too dependent on teachers’ technical skills. A strict, purpose-driven naming convention — built into the system — would create predictability and reduce errors. And this, in my view, is just the first step in a broader, step-by-step change where each course component is clearly framed to support even those instructors who are less interested in digital structure. From here, we face a choice: either maximize flexibility and accept higher risk of inconsistency, or reduce complexity through enforced conventions and guided workflows. From a student perspective, the latter is far preferable: it should be hard to do things wrong, not simply possible to do everything right.

ResponsesInList.Title: Improving Moodle for Students with ADHD: Standardization and Accessibility Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: The Moodle project has focused on maximum flexibility from its start around 2000, I don't see that changing significantly.

ResponsesInList.Title: Improving Moodle for Students with ADHD: Standardization and Accessibility Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: The issues we face with our learning platforms aren't just "instructional" problems; they are fundamental system design failures that directly impact our experience. The way the platform is structured determines whether it increases or reduces our cognitive load and the chance of errors. My central point is simple: We need a shift in design philosophy from "maximize flexibility" to "reduce complexity through enforced, guided workflows." ​ The Flaw of Flexibility and the Engineering Mindset ​The current system's focus on maximum flexibility, which often feels like an "engineer's mindset," treats usability as secondary . It creates an environment where, while it's technically possible to set everything up perfectly, the complexity means it’s all too easy to do things wrong. This leads to "configuration overload" and wildly inconsistent course experiences, which is a massive, unnecessary burden on students. Our focus should be on knowledge transfer , not on mastering complicated software. ​ The Necessity of Enforced Standards ​We need the system to incorporate governance and guardrails . Essential elements like a system-enforced naming convention for files would eliminate inconsistency, instantly improve predictability, and ensure better accessibility for tools like screen readers. Institutions must prioritize a standardized, recognizable course structure to ensure a minimal learning curve . The choice is ultimately between flexibility (high risk/inconsistency) and enforced conventions (low risk/high predictability). From the student perspective, the latter is vastly superior because the system should make it hard to do things wrong. ​ Predictability as an Equity Requirement ​This need for predictability goes deeper than general usability; it's a critical issue of inclusion . A teacher can work a lifetime and still not fully grasp the specific perceptual needs of students, particularly those with neurodevelopmental differences , such as an ADHD brain . For these students, the platform's inconsistency—a disorganized folder or a confusing label—is not a minor annoyance; it's a significant, energy-draining cognitive barrier . This means that a minimal learning curve and reliable consistency are not a luxury; they are an absolute necessity for equitable access. ​

ResponsesInList.Title: Improving Moodle for Students with ADHD: Standardization and Accessibility Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: Flexibility has been baked into the core of Moodle since the start and it is now a vast enterprise with around half a billion user accounts globally.  The things you say may be true but a wholesale reset of its design principles and focus is simply not going to happen. With that in mind you might consider what incremental changes could help. For example in your original post you mentioned Long and complex course pages where crucial information gets lost. No standardized course template – every teacher organizes Moodle differently. For 1 there have been features and plugins with features to attempt to address this in the past, and others might like to comment on how this has been addressed. For 2 imagine if a clean fresh install of Moodle gave an option to install a course on "Learning to use Moodle", that came with a well designed course template and it was possible to have an option that each new course created came with a default template based on a global setting but with an option to select from a bank of course templates/layouts. What do you think?

ResponsesInList.Title: Improving Moodle for Students with ADHD: Standardization and Accessibility Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: for #2, I use the Course Templates plugin and it's very helpful. But as you said, all of this is possible with plugins, that's the point... no one-sized fit all to force on everybody, just let users select the plugins that work best for their organization/situation.

ResponsesInList.Title: Improving Moodle for Students with ADHD: Standardization and Accessibility Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: Your point is that Moodle can be made more structured through plugins, but this depends on whether each institution allows and installs them. Just because the functions exist does not mean they are actually used in practice. It was only when I started doing my own research that I realized such plugins even existed — this is not something universities ever talk about. I have also heard about a plugin that can download multiple files at once, which could potentially be useful in the development of standalone applications. The discussions here have led me to realize that I may need to develop a tool where people with ADHD can restructure downloaded material from Moodle themselves. Since Swedish universities also tend to switch learning platforms every few years, it seems, as usual, that we have to take matters into our own hands if we want real order.

ResponsesInList.Title: Improving Moodle for Students with ADHD: Standardization and Accessibility Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you for your thoughtful reply. I understand your point about Moodle being designed for maximum flexibility and that a full redesign is unlikely. Still, I can’t see how teachers realistically would have the time to learn and apply Moodle-specific training courses. Most of them already struggle to balance teaching with their own research and administrative duties. In that context , expecting them to master course templates and structural conventions feels unrealistic. This is why I am leaning towards creating external structures outside Moodle – based on downloaded materials – where students with ADHD (and others) can organize content in a way that reduces the cognitive burden. From the student perspective, this often feels like the only practical solution. That said, I also wonder whether I am missing something: do schools and universities not already apply standardized course templates on the teacher side? As a student, I only see the “front end” of Moodle, and it is often chaotic. I would genuinely like to understand if the lack of structure is because templates do not exist at all, or because they are optional and inconsistently applied. In general, I am positively inclined toward open source and flexible features, but in this case my main aim is simply to figure out the cause-and-effect relationship behind the current course design practices. Without knowing why courses look the way they do, it is hard to know whether the solution lies in better system defaults, stronger governance, or external tools.

ResponsesInList.Title: Improving Moodle for Students with ADHD: Standardization and Accessibility Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks John, I will have a play with that plugin.

ResponsesInList.Title: Improving Moodle for Students with ADHD: Standardization and Accessibility Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: It is good practice for organisations to employ someone with experience in learning design who understands the issues. Without the right knowledge people will work around technologies designed to promote good practice. One version of the Moodle editor was designed to push people towards accessible content but some people put effort into work against and around that. Good course design and standardisation is far more a human than a technical issue and requires education and knowledge.

ResponsesInList.Title: Improving Moodle for Students with ADHD: Standardization and Accessibility Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Johan, these are all good questions. I guess it really depends on the school. I have worked with a few that all have employed some type of "Instructional Designer" that was in charge of aiding the teacher, setting up a template course, and working with the teacher to input their content. I've been lucky to be in these environments. I know there are are schools where it's only the teacher working on their own course content and unless the administration had a unified system in place to have the LMS administrator copy a course template over for them to work out of, then yes you are correct that teachers are essentially 'on their own' especially without adequate training. In my current environment, when a teacher clicks the "Course Request", I create their blank course and then I import a "Template" (which is a course that just houses all the consistent visual setup of activities ). The "Course Template plugin allows other users to copy that course template with out needing me to do it for them, so that plugin is very helpful.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle forms, hideIf and accessibility
ResponsesInList.Text: On Moodle forms, it is common for there to be some form fields that depend on other field. For example in the Forurms setting form (link to Moodle demo site) , in the  'Common module settings' section, if you change the value of 'Group mode' then the ' Grouping ' setting underneath appears and disappears. For screen readers, we seem not to do anything special for that. For example one could imagine that being marked with aria-live="polite", but that example probably illustrates why we don't do that: the other thing that changes is the next thing in tab-order, so what happens should make sense to users of assistive technology. But, what about in other cases, is there a case for making it clear to screen-reader users that changing one setting is having some impact on the rest of the form? I would be interested to know what people think.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle forms, hideIf and accessibility
ResponsesInList.Text: I think it might be nice to just read out some text with the label(s) of any revealed fields in this case. Something like 'Form control Grouping now available' and possibly (does this need announcing?) 'Form control Grouping now hidden' Just using aria-live: polite on the actual controls being revealed wouldn't make sense as it would just read out the labels and values - like you turn that on and it suddenly says 'Grouping', what's that about. (It's actually not too terrible in this case, but imagine it when multiple controls are being hidden and it will read the full text of all of them.) The same approach could be used for 'disabledIf'. It is possible to achieve this using aria-live, hidden (screenreader only) text, javascript to write the sentence when needed, and some new language strings. But it doesn't seem the sort of thing that accessibility advice normally recommends, so I wouldn't implement this without getting more opinions... --sam

Could you describe which device and settings you are using? For example, are you using the "Full Keyboard Access" setting? Regards, Juan

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle app for blind student
ResponsesInList.Text: This is response I received from blind student about the options feature you mentioned: The tab option would work on the computer, but the issue I was having was in the Moodle app itself on my iPhone, using the screen reader called VoiceOver (which is built into the accessibility settings of all Apple products). Perhaps they can try to see if there is a solution for that. Again, they may need to be in contact with Apple, who would have an understanding of VoiceOver and how it works.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle app for blind student
ResponsesInList.Text: Will this feature work with a usb keyboard attached to iphone?

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle app for blind student
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Victoria, we usually test with a standard keyboard plus VoiceOver as it is the best way to detect if VocieOver detects the app elements when browsing using the different keys. So definitively it should work if they attach a standard keyboard and use Option+Tab or any combination of keys to browse, however we are going to do further tests just using VoiceOver to see if we can detect what's going on. But it will be helpful to know if this person is using not only the phone but also a device connected to it, you mentioned braille in your first post, is this person using a "hable one" or similar braille keyboard/device? Or it is just using gestures to navigate? Regards, Juan

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle app for blind student
ResponsesInList.Text: Just another update, we tested this navigating using VoiceOver plus gestures and we were able to reach out to the "Save" button, we tested using an iPhone with iOS 18 so it would be good to know which iOS version the student is using, as this can also be an iOS bug

ResponsesInList.Title: Audio description form field doesn't accept audio file types

It only accepts VTT files. Is there a way to adjust this form field so that it accepts audio tracks? I have put forth significant effort creating high quality audio description tracks for my videos and it is really disappointing that these can't be utilized to provide an inclusive experience! Any help is appreciated. I'm not a developer, but I'm very motivated to work with my site developer to solve this problem.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle Activity Icons Should be Description (alt text = "")
ResponsesInList.Text: We have recently undergone an accessibility audit and it has been identified that the activity icons, for example, SCORM package, should be changed to decorative items. Right now the icon for the SCORM package would read 'SCORM package'. The challenge with this is that they would be decorative on the course page, but they would be not decorative on the page where you select the activity type you want to add to the course. Does anyone have any suggestions on how to handle this?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Activity Icons Should be Description (alt text = "")
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm sorry, I don't understand. Are you saying that the icons next to the resource or activity need improvement? (See the graphic below.) Could you provide an example of what the accessibility folks want? I recall how Moodle 4.0 included "words" to describe the activity or resource, in addition to the graphic.  I think people complained, and now the words are removed.  But perhaps the accessibility folks would be happy if the "words" returned? Perhaps if "alt-text" could be added to the icon, the accessibility folks would be happy. Or, is the situation that words are showing but should not show the issue?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Activity Icons Should be Description (alt text = "")
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes, I am referring to those icons. When the screen reader reads the alt text they are indicating 'assignment', 'scorm package' etc. Our accessibility folks are saying that these are decorative icons and therefore should not have alt text. (alt="") I think that it is subjunctive to some extent, so in an ideal world being able to very easily find the media, and add our own alt text would be solve the issue.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Activity Icons Should be Description (alt text = "")
ResponsesInList.Text: This is something that has been thought about quite a lot. You can probably find the history in the Tracker, if you need it. There might be some scope for different opinions on this, but the consensus the Moodle project reached is that this icons do convey useful information to the user: the type of each activity. Therefore, it is best for them to have alt text, so they do.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Activity Icons Should be Description (alt text = "")

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Activity Icons Should be Description (alt text = "")

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Activity Icons Should be Description (alt text = "")

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Radio buttons too faint to be accessible

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Radio buttons too faint to be accessible
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Brett and Mary, Thank you for your response and for agreeing that the contrast is too low. My screenshot does indeed come from the Moodle QA testing site (https://qa.moodledemo.net/) . I am particularly sensitive to accessibility , even though I do not personally have any serious visual impairments. However, I am slightly color blind, like a small but not insignificant percentage of the population. To my knowledge, this cannot be effectively corrected with glasses or other means, and it can lead to certain frustrations if the colors on a web page are poorly chosen. I have also helped an older person—very curious and intelligent—who suffered from mild macular degeneration. That experience made me realize just how inaccessible websites actually are. By the way, I would strongly recommend working with people who have mild visual impairments when developing your layouts and other formatting. I imagine that developers are generally young people without visual impairments, who have no real idea of what this actually entails. I don't mean to be too direct, but it seems to me that what is referred to as "accessibility" is, in reality, more focused on making Moodle look sleek and modern—an approach that, unfortunately, does not necessarily address the needs of people with visual impairments.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Radio buttons too faint to be accessible
ResponsesInList.Text: Dominique, the developers are well versed in accessibility and this is something we test for and explicitly design for. The change was a side effect of the move from Bootstrap 4 to Bootstrap 5 that was caught as part of testing in QA. Its now been fixed and wont be present in the 5.0 release.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Radio buttons too faint to be accessible

Furthermore, is it truly justifiable to deny or ignore these issues rather than actively working to resolve them? In any case, well done for the effort nonetheless...

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Radio buttons too faint to be accessible
ResponsesInList.Text: Dominique The product is very large and in some areas old, and a large part of the development was done by the community , many of whom don't understand accessibility.  This has lead to a not insignificant backlog of issues.  Again these are not ignored or denied, they are actively worked on.  In the last 12 months over 70 accessibility issues have been fixed and closed.  There are only limited resources on any product, and fixing some of the less intuitive parts of the system is a very big task, the current work for example in the assignment grading is very large as it relies on old frameworks so it requires a complete rebuild of the page.  accessibiltiy and usability is a priority for me and my teams, if the community also wishes to contribute to resolving some of these issues it would be greatly appreciated as well.  Accessibility of a product is an ongoing process, its never a one and done.

ResponsesInList.Title: Early Access
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, I have a student with ADA (Americans with Disabilitis Act) requirements that require that they be allowed early access to modules that are restricted by date. Is there any easy way to do this? I thought about a workaround in which I create a text box that only they can see with links to each activity, but that is a tremendous amount of work. Is there a way to create an exception to a restriction? Any other options? thanks for any help! Sarra

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Early Access
ResponsesInList.Text: Put that student in a group of their own and then set up restriction so that the module is available either on the set date or if you are amember of the group the student is in - see screenshot where the student would be in the group ADA student. You can click the eye to hide the restrictions. (Still a lot of work though)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Early Access

If I may ask a followup question, if I have more than one student with the same requirements, and I don't wish them to know each others' individual requirements, is there a way to do that. It seems that if I make it so that the members of the group are invisible to one another, I can't make the dropdown show the group. Is there a way around this? Thanks, Sarra

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Early Access
ResponsesInList.Text: Just checking first - what version of Moodle are you using? I remember you were previously using MoodleCloud - are you still using MoodleCloud? And when you create the group and put the members into the group,  you are choosing the option "Only see own membership", yes?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Early Access
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Mary, First, thank you for such quick responses. Yes, I'm on MoodleCloud, and your question sent me back to the settings where I realized I misunderstood the limitations - I thought if I set it to that setting, the group would not be available to any dropdown, but I realize now that this is only a limitation on activities , which is what I was originally considering opening early (one by one). I've now tried that setting with the module restrictions, and indeed, it works! Thank you so much for helping me get there! Sarra

ResponsesInList.Title: Audio Files Location
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, I have an issue with recording audio files. I recently discovered that my hosting provider has disabled access to MP3 files, and my recordings are in the MP3 format. As a result, I can't play, access, or download them. Is there any solution to retrieve these MP3 files, perhaps directly from the directory or through the use of a plugin? Thank you.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Audio Files Location
ResponsesInList.Text: Well, you can serve them from a different web server . You could run your own web server and upload the mp3 to a place where it serves the files. Then go to every place on your Moodle where it serves a mp3, change them to a URL , something like yoursite/upload/audio.mp3. Alternatively, you can upload them to some kind of media service like, YouTube, Vimeo, Odysee, Peertube, .. Be aware that then the participants are able to see the URLs and share them with non-participants. As you see, the root cause of the problem is your provider. You have to find a provider who allows the type of files you need. Next time he'll say no PNGs, what will you do?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Audio Files Location
ResponsesInList.Text: Okay, so there's no way to download the raw file directly from the directory and save the test recording in a different format?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Audio Files Location
ResponsesInList.Text: What do you mean by "raw files"? The mp3 you've uploaded to Moodle? Sure they are there, not converted to any other format. They have just been renamed to a hash of their content and in moodledata/filedir/ab/cd/abcdef1234..... You can find their original names and many other information in the Moodle database and can do what you want with them. If the provider supports a different audio format you can't just replace the files, since the new files will have different content hashes and new names too (counting the file extension). As I always say, the Moodle repository is convenient for the end user, a nightmare for the system administrator. BTW , the above is to my knowledge and what immediately came to my mind. There could be more practical solutions which I'm not aware of (and willing to learn).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Audio Files Location
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you for the support and insights regarding my Moodle issue. The mp3 files I’m referring to are recordings from a student speaking test, captured using Moodle’s recording feature and saved as mp3 files within the platform. I don’t have these files stored locally, as they exist solely on Moodle’s file system. I’ve cloned my Moodle site to a different server that supports mp3 files, maintaining the same versions of Moodle, PHP, and the database. I also performed a search and replace to update the URLs. Most elements are functioning well; however, during my review of the recordings, I noticed that while some audio files play correctly, others do not. The affected files show an error message: “Hmmm… can’t reach this page. It looks like the webpage at mydomain/recording might be having issues or it may have moved permanently to a new web address.” If there is a way to resolve this discrepancy, I’d greatly appreciate any advice. Thank you again for your help.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Audio Files Location
ResponsesInList.Text: > I’ve cloned my Moodle site to a different server that supports mp3 files You did the only right thing: If the hosting doesn't support what you want, then you're stuck. The workarounds I mentioned are big workarounds and if you get mp3 from students recording answers straight on Moodle interface, you can't be fishing them and uploading somewhere else. > I noticed that while some audio files play correctly, others do not. That could be a new (unrelated) problem. (You don't know whether these mp3 were broken in your original site, since it never allowed playing any mp3.) My understanding of media files and players are limited. I'd prefer you post this as a new discussion, maybe in the General help forum to get the widest attention.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Audio Files Location
ResponsesInList.Text: I regisered to test drive this function. I used different codeks before. I will write back on the results.

ResponsesInList.Title: How to disable right-click on Moodle verison 4.3.2+
ResponsesInList.Text: Is it possible to disable right-click on Moodle verison 4.3.2+? We need basic protection for direct browser right-click saving video files from Moodle course. There was some plugin for Moodle 3 https://moodle.org/plugins/local_disablerightclick?lang=en_us , but is there some option to do this in Moodle 4 version?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to disable right-click on Moodle verison 4.3.2+
ResponsesInList.Text: There is nothing in core Moodle and I suspect there are no 3rd party plugins. This thread may explain some of the reasons. https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=225859

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to disable right-click on Moodle verison 4.3.2+
ResponsesInList.Text: Actually it is fairly easy. Wherever in Moodle's php scripts it prints out the Header <HTML><HEAD>... , just change <HTML> to <HTML oncontextmenu="return false">. If all of Moodle is generated, this will block the ability to right click on the whole site. This may impede the way Moodle works, and it is not a completely secure way to stop users from  stealing images (there is an app or addon they can download to get around this) but depending on the context of your use may be sufficient. This is, as others have mentioned, no substitute for a lock down browser, and both Chrome and Edge provide a kiosk mode which does much the same thing as Safe Exam Browser without having to install anything.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to disable right-click on Moodle verison 4.3.2+
ResponsesInList.Text: Could you please explain more about: how to do this? *Updated: Oh I got it! In your Moodle site, go to: Site administration > Appearance > Additional HTML. Paste: <HTML oncontextmenu="return false"> on "Within HEAD". Worked for me! Thanks!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to disable right-click on Moodle verison 4.3.2+
ResponsesInList.Text: Why do you want to disable right mouse click?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to disable right-click on Moodle verison 4.3.2+
ResponsesInList.Text: To have a minimum of protection against video downloads, because my videos are hosted directly on Moodle. Because for me it is more practical and cheaper, I would like to host it on YouTube but I don't know how to prevent students from clicking on the video and leaving Moodle. And on Google Drive it seemed to me that the videos were very slow (don't you think?). Could you give me your opinion on all this? Do you have a better (and not expensive) solution for students to watch videos with a great experience without leaving Moodle and not being able to easily download the videos? It would be wonderful to know.I know that there may be JavaScript scripts to prevent students from clicking on videos hosted on YouTube but I don't know what they are and I don't know how to put them in Moodle. Anyway, that's it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to disable right-click on Moodle verison 4.3.2+
ResponsesInList.Text: Did you read this? https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=225859 I recommend researching other discussions on this topic,on these forums as it has come up very regularly over the previous 20 years.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to disable right-click on Moodle verison 4.3.2+
ResponsesInList.Text: Let me see if I understand what you are saying, Venelouis. You do not want students to leave Moodle.  So your courses do not have any external links to anything, such as newspapers, wikis, etc.  Not a single link that takes students to another website.  You do not have any PDF, Word, Excel, or Google Docs files that get opened outside of Moodle. And to prevent students from recording videos with their smartphones, you make sure that students must be somewhere that makes it impossible for them to have their smartphones. And maybe you are not using textbooks that students can have to learn about the topics being taught, because reading a textbook would be done outside of Moodle.  Right? Am I understanding your situation?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to disable right-click on Moodle verison 4.3.2+
ResponsesInList.Text: Almost. The phrase: "You do not want students to leave Moodle." is right. The rest of your text is wrong. Please answer me a few questions: where do you host your course videos? On Moodle or on another platform? Don't you care if your students download your video lessons?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to disable right-click on Moodle verison 4.3.2+
ResponsesInList.Text: Okay, Venelous, my point (of course 😀) was to illustrate that students are always leaving Moodle to learn.  With modern computers and technology, you cannot prevent students from downloading things, including videos. To answer your questions about video, I host my videos on Vimeo.  It's not free, but I find it very affordable ($20/USD per month), it has great features, and it always works.  It supports all the common features, and includes "chapters." Below, I am providing two examples of how to link to a video on Vimeo.  The first method is to use a hyperlink to the video, the second method is to embed the video.  I use both methods, depending on what I am seeking.  This particular video is what I require students to watch to learn how to use my Moodle. (Make sure to try the chapters icon in the video's control area.) As a side benefit of hosting videos not on my Moodle, I can easily provide students with a link (such as in an email, saying, "You need to watch this video!"), and they do not need to be logged into Moodle. Yes, I allow students to download my videos.  My philosophy is that since I cannot prevent students from copying them, I might as well make it easy to download.  Then students might watch my videos instead of some other instructor's videos, an instructor that tries not to allow downloading.  (I want students to spend time in my course, not others. 😓) Vimeo does have some privacy settings that can make downloading "harder."  There is a switch to not allow downloading.  You can make a video viewable from only certain domains. You can even password protect each video (How' that for making things harder for students... that they would have to have passwords for both Moodle and videos!) Incidentally, most of my course content is not in Moodle, either.  Most content is on my website.  Yes, some people would not want to do this, but this is my style.  It provides much more flexibility, ease, and power in managing content. I gave a presentation at a Moodlemoot explaining my methods. MoodleMoot2016, "Expanding your MoodleCloud Storage to Fill the 'Entire Sky'" Here are my examples: Moodle4 Overview ( as a hyperlink ) Embedded

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to disable right-click on Moodle verison 4.3.2+
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you very much for your answers. But in the end each professional has his own style right? $20/USD per month is not "very affordable" for me, but I recognize the quality of the vimeo services, I know some people who uses it, but I also know some plataforms which use some scripts to difficult the downloading or recording the videos, I just would like to know if some those scripts are simlpe and possible to put in moodle and how. If you know this would be very helpful and I think this would make some people save some money and know more about technologies, how to implement useful code, know more about moodle possibilities and capabilities and etc.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to disable right-click on Moodle verison 4.3.2+
ResponsesInList.Text: Certainly, "cost" is dependent on the person.  And so is quality.  My university never supported my methods, not even Moodle or my hosting service, so I paid for everything with my own funds.  However, I end up with quality instruction that cannot be matched by the other instructors. I assume your goal is for a student to play the video, right? So what I do when I want to copy a video, I go to the video and play it. However, before playing it, I start my screen recorder software. Then I can leave my computer, do something else, and return to stop my screen recorder. It's easy to crop the beginning and end, as needed. I also add burned-in captions. Ultimately, I end up with a copy of the video that I can watch whenever I choose. Since I am the only one using this copy, I don't feel that I am at risk of violating any copyright rules.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to disable right-click on Moodle verison 4.3.2+
ResponsesInList.Text: I think there is no problem to record for personal use, the problem is when people share what shouldn't be shared right? If I would like to freely share the content I would choose YouTube.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to disable right-click on Moodle verison 4.3.2+
ResponsesInList.Text: If you use YouTube, I believe you are giving YouTube the rights to your videos, and YouTube can do anything they wish with your videos. That's why YouTube is free. This is not so with Vimeo (and perhaps other platforms). So you still have to choose: 1) do you use a paid service, or 2) do you use YouTube? No matter what you choose or try to do, students can still copy (and share if they wish) videos. This is not a Moodle problem; it's the way technology works.  The only way that I know of that can prevent students from copying course materials, documents, and videos is to have them physically come to a classroom, take away their smartphones and other recording devices, and then display things to them only in this classroom. I am unsure if I mentioned that if you upload your videos to Moodle, your Moodle backup size might increase tremendously. Can your server handle this? (Mine can't unless I pay more for hosting space.)

ResponsesInList.Title: Course Index
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Accessibility People! Could you vote for my Course Index issue on the tracker please? I recently revisited an earlier post I had made and realised I needed to give a clearer explanation. Essentially, when navigating through the accordion menu in the lefthand Course Index, the current state of a collapsed or expanded item is not read out to the screen reader user. Instead the next action they might wish to take is read out. So for example, if a Course Index item is collapsed, "expand" is read by the screen reader. This can be confusing for the user as can lead them to think the item is expanded when it is collapsed. We think it would be better if the current state of an accordion item is read out first and then the action of expand or collapse is read out if they go to activate it. Also, when the user expands an item with the space bar, you hear "space" and not "expanded" and when the user repeats the action you hear "space" again and not "collapsed". Many thanks for your support. Hope it is ok to post this here. I am new to this forum! Kerry

ResponsesInList.Title: Mandatory title for Text and Media Resource
ResponsesInList.Text: Moodle 4.3 We are in the process of upgraded from 3.11 to 4.3. In many of our courses, we use the Text and Media resources (formerly called Labels) to add addition text. This is done to provide better structure to the course content without the need of adding new sections / activities . These blocks of text are part of an existing section/topic and doesn't warrant their own heading. Since upgrading to 4.3, we find that these Text and Media resources now require a Title, otherwise the first line of text appears in the course navigation. This makes absolutely no sense and clearly wasn't thought through properly from a usability perspective. There should be either an option to "exclude" these from the course navigation individually, or, if the Title is blank, exclude these from the course navigation by default. We now have the 'joyful' task of updating almost 900 instances of the Text and Media resources activity. We use a mixture of the Collapsible Topics, Flexible Sections, Tiles and Topics course formats. Is there a fix for this?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Mandatory title for Text and Media Resource
ResponsesInList.Text: This was a design decision that was made during the Moodle 4.0 UI revamp, and definently something that can be revisited. I will raise it with one of my teams. In the short term however, no there isn't any way around this.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Mandatory title for Text and Media Resource
ResponsesInList.Text: I think this is a common use case. A ”Show in course index” option would be nice.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Mandatory title for Text and Media Resource
ResponsesInList.Text: This is interesting discussion that caused me to experiment. A "Text and Media" resource can have three possibilities, and what is displayed my change. A title and text: The text shows, but not the title. No title, but text: The text shows, as in #1. A title but no text: Nothing shows, but the resource appears to take some default screen space. I wonder if it would be better to have the "text and Media" resource mimic the behavior of a Quiz (for example.) The title is required for a quiz, and it shows on the page (and in the course index.) However, the description doesn't show unless you check "Display description on course page." I was surprised that the "text and media" resource title does not show.  But as I think about it, perhaps this resource should only be used to display text without any title. As a suggestion, I would like the "Text and Media" resource to contain a title and text, and two buttons, one for "Display description on course page" and another for "Display Title on course page."  Then, we would have the most flexibility with this resource.  When using "Display Title on course page," this could be used to add "headings" in both the course page and course index. Any thoughts?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Mandatory title for Text and Media Resource
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi This discussion is good, I think. There’s also the case of the T&M resource containing just a decorative image, where nothing in the course index is wanted / needed. An easy mistake - I did it when testing - is to think the name would show as a headline, and put nothing in the content area. The T&M resource was quite hard to find on the page, with only the three editing dots giving away it’s placement 😅

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Mandatory title for Text and Media Resource
ResponsesInList.Text: Because of the versatility of the old "Label", we used it whenever we had one of the following scenarios: A block of text to provide additional information/instructions within a topic/section. A heading to break content/activities within a section. A (sub)heading (but not a sub-topic) within a section to provide clearer structure to the content. To provide a link to external resources or other courses. (We don't use the URL activity for this because of its limited functionality.) With the upgrade to Text and Media, it has now made it useless in these scenarios. Hopefully the Moodle team will address this oversight in an update in the not-to-distant future (though this would probably mean we'd have to upgrade - again).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Mandatory title for Text and Media Resource
ResponsesInList.Text: It certainly was a design decision made with a very specific use-scope in mind. It would be good if this is addressed and the original functionality restored so it is actually useful again.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Mandatory title for Text and Media Resource
ResponsesInList.Text:
The course index elements for labels all have an href beginning with #, unlike all other course index elements which are actual links to resources. With careful CSS targeting, you can select them and turn off their display. Site Admin > Appearance > Themes > Your theme (4.4 click the cog) > Advanced Settings > Raw SCSS 
```text
#courseindex .courseindex-item:has(.courseindex-link[href^="#"]) { display: none !important; }
```
 I've tested this in 4.4 Boost theme and it works there, but not in 4.3. Also, Ive not /thoroughly/ tested it, so please do so before putting this into production! There's no guarantee this trick will continue to work in future releases, but should give you a reprieve and get a chance to update the labels at your own pace.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Mandatory title for Text and Media Resource
ResponsesInList.Text: Label aka "Text and media resources" having titled of their own sounds intriguing. But it has one use case: With it one can simulate sub-sections on the course homepage, the titles of the sub-sections then appearing on the menu. But Moodle 4.5 LTS bringing true sub-sections, that use case is no more.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle blocked in certain countries such as Iran and China?
ResponsesInList.Text: When you say "if certain countries block Moodle access", what is Moodle in it? Do you mean those countries block sites running Moodle? Where? Inland or abroad? When I think of the Great Bamboo Wall of China, I imagine something very sophisticated. Filtering based on the domain names and IP ranges are the minimum. They must be doing content filtering too. I heard that they are allergic to a certain nickname of the president of the country. ;) The software running those sites are also relevant, but I think they look for software that allows to share content anonymously apart from the dark web and other illegal operations than at educational platform like Moodle, which in its core knows only the usual SSL encryption (HTTPS). ResponsesInList.Title: Notification Cover Up
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi There, I know there have been some changes to Moodle recently at my facility - since I am a heavy user of Moodle, I notice the small changes. The most recent is a notification box that comes up after I grade a students assignment, covering up what I am looking at - causing me to wait 5 seconds before it disappears.   This notification is new, and it can't be moved no mater what I do to the window size etc....how do we make it stop. I attached a picture to this submission showing the light blue box covering the spot I always look at as soon as I submit a student's grade.  I know you might be saying "it is just 5 seconds, just wait"....but I move very quickly in Moodle and it does interrupt my workflow...not to mention it is incredibly annoying. Thank you - I hope you can help and save us all from poor UI/UX design. Regards, Warren

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Notification Cover Up
ResponsesInList.Text: Warren, we are currently redesigning this whole interface so I'll pass on your feedback. What task is it stopping you completing? I've done a quick investigation and the dialogue is not stopping anything other than you clicking on the student profile. What you might be seeing is the page does a reload to ensure all the data is fresh after the save. That is what will prevent you navigating to the next student until the page load completes. What is probably a more pertinant question is do you feel that having to click save is neccesary? or if any change was automatically saved would that be acceptable?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Notification Cover Up
ResponsesInList.Text: Great, I'm glad you are accepting feedback.   Now I can see where you are going with this conversation Brett - I am an IT/technical guy so I know what we are like!! First, I ask you to put on your user hat....keep an open mind.   Breathe.  My feedback is meant to help the application improve and it is not a personal assault on anyone making changes to Moodle. Second, I never stated that it was stopping me from completing my tasks, I'm not sure where you got that from but maybe I should just clarify.   I stated that I am a heavy user of Moodle, and so any changes, I notice. In this case, when I submit a students grades, I am on to the next student (whose name appears at the top), comparing with my spreadsheet, and opening their project to grade.   It is all very efficient and have done it for  5 years. Now, my issue is that the dialog box informing me that it is saving the state (which personally I don't care about - I don't need to know this - but clearly the developer believes that I care) is blocking the student name for approximately 5 seconds which delays me selecting them in my spreadsheet and opening their project to grade.  It slows me down (5 second pause) but doesn't stop me. Like I said in my email, you could say "suck it up princess, it is just 5 seconds" - agree, but it is very annoying.   I have overseen 300 software developers in my previous life an I know what the developers say under their breath when the users complain...I get it...someone is calling your baby ugly. My point is, what if I added a 5 second delay to everything that you do on your desktop (e.g. 5 second delay launching every application) - you would get annoyed pretty quickly.   Doesn't stop you, but annoys you. That is my point Brett - and my plea to make it stop. As for your other queries: Regarding navigating to the next student, I have already navigated to the next student, I just can't see their name for 5 seconds!   Which makes me pause for 5 seconds. I do feel clicking save is necessary - I teach IT and computer programming - this is a no-brainer, I just don't need the developer telling me with a banner across the screen that they are saving....I don't care. Again, I have no issue with manually selecting Save, love it in fact.   I don't need automatic save though Moodle in general and Moodle Quiz is VERY good at automatic saves as my students have found out during exams. OK, well, that's it...do what you want with my feedback - hopefully it is useful. Regards, Warren

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Notification Cover Up
ResponsesInList.Text: Warren, sorry if the post sounded defensive, I was genuinely trying to understand the reproduction steps and what you were trying to achieve.  I was working the other way around which was save them move to the next student which is why the reload was an issue.  As I said we are currently redesigning that whole interface so this is very useful feedback. On your last points, the fact we save manually in the gradebook and grading interface is pretty unusual among LMS.  Most other major LMS I have experience with you enter the value/make the change etc and it's saved in background immediately.  Changing this behaviour would resolve a lot of weird edge cases that can result in data loss in the gradebook/assignment submissions page/grader interface.  But Moodle has worked with this explicit save model for a long time so it's important to understand a broad views of users here The banner is there for accessibility reasons, as an explicit confirmation, and many user really need this reassurance.  But as you pointed out, the positioning could be considered for improvement.  In the protypes of the new designs are moving elements around in the headset so it may be a non issue but it will be important to consider what data is obscured.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Notification Cover Up
ResponsesInList.Text: Brett,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Notification Cover Up
ResponsesInList.Text: Warren for reference we have UX designers embedded in every development team and a whole dedicated PX team for user research. The conclusions I referenced above are from direct user testing and multiple sources.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Notification Cover Up
ResponsesInList.Text: Excellent - thank you for passing on my feedback to those folks.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Notification Cover Up
ResponsesInList.Text:
If you have access to change your themes custom CSS , that pop-up seems to have the CSS class .toast-wrapper. You could potentially move it with some custom CSS, for example: 
```text
.toast-wrapper { top: 200px; }
```
 Shunt the toast around with some combination of top, left, right, etc such as the `top: 200px;` I've used here. The CSS selector I've used could well be too generic, getting unintended toasts, so you can be more specific. To just get the assignment grader page, for example, 
```text
#page-mod-assign-grader .toast-wrapper { top: 200px; }
```
 `display: none;` would completely turn off the toast, but Im unsure if there are any that are actually needed, so use with caution. If you don't have access to the custom CSS, a plugin for your browsers can inject custom CSS into a page, for example https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/customcss-injector/ for firefox . Im sure there's something similar for Chrome as well.

This seems to conflict with best practices for accessibility, as users relying on keyboard navigation or screen readers are unable to interact with these links. Could you clarify the rationale behind this decision? Is it intentional for certain use cases, or might this be an oversight? Additionally, what would be the recommended approach to make these links accessible while maintaining the intended functionality? Thanks in advance for your insights!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Links in Main Menu Have tabindex="-1"
ResponsesInList.Text: If you are refering to the Dashboar and My Course links they are accessible using the arrow keys and act more like a sub menu/tab items than individual link items although visually I can understand the confusion. This is to speed up keyboard navigation for the majority of use cases where they are options that are seldom utilised

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: confusing label on "my courses" page
ResponsesInList.Text: I might be off target. If a student isn't enrolled in future courses, the display is correct. The "Show All" doesn't display anything. Try changing the "future" to "past." If a student doesn't know that there is a dropdown for past, current, and future courses, then they need to be told this. If it is the position of "Show All" on the page that concerns you, then this would probably require a theme modification.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: confusing label on "my courses" page
ResponsesInList.Text: I agree this is not a bug (and that's why the issue was just qualified as an "improvement"). However, I'm a little less convinced about blaming the student. The student knows that there is a dropdown for past, current and future courses, because he made himself the change (the default value is "all", isn't it?). Afterwards, did he understand what was involved behind it, probably not... Of course, for people who spend all day in Moodle, the problem is solved in 2 seconds. But if my IT support colleagues, who don't use Moodle every day, get stuck for several minutes without being able to solve the problem, it's probably that something could be improved. Fortunately, this type of feedback concerns a very small minority of our students (I haven't looked in our database , but probably also because very few users change the preference for past, current and future courses...). Anyway, for students who don't need advanced use on Moodle (reading messages, answering quizzes, uploading files... in short, not more advanced use than what social networks offer ), I think they should not need any instructions or support to use Moodle (except of course students who are not comfortable with computers). The software should fit to its users, not the other way around. But I could be wrong about that. Another point that makes me think there's a problem, and as indicated in the issue, the information given to people using a screen reader is more precise than the information displayed to people not using a screen reader. The wording announced to users changes according to the value used in the menu. E.g. “Show 12 items per page” or “Show all items per page”. But perhaps even for screen reader users, this wording could be improved and made even more precise. About our environment, we're using Moodle 4.4 and the Boost theme. The screenshot was taken from the demo site: https://school.moodledemo.net

ResponsesInList.Title: Accessible Computer Programming Code
ResponsesInList.Text: How do I add an example of programming code to a Moodle course that is accessible to blind students? We are on Moodle 4.3 and use the ATTO text editor. Thank you. Laurie

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Accessible Computer Programming Code
ResponsesInList.Text: Laurie Moodle should work out of the box with most screen readers so nothing special should be required. That said is there a specific issue that you have encountered here?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Accessible Computer Programming Code
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Laurie. Have you tried enclosing the code example inside a `<code>` tag? You'll have to edit using the "HTML" view in Atto to do so. The `<code>` tag should be enclosed within a `<pre>` tag for multiline code examples. Doing so should let assistive technologies know that the content is computer code. Hope this helps.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: probelm with polyfill.js

ResponsesInList.Title: Replacement for Accessibility Block in Moodle 4.1
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi there Moodlers, We recently had to disable the Accessibility Block ( https://docs.moodle.org/39/en/Accessibility_Block ) on our version of Moodle 3.9 as it posed a major security risk. Having looked more closely, it appears that it is no longer supported, but we weren't aware. And there is no Moodle 4.1 version - we are upgrading to Moodle 4.1 in the next few months. In terms of a replacement, I have seen talk of the Brickfield Accessibility Review block, but that is for teachers, not students. I would usually encourage students to use the many tools within their web browsers to change font size, contrast etc. But we have a particuarly difficult Degree Apprenticeship course that has very strict criteria for students when they are engaged with the VLE. So is there a replacement for the old Accessibility Block? What are others doing? Many thanks in advance for your help. Catherine

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Replacement for Accessibility Block in Moodle 4.1
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Catherine, I had the same question. Did you find a solution or are you still without an accessibility plugin?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Replacement for Accessibility Block in Moodle 4.1
ResponsesInList.Text: There are obviously various sides to this challenge: First of all, faculty or instructional designers / education content writers should adopt UDL (Universal Design for Learning) good practices when designing their content in any LMS. Fortunately, there are a lot of resources to help with that. Then, existing content can be checked and improved using tools such as the Brickfield Accessibility suite. Following that, it's up to the participants to work with this content and use whatever aiding technology they need. Keep in mind that most current laptops have pretty good tools on board to help with accessibility issues, that are quite a lot better than what the TTS / Accessibility block had to offer. And finally, there are specialty integrations available, such as ReadSpeaker, which can be added to provide online and state-of-the-art text-to-speech solutions in multiple languages. From my personal experience, I can recommend this tool (comes at a price, though), because it not only offers text-to-speech for all course content, but also provides a user-friendly document viewer/reader for all text formats in your course (PDF, MS Office, Open Office, ...).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Replacement for Accessibility Block in Moodle 4.1
ResponsesInList.Text: PLEASE NOTE : the Accessibility Block ( https://docs.moodle.org/39/en/Accessibility_Block ) plugin is no longer being actively maintained by us at Brickfield. The main challenge is with the third-party external ATBar, which is not being maintained at all by its authors, at some point has lost all of its docs, and doesn't have an up-to-date SSL. If someone has funding, and would like to cover the updating of this plugin, we would be happy to engage with you on this. We are planning on sharing a new plugin which will provide guidance to users with their font size, font colour, and other display options, depending on their browser. We will update this forum discussion once it's available. As Joost rightly pointed out, there are many good tools now in both devices and browsers to help with accessibility issues!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Replacement for Accessibility Block in Moodle 4.1
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Catherine, I built my own plugin for it. It is modular in terms of the widgets inside, so you can choose what you want to enable (or develop). https://moodle.org/plugins/local_accessibility Hope this helps.

ResponsesInList.Title: Accessibility standards of Moodle 4.4.1+
ResponsesInList.Text: How compliant is Moodle 4.4.1+ (without any plugins) with WCAG 2.1, ARIA 1.1, and ATAG 2.0? And how does its compliance change when you install plugins?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Accessibility standards of Moodle 4.4.1+
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello - just moved this to the Accessibility and usability forum. Just checking you have seen the documentation Acessibility and the VPAT Accessibility conformance report?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Accessibility standards of Moodle 4.4.1+
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you for the the VPAT Accessibility conformance report. Do you also know something about ARIA 1.1, and ATAG 2.0 ?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Accessibility standards of Moodle 4.4.1+
ResponsesInList.Text: I don't sorry, but hopefully someone viewing this discussion will be able to comment further.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Accessibility standards of Moodle 4.4.1+
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks anyway , you were of great help.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Accessibility standards of Moodle 4.4.1+
ResponsesInList.Text: Ben Moodle uses aria labels and other technologies to meet the WCAG requirements.  For the most part if a product is WCAG compliant you don't need to worry about the technology it uses to achieve it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Accessibility standards of Moodle 4.4.1+
ResponsesInList.Text: "And how does its compliance change when you install plugins?" It is not possible to answer that question because the people who create Moodle have no control over plugins used. It would be possible to create a plugin that is not accessible and people might install it, but that would be a plugin by plugin issue.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Accessibility standards of Moodle 4.4.1+
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Ben. Moodle 4.4+ meets WCAG 2.1 Level AA. With WCAG 2.2 released in October 2023, we also aim to meet WCAG 2.2 Level AA conformance for future releases of Moodle. Re: ARIA - We use the appropriate ARIA tags/roles for our user interfaces whenever applicable. Re: ATAG - We currently do not evaluate against ATAG 2.0. However, The accessibility audits also evaluate Moodle's text editors (Tiny MCE and Atto) against WCAG Level AA to ensure their accessibility. Moodle's text editors also provide authors with the means to create accessible content. For example: Ability to designate headings in the text content Ability to create accessible links and images Provide the means to attach captions to uploaded media content Accessibility checker tool for the authored content Moodle also has a built-in accessibility toolkit that organisations can use to help them create accessible course content As Marcus said, Moodle HQ has no control over the accessibility of third-party plugins. So, it will be up to the institutions installing the plugins to evaluate their accessibility. Hope this helps.

ResponsesInList.Title: Missing new certification link
ResponsesInList.Text: On this page: Accessibility | Moodle Developer Resources is a link .to the WCAG 2.1 Level AA conformance. Yet this link leads to the Target conformance WCAG 2.1 Level AA from the 3 May 2023 and not the Target conformance WCAG 2.1 Level AA from the 24 January 2024. Does somebody know where the Target conformance WCAG 2.1 Level AA as of 24 January 2024 is ?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Missing new certification link
ResponsesInList.Text: See the user docs VPAT Moodle accessibility conformance report. The Statement of Accessibility Conformance is at the bottom of that page.

ResponsesInList.Title: Missing new certification link
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Ben. Our accessibility audit provider has been acquired by another company, and it seems they no longer update the list of accessibility accreditations they issued on their former website. Instead, we have updated the link to the URL of the Statement of Accessibility Conformance issued by our accessibility audit provider on the Accessibility page of the Moodle Developer Resources. Hope this helps.

ResponsesInList.Title: Follow-up on Header Hierarchy in Moodle Resources - with questions
ResponsesInList.Text: Since this thread is closed, Moodle in English: Header Hierarchy in Moodle Resources | Moodle.org , reposting for hopefullly some clarification on how to guide the use of TinyMC headings on Book Chapter content and Page content. It appears that for Books, The Book title is an H1 heading with an H2 class (image below), and the Chapter title is an H3 heading. This appears to be consistent with a Page Name also, but there are not Chapter titles. So the confusion that I have with working with Instructors is when should they be starting with an H3 or H4 heading? With the Book it appears to be H4 because the Chapter title is an H3 and in a Page it would be an H3. A little confusing based on the TinyMCE heading availability, as it provides an H3 heading in a Book but not an H2 or H1 heading for a Page. Is it safe to recommend starting with an H4 (Book Chapter content) and H3 (Page content) based on how HQ might resolve this accessibility issue? Appreciated Justin

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Follow-up on Header Hierarchy in Moodle Resources - with questions
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Justin, Sorry I haven't heard how HQ might resolve the accessibility issue, however I searched and found a tracker issue relating to it: MDL-78793 . Feel free to comment on it or watch it to receive notifications of updates.

If there is a Equation text then Equation text color is black with Hex code "#272522" and same background hex color code is "#FCEFDC".  This contrast passes "WCAG AAA" compatibility text. Having two different color for Equation texts and General text also create confusion and is not eye pleasing. (See attached image). Is there a Way possible to have general text font colour in HEX code "#272522"?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Quiz review page not properly acceesible
ResponsesInList.Text: My guess is that you are using the Formulas question type.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Quiz review page not properly acceesible
ResponsesInList.Text: Sir, Quiz question type is "Multiple choice". 1. what would be the code in that case? also, I have Administrative rights and My website is hosted by Hostinger. I am using Adaptable theme. 2. How can I reach "Advanced setting RAW SCSS field" to make the change?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Quiz review page not properly acceesible
ResponsesInList.Text: Can you confirm that you have the same issue with the Core boost theme?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Quiz review page not properly acceesible
ResponsesInList.Text: .que.multichoice instead of .que.formulas should work: .que.multichoice .specificfeedback {color:black;} .que.multichoice .generalfeedback {color:black;} You will find the setting under Appearance > Settings > Custom CSS & JS

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Quiz review page not properly acceesible
ResponsesInList.Text: Sir, Situation remains the same with boost theme.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Quiz review page not properly acceesible
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you very much sir 🙏 It worked. Now all the texts in General feedback is Black in colour.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Quiz review page not properly acceesible
ResponsesInList.Text: Marcus This is the same in core Boost, but it's not an accessibility issues as such. Moodle only targets WCAG AA compliance which this contrast level is fine for. For AAA this contrast level is ok for large text, but not normal text. I would prefer to see us change it at some point to be AAA compliant but it's not a high priority, there are larger accessibility issues that need to be addressed first like target sizes on icons etc l.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Quiz review page not properly acceesible
ResponsesInList.Text: It's interesting that Moodle is focusing on WCAG AA compliance . I get the point about the contrast level; it's okay for AA, but I see your thought about aiming for AAA compliance eventually. Totally get that there are more urgent things to tackle first, like those icon sizes. Keep pushing for improvements in accessibility – it's crucial stuff!

ResponsesInList.Text:
In order to get a non-italic font, use: ```text \( \mathrm{ your equation } \) ``` In order to get a larger font, use: ```text \( \mathrm{ your equation } \) ``` or ```text
\( \mathrm{ your equation } \)
```

ResponsesInList.Text: You get: \( \mathrm{du=dq-dw} \) \( \mathrm{du=dq-dw} \)

ResponsesInList.Title: Activity completion with no passing grade remains as “To Do” in course. Students have to click on the dropdown menu to see what is missing.
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi there, In Moodle 4.4 (with nice activity/resource new icons, it must be said ), when activity completion has the Receive a passing grade setting, the text-box remains as “To Do” if the grade is a not passing grade. So, students wouldn’t know what the actual activity status is until they click on the dropdown menu or until they go into the activity itself. I think, then, if activity completion status is not shown at a glance but a click instead, let’s make that click on the activity itself to check what is missing, but at course level add a simple way to show it… maybe with a coded check-box ;) Yes, I was wondering if it is possible to combine the M<3.11 check- box at course level, and the explicit text-box completion conditions inside the activity. The check-box code is the same as in the Activity completion report for teachers. If it is clear for teachers, why it wouldn’t be clear for students? All this reminds me the now closed Moodle Tracker MDL-71856 - Support pre-311 method of showing activity completion checkboxes within topics , where it sais: « This "Improvement Request" is to support both methods » understood as make the new text-box and the old check-box options at course level keeping the new explicit conditions text-box inside the activity. And yes, I am aware of the accessibility importance and I am agree with it, that is why the suggestion is make it as an option. What do you think? I add a couple of images to show both scenarios. ¡Saludos! PS. The Activity completion report for teachers is a very useful tool that can filter by group, by activity/resource or, by section and could be ordered alphabetically or by order in course.
