ResponsesInList.Title: Announcement to mobile users only
ResponsesInList.Text: Is it possible for an announcement to be seen by mobile users only? The announcement, of course, would be, "This website is best viewed and used in desktop mode." Thx

ResponsesInList.Title: Announcement to mobile users only
ResponsesInList.Text: If in a Text block, you could add a custom CSS class to it -- then use CSS to only show the block within certain screen dimension example: @media only screen and (min-width: 768px) { /* Hide Block with this class in non-Mobile Desktop View */ .custom-class {display: none;} }

ResponsesInList.Title: How to correct an online activity with fewer clicks
ResponsesInList.Text: Good evening, We have a moodle 3.9 with several online activities . Normally each of them has 3 open questions where they are answered with free text. When it comes to corrections, it becomes very tedious since you have to go to each response item per student, and when the popup for said response opens you have to click on rate to be able to enter a score/feedback and save. This multiplied by 3 questions for each student and 150 students is a horrible number of clicks. We would need to continue with the online questionnaire format since we have implemented a staggered entry that allows the system not to collapse. The alternative of uploading a file instead of an online assignment has been tried but it causes more problems than the one we use since there are problems with the students due to the format of the file and the possible closure of the activity before they upload it. With the online activity, it is sent automatically when the time is up even if the students do not click on the send button. The problem at this moment is basically the teacher's task to correctand how to make it more bearable in some way by maintaining this type of activity but reducing the number of clicks to correct. Any ideas? Greetings.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to correct an online activity with fewer clicks
ResponsesInList.Text: Use a quiz and then the manual grading option which allows you to mark the entries of all students in one form instead of opening many single windows.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to correct an online activity with fewer clicks
ResponsesInList.Text: Using a quiz the way Matthias suggests is probably most convenient to go along with what you are currently doing. However, any time you are wanting to have students write "free text" you might want to try out the Diary plugin.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to correct an online activity with fewer clicks
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank your for your response. But the professor must see the student response to each question before grade then they have to do every click to check the answer and after that do the grade manually as you say. The best option is to use a rubric but the quiz don't have this option.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to correct an online activity with fewer clicks
ResponsesInList.Text: So, it appears that your only problem with uploaded files is that students use different software. You can: 1) prescribe the software they must use, such as Word, text, Google, Pages, etc. Give them about three choices: Word, Google Docs, or Text. 2) train your instructors about how to open these different file types.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to correct an online activity with fewer clicks
ResponsesInList.Text: The text format (*.txt) is quite universal. You might not even need additional text files, the text can be typed straight in to the assignment.

ResponsesInList.Title: Suggested improvement
ResponsesInList.Text: When manually enrolling a student in a class it would be ideal if there was an option to assign them to an existing group in that step. This would save having to find them in the participant list after they are added.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Suggested improvement
ResponsesInList.Text: I always use a csv file, add the new users to the file, along with all the courses I want to enroll them in, along with their groups for each course. Then I upload the user file, with it set to only add new users.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Suggested improvement
ResponsesInList.Text: Perhaps. If you added a "Group" selection, the Groups would probably need to be (pre) defined before enrolling students for a dropdown to show. Right? If you thought that Groups could also be created at this stage, I don't think so. "Groups" in Moodle are very powerful, so I am one who likes that "Groups" are handled separately. But maybe this is just me. I like how Al adds students to his courses.  You might want to consider this if you are manually enrolling students yourself. But I don't do it this way.  I let students self-enroll.  Ahead of time, I set up groups and then give students an enrollment key that immediately puts them into their proper group.  However, I still check to ensure their "self" and "group" enrollments worked correctly.

ResponsesInList.Title: Suggested improvement
ResponsesInList.Text: The User Bulk Enrollment plugin allows you to to do a manual enrol and group simultaneously, it basically is a screen with a textbox where you need to paste the user's email address and type the group name, so it's not a point and click as the regular interface, but this is another location where you can do both at once... https://moodle.org/plugins/local_bulkenrol

ResponsesInList.Title: Follow up courses
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, on our Moodle site (Moodle 3.9, Boost theme), we want not make a particular course (target course) available only for people who visited/finished another one (start course). So for example if somebody wants to make say a custom cert activity available only for users who finished a test activity first it is pretty simple. In such case you can work with activity settings here, because we have all activities in the same course. In our case however the course availabilty should be subject to activities not in the same course. In the best case the whole target course is not visible if the pre-conditions are not met. Maybe it is easier to hide activities via settings  again. But under "restrict access" in the course settings I can only find criteria from the same course. Maybe it is possible to go a totally different way with the enrolment method "cohort sync". ResponsesInList.Title: New “Availability” setting for activities and resources seems a bit confusing.
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi there! Does anyone else find a bit
confusing the new combo Availability for any activity or resource in Moodle 4.3? The new setting Availability has three options: Show on course page / Hide on course page / Make available but don’t show on course page .
The last one is clearly a setting for stealth activities but, due to they are
disabled by default, what an editing user gets is a two clicks for two options (before
it was one click for Show/Hide options). Also, in previous versions, if
stealth activities are enabled, editing users could set the Make available/Make unavailable options
only if the activity is hidden first as it should. You cannot stealth an
activity that is shown in the course. And, anyway, even if stealth
activities are not enabled, “… it is stillpossible to make activities available but not shown on the course page. ” So, the one click Hide/Show
option is enough, I think. I add a couple of images on M3.11
and M4.3 to make it clearer. ¡Saludos!

ResponsesInList.Title: Where to find ALT tag in Database
ResponsesInList.Text: I am trying to clean up some accessibility issues on my website such as images that do not have an ALT description - it will take me weeks to try and locate them page by page but I am struggling to find the entry in the database ?  Surely it is in there somewhere?  Does anyone know where it is located?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Where to find ALT tag in Database
ResponsesInList.Text: They are stored in the database with the content the image is in. And, content is stored throughout the Moodle database, e.g. mdl_page.content, mdl_question.questiontext, mdl_question.generalfeedback, ...

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Closed Captioning

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Self activity
ResponsesInList.Text: I am pretty confident, that this is not possible. Creating or editing abilities is only being controlled by the capability moodle/course:manageactivities. A role has this capability in course context or not and thus can edit activities or not. ResponsesInList.Text: Based on what I know and what these other users have mentioned, I think the only way you can achieve something close to what you want, would be to give each of your users their own course with the role of teacher in it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Table captions - advice wanted
ResponsesInList.Text: I was just in a developer-y discussion about table captions (following some unhelpful feedback from an acessibility test, whch just complained that some table did not have a caption, without giving any advice about what sort of caption the table should have). Probably all tables should have a caption, to help screen-readers. If it is something like a table in some learning content, or an article, which naturally has a caption, then no worries. (But mark it up correctly .) In the fairly common case where the table comes shortly after a heading (or similar) which makse it perfectly clear what the table is, then making the <caption>text the same as the heading text is perfectly resonable, and in this case, hiding it with class=" sr-only " or similar is probably best. [For example, the table here https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/ca... probably should have a caption of 'Technical summary' but hidden. (However, it does not, which is ironic.)] If the caption text is not the same as any other text on screen, then hiding it is probably a bad smell. Any objections or improvements to those conclusions?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Table captions - advice wanted
ResponsesInList.Text: IMHO where you have placed the caption is standard for other forms of sharing information (reading, presentations, illustrations, etc.) Standardizing the caption is a good thing - most end-users will know where to look intuitively. Kind Regards

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Table captions - advice wanted
ResponsesInList.Text: I think that I see the issue, Tim (in Moodle 4.2). Below is a screenshot showing one of my "tables." Notice that this table has a clear caption. The caption is in the correct place, according to one of the style guides that I have used (I can't remember if this is APA). So, I would say this is technically correct. However, this table caption is not identified with the tag. And perhaps it should be for accessibility (screen readers). But I think a screen readers would still read "Table 1...". Yes, TinyMCE table properties can be used to "Show Caption". When I do this, the caption is at the bottom. Hmmm, a problem. Do I follow my writing guide and put the table's caption at the top, not using the tag, or do I let TinyMCE insert a tag, and then add my text to it? Another problem that I think I am noticing using TinyMCE's Table Caption is that I cannot center the caption, which it should be. So, I think I would prefer my manual method until TinyMCE's tag, and its actual text, can be moved to the top and centered. It seems to me that being technically correct for most overrides being technically correct for folks using a screen reader. I hope my thoughts are on target. Also, my style guide says that picture captions should be below the picture. Shirley suggests perhaps a "standard" position for all captions, which seems to not be in sync with my writing guide. Of course, I can manually add a caption below a figure that would not use the tag.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Table captions - advice wanted
ResponsesInList.Text: You are talking about tables in learning content - which is my Point 2. But, I am a developer, so I am currently worrying about tables in the Moodle UI, for example https://qa.moodledemo.net/mod/quiz/report.php?id=30&mode=overview - would adding a visible caption to that table make Moodle better, or would it just be clutter? What should the caption be?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Table captions - advice wanted
ResponsesInList.Text: Probably all tables should have a caption, to help screen-readers. Yes, probably. If it is something like a table in some learning content, or an article, which naturally has a caption, then no worries. (But mark it up correctly.) Yes, no worries. In the fairly common case where the table comes shortly after a heading (or similar) which make it perfectly clear [**] what the table is, then making the <caption> text the same as the heading text is perfectly reasonable, and in this case, hiding it with class="sr-only" or similar is probably best. Yes, probably best. If the caption text is not the same as any other text on screen, then hiding it is probably a bad smell. Yes, probably, although normally this should not happen. ** perfectly clear ... What is perfectly clear to one person, e.g. an experienced developer, may not necessarily be so for another, e.g. a new user. The captions could be discreet, for example, aligned to the top left, either inside or outside of the table.

ResponsesInList.Title: Why is the content area 830px wide in Moodle 4?
ResponsesInList.Text: Moving to Moodle 4 one thing that jumps out is how narrow the content area is on a desktop monitor. I am considering changing this in the custom SCSS or installing a community theme such as LearnR that has a full screen width option. But before I override Moodle's design decision, I'd like to know the reasoning behind this. Can anyone explain to me why the content width is restricted to a narrow 830px?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Why is the content area 830px wide in Moodle 4?
ResponsesInList.Text: You may take a look at https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-73918: " Login as admin Navigate to Site administration > Appearance > Themes> Boost Click the 'Advanced settings tab' In Field 'Raw initial SCSS' add $course-content-maxwidth: 1200px; $h5p-content-maxwidth: 1200px; " I'm not sure why it's 830px exactly, it may have anything to do with aligning the desktop and mobile experiences, but I always change it to 1600px.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Why is the content area 830px wide in Moodle 4?
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Daniel. The SCSS variables are useful. I've continued my search and come across a useful article at https://baymard.com/blog/line-length-readability . This research and explanation supports the width used in Boost. It recommends a line width of 50 to 75 characters. Additionally it references the WCAG https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG21/Understanding/visual-presentation.html which recommends a maximum line width of 80 characters. So based on that, I should really think carefully before messing with the content width.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Why is the content area 830px wide in Moodle 4?
ResponsesInList.Text: Talking of "recommends a maximum line width of 80 characters" the inventor of the punch card must have been a prophet: https://faculty.washington.edu/rjl/classes/am583s2013/notes/punchcard.html .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Why is the content area 830px wide in Moodle 4?
ResponsesInList.Text: It should be full width. Anyone can adjust the width of their browser to whatever they desire. Some browsers even build this into some of their features. If you want your browser to look like your smartphone, just make is narrower. Both Windows and MacOS have built-in shortcut keystrokes to do this.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Why is the content area 830px wide in Moodle 4?
ResponsesInList.Text: I agree Rick it should be a user choice. It took me a bit of swinging like a pendulum before coming to this conclusion. We often embed H5P content into the course page and that is usually better at full width, but for lots of text content, the narrower width arguably is better. I've had a go at adding a user control such as in the Adaptable theme to my fork of the Learnr theme. It doesn't address some of the width inconsistencies, e.g. the admin pages are still full width, but it is a starting point for anyone who might want to pick this up for their theme. https://github.com/noisyjerm/moodle-theme_learnr/commit/fc36530f16fd498ad2f6ff6bdd658663cd261a94#diff-a49abfc795a0f9b3d600ef406c250ada7c3a626b17771ae1a0f0d201fc712345

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Why is the content area 830px wide in Moodle 4?
ResponsesInList.Text: There seems to be at least two ways to address this current problem of 830px width of Moodle 4. 1) apply the CSS code to change it, or 2) Find (or develop) a custom theme to fix the problem. In my case, I am not a theme developer so the simple CSS works fine. But I do like seen theme developer build this directly into the theme settings. Keep up the good work, Jeremy.

ResponsesInList.Title: Threshhold for File Size Information
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi dear community In the activities , the file size is not always important. Especially if the files are only a few kilobytes in size. See the attached screenshot. In the sense of didactic reduction (minimising unnecessary information), could a threshold be inserted? For example: if the threshold is set at 5 MB, this file information will only be displayed on the course overview if it exceeds 5 MB; otherwise it will not be displayed. This way, the students know when they might or should not download this file. What do you think?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Threshhold for File Size Information
ResponsesInList.Text: In some ways its a good idea but having a sensible threshold is difficult and very context sensitive. In somewhere like Melbourne I wouldn't even bother showing it for less than 10's of MB, but even in some rural parts on australia 5 MB can be problematic. If a file is available for students it should definetly be downloadable but that is more an educational design issue than anything. The HQ team is currently looking at the activity cards and I can raise this given its timely. If nothing else we can ommit the fractional parts of the display (i.e. 102 KB rather than 102.1 KB) as it adds no value.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Threshhold for File Size Information
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi David, You may not know this, but displaying the file size in Moodle is completely optional. It's entirely up to the teacher whether they choose to show it or not. In the settings page, you can find a checkbox under the "Appearance" section that allows you to decide whether the size should be displayed on the course overview page. So, there's no need for a threshold – it's all about the teacher's preference.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Threshhold for File Size Information
ResponsesInList.Text: Looks like my team was way ahead of me Thanks Sabina

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Threshhold for File Size Information
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you, Sabina and Dalton Every little adjustment that optimises student guidance is relevant. But I agree with you: it is also a question of prioritisation. Of course, I know the "show size" function. The advantage of a threshold is that, depending on the context or needs of the school, the settings are always correct, without the lecturers having to adjust individual display options of the files, which is time-consuming. As in this example, the "102.1 KB" information is not relevant and therefore unnecessary. Basically, I think Moodle 4.x is a big leap forward in terms of UI/UX. But the usability of Moodle is not yet coherent with the needs of the students. Thanks and all the best David

ResponsesInList.Title: How to set "activity completion" with different presets, depending the activity type

By default, all the activities are set up with an active activity completion enhanced.
This is in our case absolutely unnecessary in the case of "text and media fields", but essential for activities with submissions.
At our University of Applied Arts, from a didactic point of view, all resources / content are set without completion tracking; activity completion should be set in the written assignment itself. Therefore, my question is: Wouldn't it make sense for us administrators to have the possibility to predefine which activities should / should not have "activity completion" by default? Here are some examples of the desired activity presets: Forum activity: must be answered at least once. Text activity: must be accessed. Test activity: must be completed at least once. Once the preset is defined for every single activity type, it will facilitate the use of the preconfigured activities for teachers and all stakeholders. Looking forward to reading what do you think about my idea. Best, David

ResponsesInList.Title: Accessibility audit
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, During our internship at Bordeaux INP, we conducted an accessibility audit of our institution's Moodle platform. Although we were able to make some changes on our end, we do not have access to the complete code, limiting our capabilities. Here are the main issues that we believe are important to address: Information is lost on certain pages (especially the Dashboard ) when stylesheets are disabled. Tables within courses cannot be linearized (e.g., participants). It would be necessary to add a role="presentation" attribute in the HTML code. Empty and unnecessary 'h' tags have been overlooked in several places. There is no notification to alert users when a new page or tab is opened (e.g., when accessing a course file). We appreciate your understanding and support in resolving these accessibility concerns. Best regards,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Accessibility audit
ResponsesInList.Text: Which version of Moodle please?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Accessibility audit
ResponsesInList.Text: We have just upgraded to Moodle version 4.2+ (Build: 20230504).

ResponsesInList.Title: Accessibilty Statements (Plugins)
ResponsesInList.Text:
We had an interesting conversation in the office recently about Accessibility Statements and Moodle. We drafted back in 2019 an accessibility statement ( https://www.strath.ac.uk/accessibility/myplace/ ) for or Moodle instance, but we've been re-visiting this as we're doing a bit push on accessibility particularly for content. One of the threads that came up was how do we actually go about creating and maintaining something like the document above, especially when we're using an extensible platform such as Moodle? Yes Moodle has made assertions about it's compliance ( https://moodledev.io/general/development/policies/accessibility ) but that's not quite the same as this statement about "our instance", and the issues that may arise from decisions/selections about look and feel, plugins etc. We've thought about maintaining just one big document all the time, but this is bit unwieldy and seems an awfully manual approach to this. As we were kicking this around, we thought, "what if there was a convention for plugin developers to report what known accessibilities issues there were in a given plugin?". Initially we thought "ooh we could describe that programmatically"...but that's quite a barrier and overhead, and as we looked around we came to the existing convention of the "upgrade.txt" file in Moodle. So we're proposing the following idea: Every plugin should disclose an "accessibility.md" file with the following format: 
```text
    # Accessibility statement for {friendly plugin name}({frankenstylename})




## Non-accessible content




### Issues with content


* The navigational drop-down menus in the website header are not accessible using only a keyboard. This does not meet WCAG 2.1 success criterion 2.1.1.




### Issues with images, video and audio


* Some of the alt tags for our images are missing or not appropriate. This does not meet WCAG 2.1 success criterion 1.1.1.


* Some of the pages using the legacy design include images with embedded text. This does not meet WCAG 2.1 success criterion 1.4.5.
```
 The top level heading (#) introduces the plugin in a standard format that is both human and computer readable The 2nd level heading (##) denotes high-level descriptions, I was anticipating basically "free text" and there being some "well defined" sections such as the "Non-accessible content" one. Level 3 headings (###) represent related failures groups. Finally bullets under level 3 headings represent individual failures / issues. Ideally each of the bullets would be "standardised" clauses! With this convention in place it then becomes feasible to write an aggregator / generator / Moodle page that can take all of the accessibility.md files and collate them in to 1 document, following these rules: All bullets that are identical are collapsed into a single statement, with a clause that indicates which plugins it affects, with each plugin name linking to that plugin's accessibility.md file All bullets under the same L3 heading are collated into a single L3 Heading. Resulting in a combined mark down document: 
```text
    # Accessibility Statement for {site}
    




## Non-accessible Content
    


### Issues with content
    


* The navigational drop-down menus in the website header are not accessible using only a keyboard. This does not meet WCAG 2.1 success criterion 2.1.1. (Affects [block_welcome_staff](https://site/blocks/welcome_staff/accessibility.md))





    ### Issues with images, video and audio



    * Some of the alt tags for our images are missing or not appropriate. This does not meet WCAG 2.1 success criterion 1.1.1. (Affects [block_welcome_staff](https://site/blocks/welcome_staff/accessibility.md), [block_mycoolblock](https://site/blocks/mycoolblock/accessibility.md))



    * Some of the pages using the legacy design include images with embedded text. This does not meet WCAG 2.1 success criterion 1.4.5. (Affects [block_welcome_staff](https://site/blocks/welcome_staff/accessibility.md))
```
 This MD document can then be fairly easily converted into HTML, or it can be version controlled. The links to plugin accessibility.md files could point to a Moodle page that renders them as HTML for end-users, so that the information is always up to date with the version of the plugins that *you* have on your server . Our reason for going down a file /  markdown route is that it doesn't prescribe the ways that a plugin could be failing to meet accessibility, but where there is a "standard" form they could be aggregated, and as a file in the plugin it allows the plugin maintainer to amend easily as things get fixed. Also by going to an aggregated intermediary MD format, it allows individual sites to take the "generated" version and tailor it reasonably simply to add any pre-/post-amble they'd like or take out any generated items they may have fixed locally or are not relevant, but 80% of the work is automatically done.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Accessibilty Statements (Plugins)
ResponsesInList.Text: Interesting idea! - I'm definitely interested to see how we can improve accessibility and reporting on accessibility across plugins, but as a maintainer of quite a few plugins, my preference for issue reporting and tracking of those issues is to use the issues trackers within our github repositories rather than a readme file manually committed to the repository code-base. I'd count all of the items you show in your example as bugs, and so they should really have associated bug reports within the plugins issues tracker - a public issues tracker is a requirement for plugins db approval so all published plugins should have an issues tracker. Is there a way we could standardise the issue reporting somehow? - eg in github we could use tags to flag items that are accessibility related or is there some other way we could rely on the repositories issues tracker to produce a list of the accessibility issues that might also meet your needs?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Accessibilty Statements (Plugins)
ResponsesInList.Text: I think it's an interestion quandary, yes I agree that things things are "technical" bugs in that they are and should be fixed, but at the same time, the mechanism for collating and assembling the "report" that we're obliged (under the legislation relating to public bodies) to produce would need to work, and potentially is specific to each institutions set up. This approach allows that "human readable" information to be "local" to the system, rather than something that has to be hand-collated. This also allows for a statement to be included in the plugins relating to the accessibility issues that won't be fixed, but are disclosed as such. I think also with the issue tracker itself, a lot of the content is relating to acticulating the problem in terms of it's cause and effect, and then a discussion on how it should / will be "fixed", where this information isn't particular concerned about that, but more recognising an issue in a easily comprehendable way, and cross referenced against the "standard clause" statements that almost exist. We internally maintain about 79 plugins that make our "Moodle" into our VLE, so completely do understand the development and maintenance tracking aspect of this overhead, but it's not an issue that we feel is solely addressed via an Issue tracker. The other aspect that as a text file in the plugin the list of issues being disclosed could itself also be auto-generated from a plugin's issue tracker and then be commited, so I wasn't really looking at a proscriptive of creating the accessibility.md actefact itself.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Accessibilty Statements (Plugins)
ResponsesInList.Text: My colleague also made the observation that the "bug" may be a result of a deliberate design choice, so might not be an issue, but does require disclosure that a choice to be inaccessible in some way is necessary.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Issue redirect

ResponsesInList.Title: Issue with Competency Recognition Despite Activity Completion
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Moodle Community, I'm experiencing an issue with the implementation of competencies in a Moodle course I've created. ResponsesInList.Title: Header Hierarchy in Moodle Resources
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi All, I’m trying to make sense of the Heading Structure used in Moodle 4.0 when creating accessible Moodle books . Currently, it looks like the Activity Name (Syllabus and Course Overview) is a Heading 1 (H1). However, the Chapter Name (Instructors’ Information) is a Heading 3 (H3), which means heading 2 is skipped. In Moodle 3.11, because the Course Name is included as an H1, all other components fit together (Course Name = H1, Activity Name = H2, Chapter Name = H3). Because Moodle 4.0 removes the Course name, there is the issue of skipping heading levels. When I print the book, the Heading structure is intact (Activity Name = H1, Description = H2, Table of Contents = H2, Chapter Name is H3 ). Similarly, the Heading Structure in the Moodle Page shows the Activity Name (Syllabus and Course Overview) as a H1: In the Content area, I can designate my headings using the default “Heading (large)”, “Heading (medium)”, “Heading (small)”. Which are predefined in order of: H3, H4, H5 HTML view: This is an issue because H2 is still being skipped. I know I can manually open the html view in the Content area of the Moodle Page and update the Instructors’ Information to be H2 but I think Moodle should be doing that by default if the Book title is supposed to be a level 1 heading. Is Moodle 4.0 skipping heading 2 for a reason or was this simply overlooked? Thanks, -Lance

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Header Hierarchy in Moodle Resources
ResponsesInList.Text: Im seeing the same issue.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Header Hierarchy in Moodle Resources
ResponsesInList.Text: This is a known issue which has been raised internally in HQ as it affects accessibility. We are looking to resolved this when we can.

ResponsesInList.Title: How to link to a collapsible topic
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I'm trying to create a link that links to a collapsible topic and opens that topic, that is, collapses it. My URL ends with course/view.php?id=91#section-1 but it stays uncollapsed until the user clicks on topic. How to fix this?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to link to a collapsible topic
ResponsesInList.Text: From Moodle 4.2 onwards you can add the expandsection=x param to force the section x to show expanded, where x is the section number which you want to show expanded, see MDL-75542 . It work for topics and weeks format, other course formats however maybe have not implemented this (yet), if they have their own logic of when to show a section collapsed and when not.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Hide the navigation in specific sections in the student view
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, To hide the Participants link, you need to remove the View participants capability (moodle/course:viewparticipants) from the student role. For the Skills link, if you're not using Competencies, you can disable it in Site administration > Advanced features. To hide the Grades link, go into the course settings and set 'Show gradebook to students' to No.

ResponsesInList.Title: accessible number lines?
ResponsesInList.Text: This is an image of a number line with "0" and "1" under the first two vertical marks, and then letters X A D S E K J B on subsequent marks. The question is:  "what is the coordinate of A?"  (which would be "3.") I am wondering if it's worth exploring using tables and text to try to make this accessible to students with low vision?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: accessible number lines?
ResponsesInList.Text:
Maybe someone else will know the best way to include a monospaced font in Moodle, such as Courier. If so, you could create this coordinate line with text, as shown below. I have tried to mock this up using some embedded CSS that looks like:

xxx

However, relative to accessibility , I am not sure if accessibility is improved. Perhaps an "accessibility expert" can comment. X   A   D   S   E   K   J   B <---+---+---+---+---+---+---+---+---+---+---> 0   1

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: accessible number lines?
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm thinking that an accurate description ("number line w/ evenly spaced vertical marks on a horizontal line, 0 and 1 under the first 2 vertical lines, x a d s e k j b on subsequent ones" would convey as well.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: accessible number lines?
ResponsesInList.Text: Your text (#000000) to background (#ABCCFF) color ratio of 12.81 is good and meet WCAG requirements. Contrast Checker - WebAIM➚ However, although WCAG requirements are met, your choice of colors make the figure hard to read. The Myths of Color Contrast Accessibility - UX Movement➚ For better readability, I would suggest black on white. But don't use true black, use for example #222222 (RGB 34,34,34). Or white (#FFFFFF) on Deep Koamaru (#36226A). Why You Should Never Use Pure Black for Text or Backgrounds - UX Movement➚ Effective color contrast - Lighthouse Guild➚ Enlarge font. Use a different color for letters and numbers. Axes usually point in one direction. The tick marks are usually shown on only one side of the axis. You can make the screen reader read the letters and numbers. Or write a short code to speak the letters and numbers when you hover over them. Or a little bigger:

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: accessible number lines?
ResponsesInList.Text:
A table and text will allow your screen reader to speak letters and numbers. You will get this: with this: ```text
X A D E K J B ⏵
╹ ╹ ╹ ╹ ╹ ╹ ╹ ╹ ╹
0 1
```

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, Please let me know if Moodle is compliant with the following: ADA (American Disabilities Act) FERPA (Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act) GDPR (European Union's General Data Protection Regulation) CCPA (California Consumer Privacy Act). Thanks, Abhiram Y.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: What have your searches found so far (so people don't duplicate the information you have already found)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: The answer is largely yes but it will strongly depend on your configuration, instructional design, and course strucutre/enrolement processes. This will be true of most LMS.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Compliance
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Abhiram and thank you for your question. I can confirm that Moodle is compliant with: FERPA (Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act) GDPR (European Union's General Data Protection Regulation) CCPA (California Consumer Privacy Act). However, we can not confirm compliance with the ADA (American Disabilities Act). Moodle's software can be downloaded and used globally, and as Brett says, amended by the end user in many ways, and thus we can not review all the policies applicable to the use of Moodle in all possible contexts. If you would like to provide us with a summary of the legislation in question, we would be happy to provide a high level opinion of Moodle's compliance therewith.

Since for this course, it seems a redundant piece of information, can I remove this option from the design of the quiz (all of them) as presented to the student? Thank you

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: What is the purpose of a flag in Quizzes?
ResponsesInList.Text: Another name for a flag is a bookmark - it's just a way of indicating a question that you want to return to. You can remove the option for students to flag questions by removing the flag question capability (moodle/question:flag) for the student role (at site, course or activity level).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: What is the purpose of a flag in Quizzes?
ResponsesInList.Text: Here is a video that I share with my students. It contains information about how the "flag" feature can be used (Moodle 3.11).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: What is the purpose of a flag in Quizzes?
ResponsesInList.Text: If you want to remove it from students, that is controlled by a capability, and you can change which roles have which permissions. But, as the other posters have said, there is no one purpose to the flag. It's a simple feature that can be used in various ways (or ignored).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: What is the purpose of a flag in Quizzes?
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you all for your help. This has clarified its role. We usually get feedback about a question by a direct message/email from the student, which has worked well for some years. Velson

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: show activity NOT on extra page
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Flo - Use the 'Text and media area' resource type (known as 'Label' in Moodle versions before 4.0) to present content directly on the course homepage.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: show activity NOT on extra page
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for the reply! I already found the "Text and media area" activity! I'm wondering whether it's possible, to show the content of e.g a feedback resource/activity on the course homepage?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: show activity NOT on extra page
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Flo - You can build fairly complex resources and activities using the various tools in Moodle, and the course homepage is supposed to be a starting point to get to those. There might be a case to allow something small like a poll question on the homepage, but this feature doesn't exist as far as I know. Two more suggestions: 1. You can explore and install other course formats if you're not happy with the default ones ( https://moodle.org/plugins/browse.php?list=category&id=19 ). 2. You can use the 'description' feature in the resource/activity settings along with 'display description on course page' setting to make a description of the resource/activity appear on the homepage.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: show activity NOT on extra page
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, do you think of this as an usability issue? If so, let me asure you that you do not want to display all the content directly on the course page. It will get very crowded and confusing soon. Moodle is known for the "Scroll of Death" effect, and putting all the content directly on the course page will more or less directly lead to such an effect. From my experience, it makes sense to spent some time thinking about how you want to present the content to your users and how to deal with organizing all the content, as you will probably will have too much content for too less space. And if you're thinking about accessibility (the second topic of this forum), it absolutly makes no sense to put all the content on the course page. Users expect Moodle to work and act in a certain way, which is listing all activities and content on the (front) course page, providing all the details after following a link. Modifying this expected behavior is a sure way to unsettle your users.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: show activity NOT on extra page
ResponsesInList.Text: You can achieve something like this by putting your activity in a iframe in the main course. Don't forget to hide navigation bars and so on you don't need. However, as Björn Fisseler writes, doing that too often can lead to performance problems.

ResponsesInList.Title: Accessibility change suggestions
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, while working on a project, we discovered a few areas where accessibility could be improved: 1. File picker not accessible for users with voice input The file picker API has an accessibility issue. When choosing a file to upload , the label reads “Attachment” however the input that it describes reads “Choose File” This makes it difficult for users who use their voice to interact with websites. Therefore, the label and input text should read the same. 2. Filename in File Picker not accessible for screen readers The displayed name of the file that a user has picked for upload, is not accessible for screen readers. A consequence of this is that users who rely on screen readers cannot verify that they have picked the correct file. Therefore, I suggest that you add an element that allows screen readers to read the file name. 3. Filtering enrolled users is not intuitive When filtering on users for instance, the function is not intuitive to use. To improve accessibility, “First name” and “Surname” should as a minimum be semantic headers. To improve this further, renaming the labels to “Sort on First name” and “Sort on Surname” would also be appreciated. 4. Search input is inaccessible to screen readers When the message icon is clicked, a search input appears. This input does not have a label, which makes it inaccessible for screen readers, therefore such a label should be added. The helping text “Search people and messages” is also placed below the input, and is not linked to the input, meaning that screen reader users will discover the input too late and get confused. 5. No search result count for messages makes the site inaccessible When searching for users and messages, the number of found users is not displayed. This means that screen reader users have difficulties with getting an overview of the search. The count should be displayed and have the attribute role=”status” . 6. “New activity or resource” form is inaccessible to screen readers The highlighted icons under “Select files” do not have labels or attributes that enable screen readers to read what the buttons do. Add this to make the site more accessible.

ResponsesInList.Title: Description - above or below the activity?
ResponsesInList.Text: As we build up our Moodle 4 environment at Solent, we are debating the course format layout, particularly the fact that the description appears after and below the activity icon/link. As second discussion is whether the title and icon should be the tool? Why does the tool matter? Surely the task is what matters (eg have a debate about x,y,z) rather than "here's a forum tool". The challenge in Moodle 4 (and older versions) is the call to action is also the title of the activity and the icon. I have been in touch with Martin D who doesn't recall any decision or discussion about this in the past, it just seemed logical at the time (20 years ago?). I think it is now much more obvious with the boxed in activities and icons. Could this be a setting somewhere to allow institutions decide? What would seem more logical is to have the order as below (explain the task, then do the task) Icon / Title / Mark as Done Restrictions Description of task Call to Action - link to activity What are your thoughts?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Description - above or below the activity?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Roger You wrote: > As second discussion is whether the title and icon should be the tool? Why does the tool matter? Surely the task is what matters (eg have a debate about x,y,z) rather than "here's a forum tool". Appears everywhere. I think the tracker issue is MDL-74272 . > we are debating the course format layout, particularly the fact that the description appears after and below the activity icon/link. AFAICS they can appear side-by-side. I mean the icon is a left aligned image, no text saying what tool that is, rather the title the teacher gives to that activity appearing there. Saves vertical space, more compact, better overview. The current (Moodle 4) huge icons did the reverse!

ResponsesInList.Title: Course Contents Listing
ResponsesInList.Text: I have created a Course Contents index that appears on the course menu page which I think others would find very useful. It gives direct links to lesson pages in the course, allowing the whole course to be used as a reference document. On ours, I have set it so the course contents do not appear until "End of Lesson" has been reached. However, due to my lack of skill/knowledge, I have done it manually by inserting a label, then copying and pasting each lesson title and it's page link. It's a very repetitive (boring) task, but something I think could be automated easily by someone with the knowledge and skill. It strikes me that someone who knew what they were doing could quite easily create a new item under "Add an activity or resource" maybe called "Course Contents" which does this automatically. I suspect it would be very popular, and would certainly help accessibility no end. Is this a good idea? Is anyone willing to take this on?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course Contents Listing
ResponsesInList.Text: Consider looking at the "Checklist" plugin. It creates a course listing (for students to check-off activities ) automatically. It probably doesn't do exactly what you wish, but it's worth a look.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course Contents Listing
ResponsesInList.Text: Also, if you have the Activity names auto-linking filter turned on, you don't need the links at all, just copy in the activity names: the filter does the linking for you. You might also find the Filter Codes plugin useful.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course Contents Listing

I'm no expert on Moodle, so it's highly likely I've missed something or misunderstood! I'm trying to make finding and accessing course content quick, easy and obvious. As standard, the Topic title is listed with just the titles of any Lessons in that Topic. This example has only one Lesson ; However, a lesson has multiple pages, which cannot be seen or accessed without opening the lesson, then either scrolling through it or using the "Jump to" drop down. This makes it awkward to find and access lesson pages. The student doesn't even know what the lesson pages are titled until they use the Jump to drop down. With the Contents page I have created, students can see on the first page of the course what is in each page of each lesson, and can go directly to that page to read it's content. This is impoprtant to us, as when someone is e.g. unsure how to make a child protection referral, they can find and go straight to the page titled "How to make a child protection referral" and see exactly what to do, rather than having to hunt through the lessons for the page they need.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course Contents Listing
ResponsesInList.Text: In my graphic where I show all topics, collapsed, you will see that I have around 15 different topics in my course. My second graphic shows what students see for the WK04 topic. The "WK04 Resources & Assignments" link is a web page that describes everything the student should do, along with resources, to support this topic. This is how I have structured my course(s). In your first graphic, you show a topic, "What is Abuse," and then you apparently have around 20 lessons about this one topic (from what I can see). Perhaps each of these "lessons" is an activity contained within this topic. Because you might have many lessons for a topic, you are finding it helpful to begin a topic with an index to the lessons, and you want each index item to be a hyperlink to that lesson . (However, I assume the student could scroll down to the lesson and pick it.) For the way you have created your course, I can see some value to an index (or what you have called a "course contents listing " (perhaps more appropriately called a "topic contents listing"). In my WK04 graphic, this topic represents one chapter in the textbook. A chapter can contain 5 to 15 sections , but I don't see a need to list all these sections in Moodle since they are in the textbook. Instead, I provide a Course Calendar that shows what students should read each week.  The Course Calendar shows that most chapter sections are to be read and therefore, shows "exceptions."

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course Contents Listing
ResponsesInList.Text: I can see where the confusion arises and I think we're using Moodle in slightly different ways. If I've got this right, you are largely using Moodle to organise your student's access to existing third party resources. However, we are largely using Moodle to deliver original lesson/training materials which we have created within Moodle. We use the access/completion/hide settings available in Moodle to ensure students work through the whole course sequentially - it's not possible to skip a lesson or a quiz. However, once the course is completed, the "Course Content Listing" allows them to use the course as a reference document, just as your students can use their textbooks. Need to think about the name too - your suggestion is good, but a bit too comprehenesive, as this isn't intended to link to most of the possible activites/resources that can be placed in a topic (e.g. assignment/quiz/ download /etc). It's just for direct access to the actual educational content, which in our case is lessons.

ResponsesInList.Title: Brickfield Accessibility Starter Toolkit link error
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, I am using the Brickfield Accessibility Starter Toolkit and I'm getting errors on links that are set to open in new windows. I've added explanatory text, such as " The Library of Congress website (opens in new window) will provide you with research information to complete your project." However, the error is not clearing in the Error List. Does anyone have an example of how they've corrected link text to clear the error? Thank you.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Brickfield Accessibility Starter Toolkit link error
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Elizabeth, many thanks for your question. With the Brickfield Starter checks, the only way to stop it showing up in the report is to remove the “open in new window” option. We will update our starter language string appropriately in the next update. To provide some background, there are very few valid reasons for forcing a user into a new window and there are many reasons why you should not do so. I love one quote from the Nielsen Norman Group , or NN Group, an industry recognised World Leader in Research-Based User Experience, "Opening up new browser windows is like a vacuum cleaner sales person who starts a visit by emptying an ashtray on the customer's carpet. " Here are some reasons why you should not force links to open in new windows For everyone, bouncing people into another window is a surprise and not a good one (like a box of chocolates). This will further create problems for users with low sight or cognitive disabilities who may not see that a new tab has opened. Opening a new window or tab resets the back button in that window. Users with screen readers cannot go back to the page they came from. This breaks the navigation experience for that user. Whenever someone clicks a link they should be able to go back. The back button is a heavily used feature in browsers. If the person is using a terminal - they force one window only generally, so putting a link into a new window literally means they cannot navigate between windows/tabs and will either lose the existing site or not access the new link. Navigating multiple windows/tabs is a pretty horrible experience and can cause a lot of confusion on mobile devices - especially phones - this is not an experience you want to force on your users The core, starter version flags these issues for your action. With our Premium product , we have helpers that offer different ways to handle opening links in new windows. In short - let the user decide if they want to open a link in a new window or not - and perhaps add “(external site)” as text so they can tell if it’s external.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Brickfield Accessibility Starter Toolkit link error
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Brickfield Accessibility Starter Toolkit link error
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Elizabeth, we have now submitted code via Tracker MDL-75404 to enable this feature as requested! If you'd like to review its details and even vote for it, that will show its benefits for those doing peer reviewing, to hopefully get it approved and integrated into the next Moodle minor release.

ResponsesInList.Title: Customize the Alt Text for Moodle Core Webpages
ResponsesInList.Text: Is there a way to customize the core web pages within Moodle (like the forgot password page, course overview pages, etc.)? I need to be able to customize the ALT text accessibility of these pages . For example, the close button on some pages reads “Times sign” by a screen reader instead of the close window. Also sometimes the screen reader focus is out of order on some pages (reading items at the bottom of the page first, etc.) And yes I have checked Moodle documentation, plugins, and all my admin settings and I do not see any options for this.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Customize the Alt Text for Moodle Core Webpages
ResponsesInList.Text: Whenever you believe there are alt-text issues with any Moodle graphics, report this as a bug in Moodle Tracker . They should be fixed.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Customize the Alt Text for Moodle Core Webpages
ResponsesInList.Text: As Rick says, that is a bug. ALL alt text should be in the language pack as a language string and you should be able to change and customize that as usual. It should never be hard coded. You can verify whether an alt text is hard coded or is a proper language string using the Debugging tool to show origin of language strings . Focus is a separate issue from strings, that's a theme problem, and should be reported too.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Customize the Alt Text for Moodle Core Webpages
ResponsesInList.Text: I tried to check the language pack but maybe I was doing it wrong. Do I just search for the alt test that is wrong? So in the example above, search for "Times sign" and replace it with close?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Customize the Alt Text for Moodle Core Webpages
ResponsesInList.Text: Kim, Yes, if it is wrong then you can change it for your own Moodle instance by putting what you want in the Local customization field for that particular string. The details are in the documentation for Language customisation . This only updates it for your site, not for core Moodle, so reporting errors is still important so that the language pack maintainers, which for default English is Moodle HQ itself, can fix those.

ResponsesInList.Title: Design Flaws in Moodle 4.0
ResponsesInList.Text: There is so much that is great in Moodle 4.0, forgive me for posting a baiting title concerning flaws in the interface. I just completed a Moodle Users Association Town Hall where Chris Kenniburg pointed out three design flaws in Moodle 4.0 that he is attempting to correct with the upcoming LearnR theme. What do you think of these three issues that he points out? course index block drawer page widths ....because five-year olds cannot find what to do. Check out the attached Town Hall Summary.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Design Flaws in Moodle 4.0
ResponsesInList.Text: I don't know that I'd call them issues but I think there is a need for a more flat way to navigate around. I'll record a video more fully explaining but in k12 and maybe corporate training, the navigation must be direct and guide or keep the user on track. The course homepage provides context and instruction on what needs to be completed (or should anyways). From there the student jumps into the content. We can keep them in the content with activity navigation or they can pop back to course homepage to see what needs to be completed next. The course index distracts from this process and guidance. At least, this is our initial thought. Once a user is done in a course they can exit to my courses or the dashboard for more upcoming due dates. As for blocks, we felt it might be best to try and keep access to those on the page and provide a bigger area to place blocks. That led to header and footer block panels. This puts all learning content and course navigation in plain view. We think this lowers the stress of having too much on the screen and helps guide the user into a path to access learning materials. If a user is guided, they don't feel confused or scared that they are not on the right location. They can feel this way if there are too many ways to end up at the same spot. Our new theme allows site admins to focus the learner on a path to access course content in a way that feels guided. Some longtime Moodle users might feel as though something is amiss because you are familiar and have formed pathways on how you access things in the site. New users do not have this. The LearnR theme provides a focused path that is more simple and easier to understand and doesn't allow shortcuts which new users find confusing.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Design Flaws in Moodle 4.0
ResponsesInList.Text: As I have said in other places so far: 1) The course index does not work in long courses with have on the order of 50 or 100+ activities in them. Basically, we now have two scrolls of death: a long one with topics and a short one with the course index. Secondly, it forces students to do a lot of opening and closing of the sections . This has been a source of complaints for years with the front page tools like the Combo box. The NavDrawer was actually easier to use than the index is. The one really nice thing about it that it scrolls in synch with the topics scrolling. The real issue behind this is: it is hard for the student to get exactly where they need to be to do the work they need, either the activity they are currently working on or the very next thing they have to do. That's 80 percent of the course nav they use right there. it is still hard to do that.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Design Flaws in Moodle 4.0
ResponsesInList.Text: I don't know whether this has been mentioned (there are simply too many, reappearing in various places). ?5) The "card" around each activity. Scroll the Moodle in English homepage and see whether you notice when you go from one section to the next!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Design Flaws in Moodle 4.0
ResponsesInList.Text: Randy, I think we are on the same page with some of the usability aspects. 1) The course index does not work in long courses with have on the order of 50 or 100+ activities in them. We agree and think the actual course page can suffice as the main navigation because it actually provides the information students need to know which activity or topic they need to be in and working on. 2) As I mentioned also elsewhere I have worked with the RemUI theme for several years and it has this block drawer on the right. It is a source of support issues because Teachers will put important blocks there that students never see. I can confirm some users never ever knew there was a course drawer and when it disappeared they had no clue how to bring it back.  Kids simply didn't click on anything unless told by a teacher to do so if it was a link located outside of the normal activity area. 3) White space is wasted space unless it is actively clarifying navigation and content. We have no idea what user screens or monitors or visual needs may be. Narrow screens make for longer courses and more scrolling. Going from narrow to wide in an activity drove me nuts.  I couldn't predict which activity would display which way and certain ones I thought should have been full screen were not. 4) I will add another one we have discussed in the forums: removal of the Back to Top ability in the Topics format. This is closely related to the course index issue: the only way to get back to the top as a Student (since you don't have a secondary nav like Teachers do) is to scroll - is it easier to scroll the main topics view or easier to click into the course index and scroll there? Either way is too much work. This is on our list to bring back in the LearnR theme. I absolutely love the new topics course format.  I love the Dashboard and My Courses split.  I love the icons and other aspects of the pages.  The Primary and Secondary menus are amazing and so much more organized.  The more I use Moodle 4 without any drawers, the more I love the way it feels to use the tool.  It's predictable.  It's clean.  It makes sense with how I must navigate from course to course and activity to activity.  We won't get deep level input from our users until next year when we launch Moodle 4 in the fall.  Until then, I will be updating some Professional development training sites to Moodle 4 soon.  There is a lot to love about Moodle 4.

ResponsesInList.Title: Redesigned Themes for Usability in Moodle 4.0
ResponsesInList.Text: I agree that the course page itself is enough for navigation that a course index is unnecessary. That has been my experience--in addition, my students have never touched the course index in my experience in a blended classroom. And Chris, since you mentioned these may not be design issues or flaws, I renamed this thread "Redesigned Themes for Usability in Moodle 4.0".

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Redesigned Themes for Usability in Moodle 4.0
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Don You wrote: > I agree that the course page itself is enough for navigation that a course index is unnecessary. I seriously doubt that. The course I am building right now has six chapters, each having four to six sub-chapters. The sub-chapters in turn have three to four sections . The sections are where the resources and activities appear. I got the structure under control with the excellent https://moodle.org/plugins/format_multitopic plug-in. Here is the navigation menu as displayed in https://moodle.org/plugins/theme_rebel (1. Programming is a chapter, 1.1 Hello World! is a sub-chapter, 1.1a, 1.1b,.. are sections): The multitopic format brings a two-level "tabbed" (horizontal) navigation which I use most of the time. Still the left-side navigation is an enhancement, and not obstrusive since it is to be opened as closed as needed - at least in Rebel. Agree with the new title "Redesigned Themes for Usability in Moodle 4.0". We need Chris' theme factory!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Redesigned Themes for Usability in Moodle 4.0
ResponsesInList.Text: I ask the question, "How does the student know what to complete in the course?" That answer is not universal but the most obvious place to do so in Moodle is the course homepage whether by a forum announcement, a due date, context from the section a teacher has highlighted, completion data, or a mix of these. So, it would make sense that they go back to the course page for information on what needs to be done after completing an activity. I look at this navigation pathway like a football quarterback moving his team down the field. They execute a play(activity) and come back to the huddle for the next play and the next play until we score a touchdown and complete the course. The course index cannot call plays. It is like the head coach with the playbook. The playbook/course index is useful for the quarterback but not the players because the players are executing what's being called on the field. They do not know what will be next and they aren't particularly interested in just randomly running plays in their freetime. I do see the benefit of the course index for the teacher but I worry our students might not find it useful. Now I could be entirely wrong in this opinion. We won't know for sure until later this year. We might still include it if we see friction in moving about a course. To be fair, some courses might be incredibly long or layered. Maybe the course index is needed because it provides a simple list of everything in the topic/section for the user. However, a better course format could fix this. For instance, once you enter into an activity in a course you might expect to see a list of the section activities to the right of the page much like a table of contents. That list can contain the completion checkboxes and help guide the user through the topic/section. However, all of this distracts the user from executing the play and getting back to the huddle. I would consider this jumping from activity to activity like a "hurry up offense" at the end of the game. There is a reason teams don't run a hurry up offense without going to the huddle. The activity navigation could be a less obvious way to move about in a planned hurry up offense and is less distracting than my table of contents suggestion. I love the concept of the course index but it is too far removed from the individual activity and section with a bird's eye view of the entire course. I would propose the course index ONLY appear when working on an activity and be limited to only the items in the same topic. Generally, teachers move through a topic at a time. This might be useful and not overwhelming with everything in the course presented at once. It helps provide a slightly bigger view from where the student is in the course. I am in an activity but also here are the rest of the materials in that same general context. Now, to be honest I am not sure if it should be in the drawer or visible to the left of the content on the activity page. At full width, this is possible and might work. I guess I am saying there are lots of ways to navigate within a course that must be considered. Do I know best? Absolutely no. That's why the theme gives the flexibility to consider these scenarios and plan it out accordingly for your learners. I like the course index for me but I am unsure about student use at this time. My daughter instinctively used it but a case could be made that I was sitting next to her directing use. Internally, we are still working on our rostering plugin and once that is done we will be asking teachers to take a look and might present a few different looks with and without the course index to see which they prefer. We'd do this with students too. Our initial thinking is to strip this down to the bare minimum so that we can "simplify" the tool for staff who might say Moodle is complicated. A simple pathway like the huddle/quarterback does demystify how you get around inside a course in Moodle. It makes that part simple and easy to understand.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Redesigned Themes for Usability in Moodle 4.0
ResponsesInList.Text: Talking of themes taking over the UX, here's a first example https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=434012#p1747254 .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Redesigned Themes for Usability in Moodle 4.0
ResponsesInList.Text: I agree with all the Chris and Don says above, but also I do have my doubts along with Visvanath about the course topics being sufficient itself. I have been thinking about a good way to overcome all this and I think that having a sticky secondary nav bar for the student role could solve some of theses issues. A sticky student secondary nav always has a "Course" link to the main topic: the solves the Back to Top issue and also means you can finally remove the remnant of the breadcrumb from the new Activity page. Add Sections to the secondary nav: this is how the NavDrawer worked - the problem with that wasn't the section list per se, it was the way the it looks and works. Having a section list on the top pull down menu follows a menu convention we have had since the days of DOS (and before). Put both a Grades and a Progress item on the sticky menu and have them be controlled by the existing course level settings to Show grades / Enable completion tracking. A main progress report of completions is far more used than all the other "Activity reports". The little icons on the Course index and the Course topics indicators are good as were the old style checkboxes, but they are no substitute for a good report for Students which we have never really had. Most importantly, a dd a Menu item to go to the most recently used and/or completed activities . This can be done in the Recently accessed block on the Dashboard , but it should be in the course itself on the secondary nav, not in block hidden away in its drawer but somewhere always accessible, like a sticky secondary nav. After all, we know where users last were in each course in the mdl_block_recentlyaccesseditems table and we know what they have completed already too. And we know all the due dates of activities too. And if the Teacher has highlighted a section, put that in the menu too. What you want is a menu with a few options on it showing the key navigational points in the course. So - - Last thing I worked on not yet complete - Other last thing I worked on if still not complete - Last thing I completed - Item(s) with due date(s) real soon - Teacher highlighted section Put these in the course. Having them the dashboard is good. But in a course students need to navigate locally without leaving the course to use the Dashboard to go back in to the same course. And with the new Block drawer, as I mentioned is the case for RemUI users already, you can have no confidence at all the students will see or use blocks that may do such service. I think putting them on a stick secondary nav is the way to go. Students should not have to scroll to get to an activity they are working on or to the last activity you completion (presuming you will be doing the next one in order, which may or may not be true, but we can't read minds quite yet.) This idea is already a part of the functionality of some of the Dashboard blocks, but it should be in the course and the secondary nav is the place for that. The primary / secondary navs are one of the best features of 4.0 - I heartily applaud moving away from the NavDrawer - and they should really be used more. But they also need to be made more customisable by admins and teachers too who can make adjustments to the menus depending on how they and their organization use courses.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Design Flaws in Moodle 4.0
ResponsesInList.Text: A bit of margin between the last box in a section and the next section is all it would take. Add the following to the page styles and the experience is greatly improved - on a page where it is expected you will be scrolling anyway. .course-section-header:not(:first-of-type) { margin-top: 5rem; }

ResponsesInList.Text: The toolkit runs through scheduled tasks which run on cron. If you want to make the re-analysis happen faster, you can make those tasks every minute or two minutes. Regards Gavin Co-Founder of Brickfield Education labs

ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks v much. I hadn't realised that the report was re-run automatically based on scheduled tasks. I see now coming back to it a few days later that it has indeed re-run. Thanks for a really great tool.

ResponsesInList.Title: Documentation on Tiles accessibility
ResponsesInList.Text: I am trying to find documentation on the Tile format accessibility without luck. Would anyone know of resources on this topic?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Documentation on Tiles accessibility
ResponsesInList.Text: Did you find any info? Im also interested in how accessibile that format is

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Documentation on Tiles accessibility
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Karen, It was hard to find anything specific to TIles. But Moodle is WCAG compliant https://moodle.com/news/moodle-wcag-2-1-aa-accessibility-compliance/ Whilst I'm a novice user I tried out Jaws and NVDA, and after found I was able to navigate successfully. However, the modal windows could cause issues for those using screen magnifiers, or making it difficult to adjust the screen layout for those who might find it cognitively distracting, eg neurodiverse students. One thing I discovered is that a student can choose to turn off the animated navigation ie modal window in Tiles layout and Moodle becomes a traditional website with the whole page changing with each link clicked and minus the modal windows. This makes it more flexible for diverse learner needs. We are promoting this to students along with other hacks for inclusive Moodle use. If you happen to find any specific information please drop a reply here. Cheers, Justin

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Documentation on Tiles accessibility
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Justin. I'll certainly share anything I find

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Can students access content without having to download Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: No students have to download Moodle to access it - you are on a Moodle site now and you didn't have to download it, did you? It is just a website. If you mean can students access a course online without having to download the course materials - well that very much depends on what your course is made off. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Can students access content without having to download Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: Students don't need to download any software to access a Moodle course (unless you want them to use the mobile app on their smartphones)To access it on the internet as a regular website you just need to allow them access. You might be interested in the Admin Basics courses on Moodle Academy too

ResponsesInList.Title: Additional time setting (override) on all activities
ResponsesInList.Text: In my university students can get "reasonable accommodation" e.g. for neurodiversity. One of the measures is to give them additional time on all activities where anything needs to be completed. On the quiz activity there is a way to deal with this and I e.g. put every participant who gets 50% additional time into a group "half extra" and that works fine. I would like this group override feature generalized so it can be applied to any activity that has any deadlines in it. The trickiest case I can think of right now is in the workshop activity where an override for the submission of a student A would need to cascade to an automatic override for any students B who is the evaluator for A. Ideally, that override for B would only be for those evaluations that have themselves been overridden not for the evaluation of submissions from a student C that does not have an override for their submission.

ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks, Mary. Yes, MDL-72454 removed the "back to top" button. And yes, if the (left-side) course index is open, one can navigate to any resource, activity, or topic. So perhaps the "back to home" button isn't needed. But, what about some activities that can get long, like forum discussions ? The "back to top" button shows in Moodle 3.11, but doesn't show in Moodle 4. And forum discussions don't have any navigation tool, as quizzes have. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: "Back to Top" Button Missing in Moodle 4
ResponsesInList.Text: If I'm not mistaken this was something introduced by a UX decision visible on this Figma Design Somehow, only now the secondary navigation is b eing changed to stick on top .  While this isn't the same than having a "BAck to top" button, it helps. Personally, I'd rather have the old back to top button than the new button with that floating information.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: "Back to Top" Button Missing in Moodle 4
ResponsesInList.Text: "Personally, I'd rather have the old back to top button than the new button with that floating information." Yes, Hugo, I too agree. I found it to be a nice feature.  However, it doesn't seem to be a big enough deal to me to complain about it.  I use Safari, and the "Command+up arrow" keystroke goes to the top in most cases.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: "Back to Top" Button Missing in Moodle 4
ResponsesInList.Text:
That is absolutely necessary in courses that are long: say having 120 or more activities in them. In long courses, the new index is of no help whatsoever in getting back to the top because the index scrolls too. Back to top is a standard feature in any web site with long pages. Instead we get something that looks pretty while making user navigation
much harder. Effectively what we now have are two "scrolls of
death"-0 the traditional long one and a new shorter one. Neither with a
way to get back to the top. Worst of all, the only reason for this change was "The new page footer button is taking the spot where the back to top link is rendered now." Well, put it somewhere else then. You've now got a persistent top menu bar for one thing. Put in the new course index then. Or have it float like a thousand other back to top methods. You don't have to recreate the wheel, but you do need a wheel.
