ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Auto-resize every uploading images
ResponsesInList.Text: Consider the image optimizer plugin? https://moodle.org/plugins/filter_imageopt

ResponsesInList.Title: Odp: Re: Auto-resize every uploading images
ResponsesInList.Text: i know this plugin but it doesnt work ( i installed , configured and try using - its still in my moodle ). From computer when i add a picture 4,6 MB it sends end a get an information that the file is to big ( max 2 MB) . So it doesnt work as i expected. Is there another way?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Odp: Re: Auto-resize every uploading images
ResponsesInList.Text: Unfortunately, there is no ready-made solution at the moment for moodle (:

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Auto-resize every uploading images
ResponsesInList.Text: Actually there is a standard feature that does this although it could be fine tuned. The pdf feedpack plugin for assign does generated a compressed or reduced resolution image that is substantially smaller than the original. To do see this set up assignment where students upload a full scale image and enable pdf feedback under the feedback options in the setting. The image converter needs to be set by the admin and ghostscript installed for it to work correctly. When the teacher grades the assignment an image is generated for the teacher to see and to mark with annotations. The image is reduced from the original resolution. You can right click the image and select 'View background image' to download the png image. I uploaded a 4M jpeg image file and downloaded a 825K png file. The ghostscript options in edit pdf plugin could be changed to give a better result. Unfortunately, the file converter is difficult for most admins to set up or they do not do it for various reasons, but it actually performs some very useful functions.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Auto-resize every uploading images
ResponsesInList.Text: In the Moodle version 3.8, I did not find these settings. assignfeedback_editpdf (2019111800). There are only settings: - assignfeedback_editpdf | default - assignfeedback_editpdf | stamps

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Auto-resize every uploading images
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes the final pdf is slightly larger than the original which wraps the annotations around the image. However the editor displays a png image that is optimized for display in a browser. This image can be downloaded by right clicking the image in the editor and selecting view background image .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Auto-resize every uploading images
ResponsesInList.Text: It is best to find a solution for implementing imagemagick to optimize the image.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Auto-resize every uploading images
ResponsesInList.Text: Currently, I have managed to create a separate plugin for uploading the response as a photo. This plugin now works identically to the answer plugin as a file. The only thing I can’t do now is to process uploaded photo files through ImageMagick processing. To do this, I need more time to work out the necessary algorithm when implementing an additional function using ImageMagick for processing graphic images, unloading organized in my new plugin for moodle.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Auto-resize every uploading images
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Yevgenii, That looks like a really cool idea for a plugin. Imagemagick is a more capable than gd is usually used in core. I discovered another way to handle this is with the database activity. You can add a picture field in a template with image dimensions specified for single and list view. The templates are displayed with thumbnails generated to the specified values. Clicking views original, but thumbnails can be downloaded with right click. Sometimes the conversion fails silently (depending on dimensions) and the original image is resized in browser.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Auto-resize every uploading images
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Daniel, Initially, I was thinking of adding an additional basic settings option to the new plugin: width (px) x height (px) and image compression quality. This can be done in the form of a drop-down list or enter values in the form field manually. Now this task is not the main thing for me. Currently, I see 3 ways to solve this task. 1) At the moment, my main task is to find the optimal solution for inserting the image processing function through ImageMagick, which works only through the file entry and exit procedure. Otherwise, you can restart the server ’s central processor, which may slow down the kernel moodle. In order not to overload the server’s CPU during mass processing of photo files, which may lead to a slowdown in the moodle core performance. I don’t want to make changes to the moodle kernel code either. Otherwise, every time after updating the kernel of the system, me will have to make additional code changes every time. 2) At the time of the formation of the pdf document when creating a temporary png file from the original downloaded photo file - at this moment can add the ImageMagick function to optimize the photo according to the parameters set in advance. In the work of this procedure there will be no mass load on the central processor of the server until the teacher opens the desired original file through the "grade" tool. 3) The next version of the tool is related to photo optimization. Need to create a new script separate from moodlethat will work only in a specific moodeldata directory and process the newly created graphics extension files in it. Now the main thing is to decide on the right decision on choosing the optimal path.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Auto-resize every uploading images
ResponsesInList.Text: Yevgenii, A lot of the work may all ready have been done in Moodle with editpdf with the File converters api https://docs.moodle.org/dev/File_Converters . You could create and file converter plugin with Imagemagick that would create thumbnails.

After changes file  should finish upload and placing in right place in  the course. https://www.php.net/manual/en/book.imagick.php

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Auto-resize every uploading images
ResponsesInList.Text: This issue of "filesizes" is present in almost anything that gets uploaded, not just photos. For example, if you want a student to upload a pdf file, the student's pdf file might be 10MB in size, whereas if one were to compress it, it would be only 15KB. A dramatic difference. Same thing for videos, audio, even PowerPoints and Word files. I do like Daniels's suggestion to have a built-in link to some kind of File Converter.  This is an interesting approach. It may be a little difficult to expect Moodle to have build-in filesize optimizers for all of these various formats. Maybe someday. But until that day, the best thing that I have found is to try to explain to students how to reduce the size of media. For example, in my "Introduce Yourself" forum, I tell students that they can upload pictures, but to try to keep their pictures to 400x400 pixels. Do they listen? (Ans: No. I have yet to show them the easiest universal way to do this.)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Odp: Re: Auto-resize every uploading images
ResponsesInList.Text: The upload a file function is a repository plugins. Instead of using 'Upload file' users have the option to selct files from 'Server files' and 'Private files' repositories in activities . So in principle a file could be uploaded to Moodle and compressed. The compressed file could be loaded from one of those repositories. A new repository plugin might also be made that would of compressed versions the users Private files. Actually I think there must already be (or one time were) ways of doing the with existing repository plugins (Flickr, Picasso, Gdocs etc.).  For example users can upload a file to G Drive, manipulate it with Docs tools, and then use plugin integration to insert the content in any activity. That requires admin to set up the integration and for users to set up account with the service and then link them with Moodle. This should also work with the other office suite integration.

ResponsesInList.Title: Required Common Quiz for verifying active participation
ResponsesInList.Text: I am looking a Moodle for a possible replacement to our current LMS. One thing we are looking for is a way to ensure active student engagement.  I am aware of the Analytics module, but we are looking for a more active way of ensuring student engagement in their classes. Currently we have a custom module that requires students to take a quiz prior to gaining access to each of their enrolled classes. The content on the quiz is basic university based information.  The way is currently works is they are a guest in the class. they take the quiz and their role is changed to student. As a guest they do not have access to the course material, it just holds them in the participant list. and adds to class to their class list. I realize that things may nor work the same with Moodle but we are looking for some sort of gate activity that will help us verify active participation. So is anyone doing something similar to this or are you aware of any plug-ins that will help us accomplish this Just a note. I am new at this institution and worked with Moodle previous to this. Thanks Kyle

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Required Common Quiz for verifying active participation

The goal seems to be to give students a bad user experience, by making them jump through some stupid compiance hoop. Or, have a welcome forum which you actively moderate, again with in intrigueing on-topic question to provoke discussion. I mean, whatever alleged requiremen that the powers that be, or the status quo, seems to be forcing you to implement. Can you dig into it and try to find out what they really want, and then find a way to achieve that which does not tread your students like naugthy, un-trustworthy boys and girls, becuase I imagine that is not the kind of learning culture you really want to promote.

ResponsesInList.Title: To what extent is Moodle usable in Arabic
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi All. I am doing an evaluation of various LMS solutions for a client. They need an LMS that is fully functional in English, French, Portuguese, and Arabic. I need to know to what extent Moodle is usable in Arabic. I saw that 72% of Moodle has been translated into an Arabic language pack, but what does this mean? How much of Moodle will a user be unable to use because of that remaining 28% that is not available? Also, on language packs, will a separate deployment be required for every language pack? Or will users be able to simply select their language and see a different language version of the deployment? Are language packs available in Moodle Cloud ?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: To what extent is Moodle usable in Arabic
ResponsesInList.Text: I don't know about the arabic language pack, but I can make the following general points: Hundreds of registered Moodle sites in the middle east ( https://stats.moodle.org/ ), and that includes some big players like the Arab OU. Moodle has many features, most of which you won't use. And most features have obscure error messages. 72% of all strings translates can easily be 99.9% of strings anyone ever sees translated. If you hit an un-translated string that is really important for your Moodle site, you can immediately fix it in your own site using Language customisation - so you won't be stuck waiting for someone else to translate it. And, translating Moodle is a colaborative effort, so as well as fixing the translations yourself, you can contribute them back to the main project at https://lang.moodle.org/ . Regarding how this is all configured, and how it looks to users, the best thing is to get a test site, and experiment for yourself. You can start experimenting at the demo site https://qa.moodledemo.net/ which seems to have lots of languages installed. You can also read the docs at Language settings .

ResponsesInList.Title: Quiz: "Submit Answer" not "Next Page"
ResponsesInList.Text: IMO : Moodle's method of moving on to the next question in a quiz could be a little more clear. At the bottom of the question there is a "Next Page" button which means submit your answer and go on to the next page. Below that there is a quiz navigation "finish attempt" link. So which is it? IMO: "Next Page" does not really tell you exactly what you are doing.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Quiz: "Submit Answer" not "Next Page"
ResponsesInList.Text: Personally, I don't use the Next page option. I prefer to have all questions on one page. You can change it from the Quiz settings / Layout.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Quiz: "Submit Answer" not "Next Page"
ResponsesInList.Text: But Next page does not submit the answer. You can go back and change it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Quiz: "Submit Answer" not "Next Page"
ResponsesInList.Text: I think it depends what you are doing. I prefer quizzes that are more about learning than testing. Therefore I strongly prefer How questions behave: Interactive with multiple tries, and with that behaviour, one question per page is best. If, however, you are using Deferred feedback quizzes, and you only have a few questions (recommended), then all questions on one page is best. It really all depends what sort of feedback cycle you want to set up for your students.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Quiz: "Submit Answer" not "Next Page"
ResponsesInList.Text: This is a common misconception: When go to the next page Moodle saves the answers in the outgoing page, that does not submit anything. You can submit the whole in one go, there is special button (differently labeled) on the last page. The "saving" the answer feature could be crucial if your batteries drain during the exam! @Mary, in your one page exam, there'll be nothing to recover after a violent exit, typically the session being timed out. Whatever, you should remember that quizz is not designed for you nor for me , it is designed for all . it is one feature the big TEAMS-and-FORMS-craze can not beat.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Quiz: "Submit Answer" not "Next Page"
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Walter, If you prefer to use something besides "Next Page" you can also change it for your whole site via Language customization. In the en language pack, or whichever applies to your site, the component is mod_quiz, the string is navigatenext and the standard text you want to change is Next page.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Copy a forum to 100's of courses
ResponsesInList.Text: If you want to have a separate, individual course forum in each course, the backup once, restore multiple times. Or if you have the sharing cart installed, use it to place in every course. If it is okay to have just one forum used by EVERY course, create the forum in the Main Menu on the front page . Then configure the Main Menu Page contexts to, Display throughout the entire site.

ResponsesInList.Title: Gradebook - appearance more akin to Activity Completion?
ResponsesInList.Text: While I adore Moodle, I often find the UI of the gradebook difficult to handle because of the "scroll of death left".  The sidescroll is extensive, largely because the activity names are horizontal . Have moodle devs considered changing the activity names to a vertical structure more akin to the activity completion to make viewing the gradebook more manageable?  See attached.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Gradebook - appearance more akin to Activity Completion?
ResponsesInList.Text: In the meantime, With a little css you can achieve that - I'll post the code when I get into work

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Gradebook - appearance more akin to Activity Completion?
ResponsesInList.Text: That would be great! I just think it makes soooo much sense.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Re: Gradebook - appearance more akin to Activity Completion?
ResponsesInList.Text: Well I opened my big mouth way to soon. The gradebook (having several rows and headings before the grades) is much more complex than the activity completion report (which has only 1 row/heading before the checkboxes). I was able to get somewhat there but it all depends on how your gradebook is structured. So.... I'd suggest opening an Improvement Suggestion tracker ( https://tracker.moodle.org/ ) so the professionals can weigh in with their thoughts.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Re: Gradebook - appearance more akin to Activity Completion?
ResponsesInList.Text: Garth, I hear you. However, the problem might be that since the nature of this resource (i.e, the grade book "spreadsheet") one could ask is it better to scroll left, or down?  If we flip the grade item titles 90 degrees, and the title is long, then I would have to scroll down to see all the students.  So I am not sure which is better. It is interesting that some years ago, Blackboard (or maybe it was D2L) had a decent solution.  Each grade book item had both a regular name and a " short name ."  In the grade book, the short name was used.  (From what I can tell, the current Canvas method is a bit strange because the width of each column has a lot of dead space, maybe 35%-45%. See below.) So, this idea of each activity having both a short name and regular name might be an approach to fixing the grade book display problem.  However, one more "field" of information would need to be entered, or an auto-abbreviation method employed.  I sense that this concept would take some serious thinking about the best way to implement it.  Of course, there would probably need to be another setting for the grade book "Display short name (Y)?" A possible quick fix might be a grade book setting that says "Rotate titles 90 degrees (N)?"

ResponsesInList.Title: Gradebook - appearance more akin to Activity Completion?
ResponsesInList.Text: This is the closes I could get with some CSS: skinny columns and rotation of the text: .path-grade-report-grader .gradeitemheader a {max-width: 150px;} .path-grade-report-grader .item.catlevel1.cell a, .path-grade-report-grader .item.catlevel2.cell a {white-space: pre-wrap; transform: rotate(270deg);} or, skinny columns but no rotation of the text: .path-grade-report-grader .gradeitemheader a {max-width: 150px;} .path-grade-report-grader .item.catlevel1.cell a, .path-grade-report-grader .item.catlevel2.cell a {white-space: pre-wrap;}

ResponsesInList.Title: User Experience (Ux)  Design / User Interface (UI) Design
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I have been in HealthCare for almost 13 years and we have used Moodle for that period of time. I have created lots of Online modules in moodle, Articulate Storyline, and WordPress. I have good UxD, UI and IxD experience. The PROBLEM: In the past we created User Guide on how to navigate and work within Moodle. But this guides were created to navigate users through roadblocks. We also used CSS to customize the book and quiz pages to the extend of our ability. However, when our developers installed moodle updates the CSS would break and there was too much manual labour involved to correct that. So what we did was not a sustainable solution . ResponsesInList.Title: Assign plugin feedback not expanding in Safari
ResponsesInList.Text:
Using the assign activity, whenever the teacher leaves enough feedback to a submission, the section will be contracted, but the link on the expand '+' button does not work on Safari upon page loading. However, if we execute on the console: 
```text
$('.expandsummaryicon')[0].click();
```
 The contract '-' and the expand '+' links start working normally. This behavior is found Safari for IOS as well as MacOS. On the other browsers it works as intended. Tried fixes: On the file: mod/assign/renderer.php There were 2 lines with this exact same call: 
```text
$this->page->requires->js_init_call('M.mod_assign.init_plugin_summary', $jsparams);
```
 Those were changed to this: 
```text
$this->page->requires->js_init_call('M.mod_assign.init_plugin_summary', $jsparams, true);
```
 Adding the 3rd parameter which sets the ondomready value to true. but the behavior did not change and the Safari error remains. Please help! Best regards Felice PS: To contract the feedback via JS console on the navigator, you can execute: 
```text
$('.expandsummaryicon')[1].click();
```

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Assign plugin feedback not expanding in Safari
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Felice, I've seen you've already opened MDL-68035 : I think it could be a duplicate of MDL-67442 . HTH , Matteo

ResponsesInList.Title: How to make a quiz containing 10 questions at random from a bank of 20 is not discoverable
ResponsesInList.Text: I guess this is the place to find helpful usability people who might like a challenge. It seems that, for a significant minority of users, it is not obvious how to do step 2 of the following: They already have 20 questions in the question bank. They want to create a quiz that give 10 different questions picked at random for each student. (Here is the latest request for help in the forum: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=395272 , but we get this question every so often.) I am not going to explain how it should work here, because some of you usability folks might not know yet, and you can try it for yourself, and see if you can work at the UI. (If you want to know, you can look it up in the docs on the 'Building quiz' page). If you do want to try it, then the easiest way conduct a usability test yourself is: Go to https://qa.moodledemo.net/course/view.php?id=2 . Log in as teacher. Turn editing on. Add a quiz (you only need to type a name. You can ignore the rest of the form). Then you are ready to try to perform the actual task: you want the quiz to ask each student 5 questions at random from the 'Default for QE' category that already exists in the question bank and contains 10 questions. As I already said, from the sequence of questions people ask in the Quiz forum when they can't work out how to do this, I know there is a usability problem here (although once you know how to do it, the interface is quite easy to use, flexible and efficient.) I have never been able to think of a good way to change the UI to make things better, so I thought I woudl ask here, and hope that someone could think of some good ideas. Thanks.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to make a quiz containing 10 questions at random from a bank of 20 is not discoverable
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Tim, It seems the 'Add' functionality is quite well hidden, as it doesn't really appear in a position on the page where it's actually making sense. When reading LTR direction, one would expect to have the button / menu on the left or center bit of the page. All in all, if there are no questions associated with the quiz, the prompt to start adding or creating questions should be more visible. Maybe an overhaul of the add questions process is in place. Now, there's an Edit quiz button that only displays when there are no questions in the quiz. IMHO that's one click too many, to get to the question management bit of the quiz. Then, when arriving there, it's not clear where to click to start adding questions. Renaming the 'Edit quiz' button to 'Manage quiz questions' would make sense, as does adding a more user oriented and bigger 'Add question' button. I'm not a UX engineer, but I agree with you that working with quiz and question bank would benefit substantially from improvement.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to make a quiz containing 10 questions at random from a bank of 20 is not discoverable
ResponsesInList.Text: From my experience many users fail to grasp the fundamental difference between the set of questions in a single quiz and the underlying structure of the question bank that entails every question ever created in or imported to a course. So I don't think it's primarily a usability issue on the level of "make the add-question-button bigger" but instead a bigger usability challenge of the whole quiz creation workflow. Isn't it the same lack of understanding that also results in issues of redundantly imported questions sets and resulting unwanted duplicates within the same course? I know, this doesn't make it any easier, but I think a usability discussion of how to make this kind of multi-stage quiz creation workflows (e.g. import/create questions, create quiz, select and shuffle automated questions, solve quiz, grade quiz, etc.) visible in a comprehensive overview within Moodle would be highly appreciated!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to make a quiz containing 10 questions at random from a bank of 20 is not discoverable
ResponsesInList.Text: My experience comes from working with the other three "big" LMSs (BCD.) Moodle is the only LMS that provides this centralized "quiz question database " perspective. So I think that Benjamin is thinking correctly, that perhaps to effectively use a " database " of questions one has to think a little differently. In the other LMSs, it is more common to create quiz questions from within a course. BB did (I am unsure about Ultra) provide "pools," but they were a bit awkwardly implemented. In none of these other LMSs could you change (improve) a question in a central location and have it immediately be correct in every course using it! So, not everyone understands this. Even my "Business Analytics" department chair doesn't understand that Moodle's question database is conceptually quite different than C's quiz engine. Tim, the problem that we might be facing is that Moodle allows questions to be created in either the database or at the quiz level. If one is doing this from a quiz, it is hard to think about how to add 20 questions to a quiz, and then have only 10 of them randomly show. In fact, I don't know how to do this, which is why I tell folks to add the 20 questions to the database first, and then in the quiz pick 10 of these randomly. This could be one source of confusion. Some instructors just want to quickly go into a quiz and do everything. Learning how to add questions to the question bank takes time. Additionally, question categories have to be properly used.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to make a quiz containing 10 questions at random from a bank of 20 is not discoverable
ResponsesInList.Text: In the past, Moodle was like what you suggested: if the quiz contained no questions, then the teacher was taken directly to the "Edit quiz" screen. This lead to a different usability problem. Teachers would complain "I can only add and remove questions from my quiz when I first create it. Once the questions have been added, there is no way to go back and change it. Therefore, I swtiched to the current UI, where you always start on the quiz view.php screen, and you have to click "Edit quiz" to add/remove questions. Juding from the questions people ask in the quiz forum, this seems to have worked, even though it is one more click once you know what you are doing. In terms of the particular issue I want to talk about here. Can I just make it clear that if you want to suggest something that has a chance of being implemented in the near future, it needs to be a small incremental change that just makes the current UI a bit better. If you want to think about radical overhauls, ... well, you can. But I don't know anyone with that much spare development resource at the moment. (But, it might make a good MUA project, I suppose.)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to make a quiz containing 10 questions at random from a bank of 20 is not discoverable
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, In our installations we always change the language to "Manage questions" instead of "Edit quiz" to make it clearer. We also find that sometime teachers struggle to add questions whether random or simply from the question bank. So, following Tim's advice of a small change suggestion, I'd say the "Add" menu would have to be on the left side of the screen and gain visual strength. The plain fact that is a simple text link justifies why so many users have difficulties IMHO . Thanks

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to make a quiz containing 10 questions at random from a bank of 20 is not discoverable
ResponsesInList.Text: Just to be clear, and helpful, the first screen that I see when I click on a newly created quiz is shown below. Hugo, I believe that what you are saying is that you change the "Edit quiz" button to "Manage questions." This is one screen where perhaps some simple changes can be made. The message "No questions have been added yet" is correct. However, clicking on "Edit quiz" does more. It not only allows one to edit or manage questions, it also allows one to set up "overall quiz points," it provides a way to page-break questions with headings, change points for each question, and shuffle questions. So, maybe "Edit quiz" is better than "Manage questions."  I kind of like "Edit quiz," and like that this exact same wording is what appears on the "gear" icon dropdown. Maybe a better button wording should be "Edit quiz and manage questions." But this becomes a long button. Instead of the current wording "No questions have been added yet," maybe this can be improved.  For example: "By clicking on the Edit quiz button below, you will be able to manage questions (create new, add from the question bank, pick questions randomly from the question bank, remove, and order), change their points, shuffle questions, and add pagination and section headings.  For more information, see the " Moodle Docs for this page.  Although you can create new questions in Edit quiz mode, a better-recommended approach is to first add questions in the question bank, which provides better question organization, and then add them to your quiz. When on the "Edit Quiz" page, use the "gear" icon to quickly get to the question bank. " There seems to be space for a long paragraph like this one, and in my Boost theme, it shows in a "red" box. Well, you get the idea.  This paragraph needs some wordsmithing.  Sometimes people don't see the "Moodle Docs for this page" link at the bottom, so maybe having redundant links to the Moodle Docs in the above paragraph would be helpful.  Also, a link to some videos, in this paragraph, could be helpful since creating quizzes is a bit technical. For reference, I will include a screenshot of this quiz containing a few questions.  One point of confusion could be that "Total of points" shows 2.00, yet Maximum grade shows 10.  I don't know if this is a source of confusion.  I think what this is really showing that the questions, as created, were established to be 1 point each.  There are two questions, each worth 1 point, which totals to 2 points.  However, this "2 points" will be converted to a scale of 0 to 10 for this grade book item."  In other words "Maximum grade" really means "Maximum grade book item grade."

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to make a quiz containing 10 questions at random from a bank of 20 is not discoverable
ResponsesInList.Text: " However, clicking on "Edit quiz" does more." True. In the sake of simplicity we've changed our translation. Teachers were confused between "Edit settings" and "Edit quiz". While not 100% true we've found that this works best in Portuguese.

ResponsesInList.Title: Calendar issue: global event, turned into course event reappears as global.
ResponsesInList.Text: See if I can explain myself properly: A teacher created a recursive event that propagated on many consecutive days in our calendar. He created it as a site (or global) event. Later on, we decided it was better for it to be designated as "course" event, so we changed the type of event to course and for a while it worked. But a few hours (perhaps a day) the event had returned, actually added as another event altogether, and now we have two repeated events, one as global and one as course specific. Any ideas on why this would be happening and how to stop it? Even if it has some development implications, I would be interesting to follow the lead. Thanks!

ResponsesInList.Title: [3.8] - End of schoolyear, saving results and having new students
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, The school year ends in June.  In Moodle, I have a class '3 AVV A' that has lessons and tests. Next year I will have new students in this class. How do I save the results of my current students so I can review them again in for example 2 years? I want to be able to view their answers and their grades during the time they were in this class. Thank you for your help. Best regards, Thomas

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: [3.8] - End of schoolyear, saving results and having new students
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Thomas, One way is to basically create a new course for the new students and import the course files and activities through the Import function you'll find in the course management menu. Import course doesn't transfer student data, so all you copy is just the set up activities and the course layout. From 3.9 onwards (May 2020), the intention is to have a separate 'copy course' functionality. When you copy a course through the import functionality, you can set an end date or completion date on the old course, have it accessible for reference only. If you'd like to 'freeze' the course, you can use the experimental feature 'freeze context ', found in Site admin > Development.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: [3.8] - End of schoolyear, saving results and having new students
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you for your answer Joost, Looking forward to 3.9.

ResponsesInList.Title: How to change the required icon in sign up page
ResponsesInList.Text: I want to change the required icon (caution) to (*) or add text (required).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to change the required icon in sign up page
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes, this is rather confusing -- when you hover over it, it displays a help cursor, but nothing happens when you click on it. It's not until the very bottom of the page that you finally see the message "There are required fields in this form marked (!)." I don't know the best way to handle this, but with some CSS you can swap the icon out for the asterisk: /* Swap Required Alert Icon with Asterisk */ .fa-exclamation-circle:before {content: " * "; font-weight: bold;} Disclaimer: You have to know what the class is called for your theme, and you have to know what other parts of the site use that class so you don't unintentionally change this icon in other places where it may be useful to leave as is.

ResponsesInList.Title: Queries to retrieve Statistics
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Moodlers, I would like to find a way to retrieve the below statistics (knowing that I have consult the ad-hoc webpage and i didn't find anything related to what I need) 1. A query that will retrieve the total number of created activities (per course and per activity) during a certain period in the past (for example between January and February 2018) the exact state of Moodle at that time. 2. A query that will retrieve the total number of resources (per course) during a certain period in the past (for example between January and February 2018) the exact state of Moodle at that time. I managed to execute this query but for the current stat of Moodle, which means for example in query 1, if I run the query right now to retrieve the data between January and February 2018 it will be different if I run the same query but at that time, because a lot of activities will be deleted Below are the queries Thank you ===================================================================== Query 1: total number of activities per course per activity (SELECT c.fullname AS "Course fullname", c.idnumber AS "Course idnumber", (SELECT TABLE_NAME FROM INFORMATION_SCHEMA.TABLES WHERE TABLE_NAME like '____forum') AS ThisType, to_timestamp(act.timemodified) as DateModified, act.name AS Title FROM prefix_forum AS act INNER JOIN prefix_course AS c ON act.course=c.id) UNION (SELECT c.fullname AS "Course fullname", c.idnumber AS "Course idnumber", (SELECT TABLE_NAME FROM INFORMATION_SCHEMA.TABLES WHERE TABLE_NAME like '____assignment') AS ThisType, to_timestamp(act.timemodified) as DateModified, act.name AS Title FROM prefix_assign AS act INNER JOIN prefix_course AS c ON act.course=c.id) UNION Query 2: total number of resources per course SELECT f.contextid, c.idnumber AS "Course idnumber", c.fullname AS "Course fullname", f.filesize/1024 AS "filesize in KB", f.filename AS "filename", f.mimetype AS "filetype", to_timestamp(f.timecreated) AS "timecreated", to_timestamp(f.timemodified) AS "timemodified" FROM prefix_files f INNER JOIN prefix_context ctx ON f.contextid=ctx.id INNER JOIN prefix_course_modules cm ON ctx.instanceid=cm.id INNER JOIN prefix_course c ON cm.course=c.id WHERE (f.component='mod_folder' OR f.component='mod_resource') AND f.filesize>0

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Queries to retrieve Statistics
ResponsesInList.Text: This question is definitely not in the best forum, but still. I would not do Query 1 like that. I think the thing you should be using, but are not, is the prefix_course_modules table (joined to the prefix_module table).

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle 3.8+ Question Bank -> Questions -> Preview button move to Edit actions submenu
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, on Moodle 3.8+ Question Bank -> Questions, to preview a question one needs to click Edit -> Preview under Actions column but before 3.8+ the preview button was placed next to the question itself so there was no need to click Edit button. Also the previewed question is not opened on a new popup window. This new one is very annoying cause reviewing lots of questions requires to loose a lot of time. Is there any setting to go back to the previous scenario? Thanks in advanced.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle 3.8+ Question Bank -> Questions -> Preview button move to Edit actions submenu
ResponsesInList.Text: What you are seeing is the progressive change to a consistent user interface, which has been happening for a while.  I think that I made a feature request when the grade book made this change.  Actually, I think Tim Hunt made a post not to long ago letting us know about this question bank change. Anyway, you can make a feature request in Moodle Tracker to go back to the old method (but I don't think it will do any good.)  I am not part of Moodle HQ, I am just another user giving you some thoughts. As a suggestion about how to preview a bunch of questions, consider creating a quiz and putting these questions into it.  Then, review the quiz.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle 3.8+ Question Bank -> Questions -> Preview button move to Edit actions submenu
ResponsesInList.Text: As Ruck says this was an intentional change, and I posted about it in the Quiz forum before making it, to see if there was a strong objection and there wasn't, although there was some debate about the extra click required. I have mixed feeling about this, and also the change which means that the preview now opens in a new tab rather than a pop-up window. The extra click is a down-side, but there there positives. One thing that used to be wrong with the old UI was that if you used the standard short-cut to open the preview in a new tab in the background (CTRL + click) then that did not work. Instead, the only option was to right-click and choose 'Open in new tab' - so that is two clicks per question. With the new UI, you can just keep CTRL held down, and choose preview from each menu - also two clicks per question, but less fiddly, because they are all clicks wiht the left mouse button. So, my own experience is that for "reviewing lots of questions" - which I do quite a lot when I have to find an example question that is suitable for testing the code I am working on, is that the new UI is slightly better. I also like the fact that the menu makes the UI less cryptic, and means that we can afford to add a few extra options there (like Export as XML ).

Kind regards,

ResponsesInList.Title: Group messaging: usability concerns and suggestions
ResponsesInList.Text: We are upgrading from 3.4 to 3.6, and at first glance we liked the group messaging functionality. But a fter testing it, we have discovered several issues. This is what we have found, please correct us if we have got it wrong: There is no default setting to allow group messaging on course (or system) level The course manager/teacher has to activate the ability for each group in the course. This has to be done for all groups in the course one-by-one. There is no way to change this setting in "bulk" after the groups are created It is not selectable for all groups when auto-creating groups Groups cannot be searched and added, the way single users can, in the contacts list. This might lead to: All groups that you are a member of and that have been set to allow group messaging are always visible in the IM, and this might become a very long list. When one of your groups are missing in the IM, because that group has not been allowed to group message, it will be confusing to the user. Users will try to search for the missing group (see 5 above) When a teacher needs to create additional groups, it's easy to forget to give those the group messaging ability. This will cause stress and confusion, when some students complain that they cannot find their group in the IM. Suggestions: A site-wide course default setting to set allow/disallow Group messaging when creating a course: Allow group messaging [Yes/No] A course default setting under the Course Settings: Allow group messaging [Yes/No] The setting for each group remains as it is, but is pre-set according to the choices in 1-2 above When bulk creating groups this should be an option, pre-set according to the choices in 1-2 above The setting should be indicated in the groups overview with a checkbox The setting should be able to be changed in bulk in the groups overview, by using the checkboxes and select all

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Group messaging: usability concerns and suggestions
ResponsesInList.Text: I think these are good suggestions Peter. We have Moodle 3.5 and I have turned messaging off because the controls arent tight enough. I'm hopeful that Moodle 3.6 would fix these issues, but maybe I might hold off upgrading until messaging is full fixed in the next version. (Sometimes, I wonder how much this forum is watched by Moodle UX people. I have submitted several emails now related to usability with no response.)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Group messaging: usability concerns and suggestions
ResponsesInList.Text: Good suggestions. One thing i like about group messaging is that the context of the course is provided in the message. I feel like there should be some way to represent a student sending a private message from a course, otherwise a teacher of a number of classes with many students may not know where (or even who) it's from. I suppose i could create one big group for everyone and set up messaging but then it would all be public - what i need is for that whole course group to be "private" between members and teacher role. We have a scenario where we have advisor roles covering many courses with hundreds of students, currently using dialogue, but really messenging should be able to do the job - had hoped it would with this update in 3.6 but it's not quite there yet.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Group messaging: usability concerns and suggestions
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Peter, thank you very much for these suggestions! I would like to let you know that I have proposed a MUA project which is targeted at improving the (group) messaging system for the current MUA project cycle. You can find it on https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-66562 and you're welcome to add any comments there. Thanks, Alex

It seems like this would have been discussed but a forum search here was not turning up relevant results for me. Anyhow, my institution has been using a custom course block plugin that just lists all of a users courses, separated by category. I really like the new course dashboard block in Moodle 3.6+ and want to transition away from the custom course block in the future. But, I have a couple of usability questions: 1) For "regular" users like students and teachers, it seems like a search filter in the block would be a no brainer addition. Yes, they can sort by future/current/past, and star or hide courses, which is great. I hid the block on my dashboard and find myself missing this functionality. The quickest way I've found is to go to Site Admin->Courses->Manage Courses and Categories, where there is Course Search field. I tried adding this page to my Admin Bookmarks but it doesn't seem to be possible. Surely there is a quicker, built-in way to get to course search? Or should I look for another plugin.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: "Import" doesn't create sections/topics
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Anna-Maria, I don't know if the Usability forum is the best place to ask this question. A moderator may wish to move it to the backup/restore or general forum. Regarding your question: when you import a course or restore a backup, it takes the settings from the source course. If a section is hidden in the source, it will be hidden in the target. ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle Content Creation Competitor
ResponsesInList.Text: I think it's important that Moodle is aware of different UX designs that suit secondary school teachers, so I thought I would drop a short note about a competitor in the Australian domestic market called StileApp. StileApp is a content creation/Quiz creation tool that can be used to host a class of students. It doesn't have the power of Moodle in many areas, but it does make content creation easy using a lot of on screen Ajax calls when editing. ResponsesInList.Title: Greyed-out features in a product
ResponsesInList.Text: I have recently been tasked to write/design requirements for a "lite" version of our flagship product, The "lite" version of the product would have certain product features greyed-out to the basic user, enticing them to sign up for the full membership.  I don't like the idea, was curious to hear from experts in the field on the matter.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Greyed-out features in a product
ResponsesInList.Text: Amy You are quite right not to like this idea. In particular, greyed-out items I have seen rarely pass the WCAG accessibility compliance for color contrast. They are almost always too light, since even #777 does not pass the minimum contrast required (example and nice discussion here: https://webaim.org/articles/contrast/ ). In general, the semantic use of color as the ONLY mechanism to convey information is a basic accessibility error to be avoided. Here's the official statement: "Color is not used as the only visual means of conveying information, indicating an action, prompting a response, or distinguishing a visual element." from the W3C document: https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG21/#use-of-color . You will notice that some places in Moodle that used to have only grey-out colors to indicate hidden or other items (eg the dimmed style class), have been updated in recent versions so that they have additional text indicators to show status in addition to color; for instance, course activity items that are hidden or stealth hidden from students now do this, which is an important improvement and good practice to model. Randy

ResponsesInList.Title: Fordson course management panel
ResponsesInList.Text: Does anybody know how I can remove items from the course management panel in the Fordson theme? I have items on the list that refuse access to certain users, so I would like to remove them so the user doesn't know they are there. Regards Keith

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Fordson course management panel
Re: Fordson course management panel
ResponsesInList.Text: Is it just specific items or entire categories? Individual items will be much harder to do.  I suppose we might be able to build in a check but that would be a very customized setup. The entire menu for the teacher dashboard is built with this function: https://github.com/dbnschools/moodle-theme_fordson/blob/master/classes/output/core_renderer.php#L1077-L1297 You might be able to build in checks or permissions that if the user does not have them then the item disappears.  It's a bit of work do. I don't know if each item on the page has an associated permission .  This would also require you to create new system roles for the teachers or people you don't want to see certain items because you have to actually remove that permission for the role.  This could mean you have teacher A and teacher B roles. I can't promise anything but I might take a look to see if I can build in permission checks for the menu items.  I bet others would like this too. Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Fordson course management panel
ResponsesInList.Text: Using this line as an example: https://github.com/dbnschools/moodle-theme_fordson/blob/master/classes/output/core_renderer.php#L1138 I am thinking you could target a role permission such as: $gradestitle = (!has_capability(' enrol/category:config ', $ context )) ? false : get_string('gradebooksetup', 'grades'); You would change the bold capability to whatever the permission is that is associated with the menu item.  That way if the user had a role that didn't have that permission it wouldn't show up.  I'm just throwing out ideas.  I am sure there might be a better way to code it. If you put a user into a role that didn't have this permission set then they would not see the gradebook item. Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: What is the best way to suggest usability improvement to Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I was just wondering, what is the best way to discuss usability problems or suggest usability improvements to Moodle. I'm looking through the discussions here, and lot of people have great suggestions but get no response to their messages. Are they being read? Is Moodle Tracker a better way of suggesting improvements? Or is joining MUA a better way... Sorry, I'm not pointing fingers, I'm just curious... kind regards, Brad

ResponsesInList.Title: Re:
ResponsesInList.Text: I think it depends: If you spot something that is clearly bad, or if you have a specific, implementable suggestion for making something better, then it belongs in the tracker. If it is more ambiguous: something in this area but it is not clear exactly what, or something about X needs to be improved, but it is not entirely clear how, the it is probably best to find a forum to discuss it. That could be here, or MUA , or .... Once there starts to be some consensus on the specifics, then put it in the tracker.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re:
ResponsesInList.Text: On the docs ( https://docs.moodle.org/dev/Accessibility ) it points to a Accessibility Working Group: "To improve the accessibility and usability of Moodle, we have established this collaboration group to work together with Moodle developers, accessibility experts, administrators, IT professionals, and other interested entities and individuals. We welcome anyone who is interested in improving the accessibility of Moodle to join this group. You don’t need to be a technical guru or accessibility expert to join; however, it is expected that you are familiar with the basics of accessibility and are willing to dedicate a few hours each month to this collaboration effort. This group meets once a month to discuss accessibility priorities, typically on the first Monday of each month. Visit http://collaborate.athenpro.org/group/moodle to join the email list. To review past meetings or to see upcoming meetings visit http://collaborate.athenpro.org/group/moodle/teleconferences/ " But I'm not sure if it is still ongoing ...

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: What is the best way to suggest usability improvement to Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: In my own observations, many topics that are posted get read, but it seems to me that the major cause of not getting a reply is that the question or suggestion is confusing or too obscure. Many volunteers participate in Moodle.org (like myself) and if I see a post that is a bit off-base, sometimes I will ignore it because I don't have the time to help the poster be more specific. I only have so much time in a day. In your case with this post of yours, you can see that both Tim and Daniel have provided responses. Having said this, there are many "feature requests" in Moodle Tracker that are great ideas, but might take time to implement. In my own case, I have probably posted several dozen feature requests (let's say 36) and probably 12 have been implemented. My last feature request to get implemented took 8 years, but it then happened in Moodle 3.7. Moodle's track record, for me, has been significantly better than the other LMSs (BB, D2L, C) that I have used. Piggybacking on what Tim said, I would agree, I sometimes start here in Moodle.org with a post, kind of like fishing and testing the waters, then I will post in Tracker. If something looks like a bug, I post in Tracker and follow-up here in these forums. In Tracker, if something about my idea is out of place, Tracker has the ability to "close" an item. I believe that posts here in these forums last a very long time.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: What is the best way to suggest usability improvement to Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you everyone for your replies. I want to get more involved in supporting usability improvements to Moodle so there is a lot of food for thought there..

ResponsesInList.Title: Dragging Files Resources into a Folder Resource
ResponsesInList.Text: I saw this was a previous forum topic and I think it still applies today as it did then. I strongly believe users should be able to drag File Resources into Folders, and in fact many teachers at my school have complained that they cant. It's not enough, to simply look for a Course Format like Flexible Sections or Sub courses to be able to help avoid the Scroll of Death, or to rely on the File Picker to move files into folders. It should be core functionality. cheers, Brad

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Dragging Files Resources into a Folder Resource
ResponsesInList.Text: This would be super useful. Creating a folder by dragging a file over another file would be great too.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Dragging Files Resources into a Folder Resource
ResponsesInList.Text: I do like the idea of dragging a file over another file to create a folder, but I could see some issues when it comes to moving files around the screen. You could accidentally drop it on another file by mistake.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Dragging Files Resources into a Folder Resource
ResponsesInList.Text: I was thinking actually, that the flexible sections format and folder functionality really should be combined. A folder really should just be a collection of activities and resources, that users can simply drag items into so to group things. I know the Topics tabs are there for that reason, but I feel a user should not be so constrained - they should be able to group things into different hierarchical levels if that is their desire. And folders/sections should be able to sit anywhere on any page. The process should be: Create a folder (a flexible section closed) Drag labels, resources and activities into the folder Go into the folder, and repeat the last two steps if necessary.. This will put an end to the scroll of death. In many ways the flexible sections format simply needs to be upgraded to look like a folder, with better drag and drop enabled especially if the section/folder is closed. just some thoughts..

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Dragging Files Resources into a Folder Resource
ResponsesInList.Text: Yeah, well said - I would think a visual helper or delay would help prevent accidentally dropping something in (a little like the Mac finder's pop up folders)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Dragging Files Resources into a Folder Resource
ResponsesInList.Text: Ive been giving this some more thought, the number of teachers who have come up to me to ask how to group their resources is quite astounding. We have over 200 teachers and I think about 20 of them have asked about it. Particularly teachers who have placed a large number of links on their page. They dont want to create a new Section, they simply want to be able to group their resources in something similar to a Folder . And they dont like the look of the Flexible Sections format at present - it also isn't compatible with Sharing Cart. If Moodle doesnt want to change the Folder resource - as in keep it only for Files that's okay. But perhaps creating a Collection resource which can be used to contain any group of Resources or Activities. I think it would be a very simple addition to core functionality. The Collection could either open on the page dynamically or go to its own page. If users could drag their Resources and Activities into the Collection, that would great. It could also be a very easy way to move multiple resources around the page. When I have time, I might create a Moodle Tracker for this.

ResponsesInList.Title: Improve checkmarks for tasks
ResponsesInList.Text: Currently, checkmarks are on the right side: While it's best practice and expected to be on the left side to assist the usage of the mental model of a todo list. Usually, the list elements also get highlighted resp. separated by either a line or by itemizing them: More examples following this schema can be found in an image search for "todo list". The right side should be reserved for support functions (like the favorite/bookmark function). Things to improve: put checkmarks to the left itemize/separate todo items

ResponsesInList.Title: Outcomes Missing from Instructor's Grader Report View
ResponsesInList.Text: We are having a unique issue with an instructor who cannot see outcomes in their gradebook's grader report, but can see them in single view and in their gradebook setup. This issue seems to be tied to the user, because if we add them to another instructor's class that has outcomes attached, they cannot see outcomes in those grader reports either, even though the other instructor can. As far as we can tell, it is only impacting one instructor at our institution. Has anyone else seen anything like this? Any thoughts on how to correct this bug, other than nuking the user and giving them a new profile?

ResponsesInList.Title: Nav Bar Alterations
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, I'm getting bombarded from users who are complaining that they don't like the 'More...' nav bar button for courses. They don't understand that it simply navigates you to your dashboard and doesn't do anything if you're already there. These same users complain that they want to see more than 6 courses listed in the course overview at a time. We've swapped from Boost to Klass (a Boost based theme), but I would like to make it so that they can have as long a list of courses as they like and take away the 'My Courses' and 'More...' buttons from the Nav Bar. Is this possible? And if so, where would I find it?

ResponsesInList.Title: Repository Documentation
ResponsesInList.Text: Greetings developers, Your software has been both a blessing and an absolute nightmare. First of all, as my two cents, advertising 3.6 as a stable edition is incorrect as it is lacking even the most basic site administration features. Regardless, I wish to access files that are within the server storage without having to upload them especially considering the upload limit. Every other edition has ways to do this, however, within the documentation there is no mention of the "create repository instance function", only what the final product would look like. While I am here, I would also like to ask for native microphone support for quizzes along with an ability to allow guests to at least preview quizzes to get a taste of what our setup has to offer, Thank you, Anhad

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Repository Documentation
ResponsesInList.Text: I’ve just checked the date and it’s past noon on 1st April so I assume you’re being serious. So... Which site administration features is Moodle lacking? The server files repository is well documented at https://docs.moodle.org/36/en/Server_files_repository . In addition there are many other repository options in core and number of additional repository plugins. Guest access to quizzes is documented here: https://docs.moodle.org/36/en/Quiz_FAQ#Why_can.27t_people_.28guests.29_attempt_a_quiz_without_creating_an_account_and_logging_in.3F From Moodle 3.5 onwards, you can record video and audio directly within the editing interface, and there are also a range of plugins that allow this.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Repository Documentation
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, Thank you for the quick response. I had a look at that page and could find nothing on how the folders are to be linked or associated with the server directory. I am running moodle on Ubuntu 16.04 and did indeed try to create a folder called "repository" within the moodledata folder along with giving it ample permissions. However, when I try to add an audio file to a question from "server files", all I can see is the folder "System". To reiterate, I wish to add files from the server command line to be able to interface with in the moodle software. As for the audio, my apologies, I meant to specify for the students to be able to record audio when answering a quiz. Thank you for your response, Anhad

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Repository Documentation
ResponsesInList.Text: So, as I said, the text editor in Moodle has allowed students to record audio directly via the browser since v3.5. In addition, plugins such as Poodll allow this too. Poodll offers more flexibility in my opinion: see https://poodll.com/audio-assessments/ and https://poodll.com/poodll-recorders-vs-moodle-recorders/ For the respository, if you’ve set up the file system repo properly, it should show as a separate instance in the repo list; you wouldn’t access it via server files. See the image in this section of the docs , which shows the file system repo in the section called, in that example, Faculty (File system) . D o you mean you wish to be able to search for and upload/link files already on your server? The file system repo allows you to put files into that directory and be visible to all users who have permission in Moodle - kind of like a virtual drive . I suspect you’re maybe wanting something a bit different, possibly akin to the Dropbox or Google drive functionality. There is a WebDAV repo, which may work for you. See https://docs.moodle.org/36/en/Repositories

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Repository Documentation
ResponsesInList.Text: "First of all, as my two cents, advertising 3.6 as a stable edition is incorrect as it is lacking even the most basic site administration features." So please enlighten us; what is it missing?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Repository Documentation
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you for your response, Sorry for coming back to you so late, That link helped a lot, maybe it was just me but even after hours of searching, I had not managed to encounter that page. Maybe making documentation more segregated for each version could help more. As for the recording, it is available in the Assignments section but not in the quiz, and I'm probably asking for a lot but that is where I would like to add them. Thank you for your assistance

ResponsesInList.Title: Help Desk activity?
ResponsesInList.Text: Using Moodle v3.6.3 as the training environment for our workplace. I'd like to provide a way for users who notice a problem (like outdated or incorrect content), or have a suggestion to give their feedback. There are several ways I know of to do this in a basic way (questionnaire, feedback, database ), but I'd really like to combine this with some back-end functionality like prioritizing and tracking the status (open/in progress/review pending/etc.) Any ideas? Thanks in advance!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Help Desk activity?
ResponsesInList.Text:
There was a plugin for a help desk - https://moodle.org/plugins/block_helpdesk - but it’s not been updated since Moodle version 2.5 and almost certainly won’t work with v3.6 but it might
give you an idea of what’s possible. Or use a completely separate system (eg. osTicket or OpenSupports ) and embed a reporting form on your Moodle site.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Help Desk activity?
ResponsesInList.Text: In my university courses, with students, I provide one bonus point whenever a student is the first one to report any administrative problem to me.  They can email me, or they can post to any of the general "I need help with this topic" forums.  It doesn't matter to me how they do it. This system seems to work.  Some students will pay very close attention to everything that I make available to them, looking for an error.  Bonus points add up, and they can accumulate to be worth around 2% of their overall grade, sometimes enough to pop them into the next grade category. In your case, whatever you do, think about some incentive that you might provide for your users to be rewarded for reporting problems.  Make it easy (like my email approach).  I don't prioritize, I just fix problems immediately so that no other student will see them. Oh, I will add the fancy words... This is my way of implementing "continuous improvement."

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Help Desk activity?
ResponsesInList.Text: There is a user support tracker plugin for Moodle available at https://moodle.org/plugins/mod_tracker However, if you click on the link for versions, you see it is listed as being for Moodle 3.0 and lower. Another HOWEVER, if you go to the source code at github, https://github.com/vfremaux/moodle-mod_tracker you will see that if you click the drop down for the branch list, there are the versions you need for all the latest  versions of Moodle. You just need to be aware that you will also need to down load and install a corresponding version of vflibs from https://github.com/vfremaux/moodle-local_vflibs ...back-end functionality like prioritizing and tracking the status (open/in progress/review pending/etc.) It is all available in this plugin. Been using it since Moodle 1.9 days. Works great!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Help Desk activity?
ResponsesInList.Text: Excellent! Thanks so much, Al - I saw that it was showing as outdated, but didn't look at github.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Help Desk activity?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Frank, Hope it works as well for you like it does for me. I only found the github branches due to trying to set up Ansible to automatically update my Moodle and plugins and stumbled upon them.

ResponsesInList.Title: Adding new topics to TOP of course
ResponsesInList.Text: They say laziness is the mother of invention, right? I have several courses going where I periodically add new content. The new stuff should be at the top, and the older stuff should fall to the bottom. Whenever I add a new Topic, it goes to the bottom of the list, and it's taking longer & longer to drag it to the top. Is there any way to force new Topics to be inserted at the Top of my course? Moodle 3.6.3 Thanks!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding new topics to TOP of course
ResponsesInList.Text: If you momentarily click on the drag and drop icon, it will show you a list of topics and you can then select the top one. If you are using the Collapsed Topics course format, you can click Close All and then drag Sections into a new order. There’s also the Weekly format reversed course format, but unfortunately not reversed topics.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding new topics to TOP of course
ResponsesInList.Text: I like the Collapsed Topics approach.  It's really fast!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding new topics to TOP of course
ResponsesInList.Text: See? This is how I learned not to be embarrassed asking 'dumb' questions! Clicking on the drag & drop icon! Good grief! Thanks very much gents, this is exactly what I needed.

ResponsesInList.Title: Difficulty Hearing Students' Audio Submissions
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm using Moodle 3.6.3 (Build: 20190311) I have given my students a couple assignments requiring them to submit an audio answer.  If they record their voices using an outside program and upload the file, I can hear it.  However, some students have trouble with technology and would rather use the record option within the assignment like by using the microphone button above in this post.  We did a test of it.  Their voices appear to have recorded, and I can push the triangle play button and see the bar for sound moving forward as normal with an audio recording when I try to grade the assignment.  However, I cannot actually hear any audio.  I have double checked my the volume in the app and my computer and can hear other files, but cannot hear these recordings.  If I open the grading and try to listen on my iphone, I receive a black box with an X and a message saying "No compatible source was found for this media." Any suggestions on how to listen to recordings made directly in the assignment would be much appreciated!

ResponsesInList.Title: Add guest access courses to starred courses block
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm testing out moodle 3.6.1 with a boost based child theme and I'm trying to get most out of the new features such as the course overview block, starred courses and nav-drawer mycourses menu. We have lots of information only courses/pages open to all users on our system. If we enrol all users onto these courses then they appear in the course overview block and they can then 'star' or remove from the course overview, but then the mycourses list in the drawer is very long, too long (20-30). So we thought we would just open the information courses as guest access to everyone. But then users can't 'star' these courses. Or am I missing something? Basically I want the mycourses in the nav-drawer to have their enrolled on core courses (about 5) and then users can favourite guest access information pages. The course overview block the user can edit themselves so it's as much of a problem. Has anyone found a good way to use all these things together without long lists in anyone place? thanks, Simon

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Add guest access courses to starred courses block
ResponsesInList.Text: For info: I found a way round it in the end. I copied the functionality to star courses from myoverview and starred courses block on the front page , and then added it to the page header in my theme. Took a lot of faffing with amd but it works.

ResponsesInList.Title: Customize mail notification template
ResponsesInList.Text: Notification mails for new messages and new forum activities contain a footer message like "This mail is a copy of an message you sent…" But most of our students (and teachers) ignore this and reply by mail anyway, so their reply doesn't reach its destination. How can I change the email templates so these messages appear at the top of the email instead of the bottom in order to give it more attention??

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Customize mail notification template
ResponsesInList.Text: You’ll need to edit mod/forum/templates/forum_post_email_htmlemail.mustache and possibly others in that directory  depending on whether you have users receiving daily digests or plain text emails. or you could allow replies by email 😉

ResponsesInList.Title: Capabilities required for 'Browse list of users'
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Moodle community, I would like to be able to provide other staff in our organisation with the ability to use the 'Browse list of users' option. However I was surprised to discover that apparently requires both the moodle/user:update and moodle/user:delete capabilities. I'd like to suggest that changing this be considered. Surely a case could be made for the ability just to view, without the need to update let alone delete. So I'd be interested to find how many other people find this arrangement unusual. There's an existing Issue for this in the tracker and an expired forum post. I'm not sure why it hasn't received more comments and votes. Forum post: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=225369 Tracker Item: https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-39627 Thanks.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Capabilities required for 'Browse list of users'
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi Andrew, In what context should these colleagues be able to see these users? In any Moodle, for those users who can see participants at site level, there's the ..user/index.php?id=1 page to consult with the full list of users, but without the delete and edit tools. The permission for this would be: 
```text
moodle/site:viewparticipants
```

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Capabilities required for 'Browse list of users'
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Joost, Thanks for the message. Cheers.

ResponsesInList.Title: Tag search results

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Tag search results
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ritchie, this was an interesting query, and yes you're correct, it's currently hard-coded to 5 in the php code. Generally, it's really not a good idea to alter the core moodle php code, but if this is important, the place to edit it is here: filename course/lib.php Line 3736 (This could well be different, based on moodle version, this is from 3.5.4+ (Build: 20190301)) function course_get_tagged_courses variable $perpage This example snippet is my git diff showing that I've altered the original value from 5 to 4, for testing... I wasn't able to find a relevant tracker ticket about making this specific page limit configurable, which would be the more ideal solution to be developed long-term.

ResponsesInList.Title: Why, oh why My Courses
ResponsesInList.Text: Just upgraded our QA environment from 3.4+ to 3.6, to prepare for our production upgrade in August. The last years we have been using the Essentials theme, a decision mostly based on not being satisfied with the moodle native theme's navigation. Now we want to look into Boost again, since it would be easier with a native theme and one that moodle.org is investing it's creativity in. This version has a lot of great improvements in the dashboard , which has become very configurable and easy to use! Very nice! But then comes My Courses in the navigation menu, and that hasn't changed at all. It can, as far as I can find in the settings, still not be inactivated/hidden or set as folded as default. It shows a list of courses based on mostly irrelevant information, sorted in strange orders. Maybe it should show "starred" courses, or courses with relevant date information (active courses)? We will try to close it with CSS , or completely hide it since it will be mostly irrelevant to people with many courses. Or have I missed something, is there a setting to do this? Suggested additional settings for My Courses: Show My Courses in navigation menu (default admin setting, could also be options for the user) - Not at all - Folded - Unfolded Content of My Courses in navigation menu (default admin setting, could also be options for the user) - All - Active courses (based on course start/end date) - Starred - Starred and active - Starred or active Sort order of My Courses in navigation menu (default admin setting, could also be options for the user) - Start date ascending - Start date descending - End date ascending - End date descending (Plus the old alternatives, but with ascending/descending option added)

ResponsesInList.Title: Parents viewing a Child's course and Assignment Dates
ResponsesInList.Text: Most schools would want their Parents to know the due dates of their children's assignment and yet this functionality seems missing from Moodle. I've been thinking about this problem, and the easiest solution would be to create a course Enrolment Method called Mentees. If enabled on a Course, then for each student, their mentee is automatically enrolled as an Observer Role with minimal permissions and are placed in a Course Group called Mentees. This would also give the ability to provide course specific activities to parents, such as a Parental Consent Form (which would just be a Feedback Form restricted to parents). Or to email a group of parents. It also allows the Teacher or Manager to decided if they want parents to be able to access their site or not. cheers, Brad

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Parents viewing a Child's course and Assignment Dates
ResponsesInList.Text: I really thought I would get some feedback to this issue. How does one get this issue on the Moodle Roadmap ?? The parent functionality is Moodle is very poor at the moment. It seems like a no brainer to allow Parents/Mentees to be able to view a Student's upcoming events. Or to be able to provide consent to Course Events such as Excursions. This would simply be the Policy functionality extended to a Course level. If Parents could be enrolled as an Observer group, then it allows teachers to easily email parents when they wish.

ResponsesInList.Title: Is noodle accessible with voiceover?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is noodle accessible with voiceover?
ResponsesInList.Text: Generally yes, Moodle will work with screen-readers.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is noodle accessible with voiceover?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is noodle accessible with voiceover?
ResponsesInList.Text: Formal information about Moodle's Accessibility is available in the wiki here: https://docs.moodle.org/en/Accessibility The main "gotcha" is that although Moodle is accessible, the content that teachers add to a site may not always be accessible - few pointers here: https://docs.moodle.org/en/Accessible_course_design

ResponsesInList.Title: RopeTeam Course Format?
ResponsesInList.Text: I am not sure how many of us report bugs via the tracker, but doing so might have some unexpected benefits.  I happen to stumble across this this morning and was greatly encouraged about where Moodle is going: https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-58419 https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1BVdLjIQ7qf4o6B5A10fJhOvjmSg_ESStKiju5j4ng_4/edit#slide=id.p This is the sort of out of the box, innovative thinking Moodle needs.  Course format in particular, in Moodle, has a very dated look and often has too much going on, distracting the learner from the learning task.  It is a classic case of software getting in the way. The rope team course format addresses this problem for both learner and course facilitator/writer. I hope this one makes it into production soon!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Bulk uploading files to course
ResponsesInList.Text: Might you consider not moving videos into Moodle and instead of putting them elsewhere, like on Youtube, Vimeo, etc.?  Big videos in Moodle causes big backups of Moodle.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Bulk uploading files to course
ResponsesInList.Text: I completely agree with Rick that you should consider alternative places to host your videos. However, if you do want to bulk upload then have you tried dragging and dropping? You can select several videos and drag them into your course page. Alternatively you can put them in a folder, zip the folder and drag and drop or conventionally upload the folder and then unzip it. However this also depends on the file size of your videos which is another reason to think about hosting them somewhere other than Moodle.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Bulk uploading files to course

In this case they are being accessed under licence, so Moodle is acting as a hosting platform.
