Each video has a specific title and the video transcript has to go in the description. Also, I have to answer whether the video should be presented on the page, or as a link, for every video. I've also noticed that the order they appear on the page is not necessarily the same as the order they appear in my File Explorer list. So, yes, it is a little quicker, but working procedurally through the course step by step still seems to be the most sensible way forward at the moment. When I downloaded the videos in Python I also copied the title, description and filename into an Excel spreadsheet. What I was aiming for was to bulk upload using the Excel sheet. Do you happen to know if such a plugin has been created?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Bulk uploading files to course

ResponsesInList.Title: What is the best way to provide videos to students in moodle embedded or streamed by an external server
ResponsesInList.Text:
What
is the best way to provide videos to students in moodle embedded or streamed by
an external server ,  taking into account
bandwidth and server load.  Does embedding
slow the whole server down depending on load?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: What is the best way to provide videos to students in moodle embedded or streamed by an external server
ResponsesInList.Text: For performance reasons we try to off load all media to another server and try to stream it. If you serve videos from your main Moodle server you can run into load issues in which the web server tried to serve the entire file that can be gigabytes large. And it takes up an https connection. With a streaming server only the part of the video that the user is watching is send and the user can also skip around the video without having to wait for the whole thing to download . Much better user experience.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: What is the best way to provide videos to students in moodle embedded or streamed by an external server
ResponsesInList.Text: thank you REX for you reply.  We have had been using RED5 as a server but with Flash being discontinued by browsers this next year??? what is a good alternative source for mostly mp4 files

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: What is the best way to provide videos to students in moodle embedded or streamed by an external server
ResponsesInList.Text: We use a mix of a self hosted Wowza server and paid solution Kaltura service.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: What is the best way to provide videos to students in moodle embedded or streamed by an external server
ResponsesInList.Text: Mr. Marc, which is the best car to buy? Yes, you will get many opinions. All of my videos are on a university "streaming server," and I am fortunate to have this for my course videos for free.  Then, I simply provide a URL to the video wherever I need to. I have been finding that the word "stream" might have some different meanings.  In the old days, one had a choice to either "download" or "stream" videos.  Streaming meant that software would download a little, then play, then download a little more in the background, then play.  Today, with faster servers and Internet speeds, I never know if my videos are being streamed or not.  Somehow, browsers seem to just figure these things out.  This is a rather long paragraph that I have to end with "I don't know." What I do know is that if you upload videos into your Moodle, backups will grow in size.  I am one who prefers to separate videos, and other content, from my Moodle, especially for this "backup growth" issue. A while ago, I did experiment with Kaltura.  I actually liked it.  However, I learned that it got to be very expensive very quickly, so I aborted.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: What is the best way to provide videos to students in moodle embedded or streamed by an external server
ResponsesInList.Text: Rick thank you for your reply is there any low cost or no cost solutions you can recommend for compatible browsers and mobile devices that will work with moodle?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: What is the best way to provide videos to students in moodle embedded or streamed by an external server
ResponsesInList.Text: All methods have their advantages and disadvantages. For a low-cost solution, use YouTube.  I don't like this approach because it can't bundle YouTube videos into a podcast.  Also, I haven't figured out how to get rid of the ads. Vimeo seemed attractive to me. I tried the "free" version.  The free version does not provide a direct video URL.  But Vimeo says that if one buys the upgraded product that you do get a URL.  I didn't want to spend the $30 (US) or so monthly fee to test this. Maybe others here can provide low-cost solutions.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: What is the best way to provide videos to students in moodle embedded or streamed by an external server
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you, Rick,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: What is the best way to provide videos to students in moodle embedded or streamed by an external server
ResponsesInList.Text: As mentioned before tere is not the one answer.  Here my criteria: Size of videos: If most of the videos are small it doesn't make a difference. Number of videos visited at the same time: If it may be possible there are lots of videos visited at the same time you need a lot of power Number of videos on the same page. Same as above Do you need different sizes and resolutions for different devices? Are the videos confidential? How many people are administrating videos? (upload process, access) Do you need backup and restore processes for dfferent platforms Do you have technical und human ressources for internal hosting. A streaming server needs different competencies than a Moodle server What is your budget? Additional services needs additonal budgets. Sometimes it makes sense to mix it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: What is the best way to provide videos to students in moodle embedded or streamed by an external server
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, Mr. Marc, We use the Kaltura Community Editon (self hosted, and free version) for our university. Moodle plugins provided by the Kaltura Inc. can not be used with the Community Edition. Regards

ResponsesInList.Title: Proper names capitalisation in Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: If I search for e.g. for "results block" I find "Add a new activity results block" & "The Activity results block only shows data stored in other locations." The same happens for many other names ( activities , blocks, etc). I don't think both are correct. Reading the entry for "Proper noun" in Wikipedia I have understood that proper nouns are distinguished from common nouns using a capitalised first letter. In the case of  single-word names, this is quite easy and most english people agree and more or less use the rule. For multiword proper names though, there are some doubts (only first letter of first word or first letters of all words). The problem starts when people that give a name, use it for so long that they come to think it is now part of the language i.e. common. But for a newcomer these words look strange or jargon. To be fair we need to be objective and have in mind as many users as possible. Power or long time users would have no problem either way. Most users would sooner or later discover the rule if it is applied uniformly. New users would very easily be instructed that names of things in Moodle have a first letter (or first letter of every word) capitalised. And that would help them a lot. My point of view is that of a translator so I can assert that it would be a tremendous help in many doubious strings in every language. p.s. I am not sure if I explained everything right. Sorry for any mistakes!

ResponsesInList.Title: Απάντηση: Proper names capitalisation in Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: I think Moodle used to capitalise all word first letters in the past but later changed the rule to almost no capitalisation at all.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Proper names capitalisation in Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Almost all text in Moodle should be Sentence case. This has been the rule for a very long time. No recent changes.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Proper names capitalisation in Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for your response! I am happy to see that you use a capital "S" to refer to Sentence case. As I read in https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/sentence_case it means "the first letter uppercase and subsequent letter lowercase with exceptions such as proper nouns or acronyms". I am referring to the exception of proper nouns. If e.g. I create a new type of block and I name it "Exceptional New Grades" how should the following message refer to it? Add a new "Exceptional New Grades" block. Add a new Exceptional New Grades block. Add a new Exceptional new grades block. Add a new exceptional new grades block. In other words, why is "The Activity results..." using a capital "A"? And why is "Add a new activity..." using a small "a"? (from the forum's description)

ResponsesInList.Title: File content display on grading
ResponsesInList.Text: When a student submits a document in response to an Assignment it will display the content of the document on the screen if the document is either a pdf or doc type. If in addition to the pdf of doc another type of file was uploaded by the student , the system will show that it is trying to generate a display but eventually will show a blank screen. Until last year this did not happen. if two files were uploaded by the student, for example one pdf file and the other an image file, the system ignored the non pdf one and displayed the pdf content correctly. This is a critical issue. For example an assignment may require a report (pdf or doc type) and also an image or software code file. Until the last version the report was displayed correctly. Now the only way to read the report is to download it to the local computer and than opening it. This is a time consuming task and there is no way annotate the document if you don't have the correct software. Is there a solution to this issue, or will this be corrected in next version?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: File content display on grading
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ofer, From the description you have provided, it seems to me neither of the two provided Document converters is set up and working correctly on your site. Go to Site administration > Plugins > Document converters > Manage document converters.  I Unoconv or Google drive Enabled? Go to Unoconv Settings. Is there a green checkmark beside the box for the Path to unoconv document converter? Click the link for Test unoconv path. Is it configured properly? Click the link for Download the converted pdf test file. Are you able to see the PDF? If you are not using Unoconv, are you using Google Drive instead? For it to work you must have OAuth 2 service working. And, you can then test if it is working properly. Without one of the two converters being properly set up and working, the problem you describe will continue to exist.

ResponsesInList.Title: Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.1
ResponsesInList.Text:
Does Moodle comply with the following Success
Criteria? Thanks in advance. Success
Criterion 2.1.4 Character Key Shortcuts (Level A): If a
keyboard shortcut is implemented in content using only letter (including upper-
and lower-case letters), punctuation, number, or symbol characters, then at
least one of the following is true: Turn off A mechanism is available to turn the
shortcut off; Remap A mechanism is available to remap
the shortcut to use one or more non-printable keyboard characters (e.g. Ctrl,
Alt, etc); Active only on
focus The keyboard shortcut for a user interface component
is only active when that component has focus. Success
Criterion 1.4.12 Text Spacing (Level AA): In content
implemented using markup languages that support the following text style
properties, no loss of content or functionality occurs by setting all of the
following and by changing no other style property: Line
height (line spacing) to at least 1.5 times the font size; Spacing
following paragraphs to at least 2 times the font size; Letter
spacing (tracking) to at least 0.12 times the font size; Word
spacing to at least 0.16 times the font size.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.1

ResponsesInList.Title: #anchor in links
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi there, For better usability , I would like to include anchors in the menu-links as well as the course topic lists, so that the user automatically scrolls to the relevant content. Like this example .../mod/page/view.php?id=36/ #page-content Which php file(s) should I change and how? Many thanks in advance, Kind regards, Tim

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: #anchor in links
ResponsesInList.Text: I found the solution: Add course-header to moodle\theme\remui\classes\output\core\course_renderer.php // Display link itself. $activitylink = html_writer::empty_tag('img', array('src' => $mod->get_icon_url(), 'class' => 'iconlarge activityicon', 'alt' => ' ', 'role' => 'presentation')) . html_writer::tag('span', $instancename . $altname, array('class' => 'instancename p-10 font-weight-400 text-blue')); if ($mod->uservisible) { $output .= html_writer::link($url . "#course-header" , $activitylink, array('class' => $linkclasses, 'onclick' => $onclick)); } else { // We may be displaying this just in order to show information // about visibility, without the actual link ($mod->is_visible_on_course_page()). $output .= html_writer::tag('div', $activitylink, array('class' => $textclasses)); } return $output; }

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle 3.3 with Font Awesome 5

Kind regards Adrian

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle 3.3 with Font Awesome 5
ResponsesInList.Text: I'd be interested to know how you've got on - I'm looking to use Fontawesome Pro 5, and it seems the inclusion of FA is really poorly implemented at the moment - the files are stored in /lib/fonts, but the stylesheet to be used has to be copied (and slightly modified) into the theme's styles subdirectory. This stuff really needs to be pluggable as-is, to enable use of any version of FA (4, 5 or newer, free or pro) just by unpacking the FA download into the right place. Otherwise it's way too hard to use Pro, which is a pain for users and rude to the developers of FA itself. Personally I'd like to see this (and bootstrap & other similar stuff) completely outside of themes - a plugin to install, which a theme can depend on if desired.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Auto Enroll in a Course dependent on other course completions
ResponsesInList.Text: Learning plans are not for enrollment. Learning plans "track" competencies that are awarded for activity/course completions. Did you research if cohort sync could be a possible solution?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Auto Enroll in a Course dependent on other course completions

ResponsesInList.Title: How to change default sorting order of student names
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, The default sorting order of student names is by last name. Is there a way to change this to first name? Where I work (in Iceland) first name is always used. I have found some posts addressing this issue but not found a solution. I have Moodle 3.3. Many thanks, Kristbjörg

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to change default sorting order of student names
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Kristbjörg, Generally, in most places in Moodle where student names are shown in a list, you can click the heading, First name, to sort the list the way you want. First click will sort a - z, then another click will sort from z - a. The other headings can also be used to sort the list. Is there a particular place you are interested in?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to change default sorting order of student names
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Al and thanks, I know about this. I mean where student names are not shown in a table, like when giving feedback in assignments, clicking the arrows in the top right corner (img). Sorting by first name in the submission table does not affect the order of names there. I have advised teachers to first, sort by first name in the view all submissions table and then open each students submission in a separate tab, in order to have the submissions in alphabetical order, but I guess this is cumbersome if you have 100-200 students. Sometimes teachers are using the assignment activity to grade something that was not submitted into Moodle, like lectures or experiments for example, in order to use a marking guide or a rubric and I guess then they order their data/papers in alphabetical order according to names. Kristbjörg

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to change default sorting order of student names
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Kristbjörg, I was afraid that might be what you meant. I don't know of any way to change the order of that list unless you dig through the code and find where that list is sorted and change it. Even if you go to User policies and change the Alternative full name format to just show only the, firstname, the names in the  list of students are still in lastname alphabetical order. As an alternative, supposedly if your language pack defines name display, you should be able to just put, language, in the Alternative full name format setting, and get what you need. Before I retired, the order of that list always seemed to frustrate me, too. What I did to get around it's annoying behavior, was install the Grade Me block, and add it on the front page of the site, with it set to display throughout the entire site. When any users logged in, if they were graders anywhere, and there was something for them to grade, it would be listed and they could be grading in just two clicks. When they saved the graded submission, the updated Grade Me block would be right there and they could go directly to the next person that needed grading. Since ONLY students with submissions needing to be graded are listed in Grade Me, they did not have to "play" with the filter setting for that list.

ResponsesInList.Title: Improved Printing of Gradebook User Reports
ResponsesInList.Text: My teaching staff would like to be able to print a "clean" user report of grades for using during teacher conferences.  Does anyone have a modification that would clean up the printing of the user reports? We would like it to skip the Moodle Header information, side blocks (which we dock anyway) and look similar to how it looks on the webpage. We can skip the first and last pages (but would like not to) on printing, but we get the teacher's picture on the printout and no student name, making it unusable.  If we try a group, you get the student names, but they are across the site name and barely readable. I would suggest this become a core Moodle change so that schools have a way to easily printout user grades. Brian Pool

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Improved Printing of Gradebook User Reports
ResponsesInList.Text: Interesting request, Brian. In my 10 years of using Moodle, I have never wanted to do this.  There have been times when an administrator has asked me about a student's overall grade, and I simply print the grade book User Report to a PDF file.  This works, but it does include some "garbage" at the top, but not a problem. Your request does take on a similarity to people who as for printed versions of a Moodle quiz. One response is "we are an electronic product, and not a printed product" meaning Moodle.  If you want paper, go back to paper systems.  However, there is always room for improvement. For the Grader Report, one can export the grade book, bring the exported data into a spreadsheet product, and make it as pretty as they want.  But there is no "export" feature for the User report.  There have been a few times where I want to play around with a user's grade book view, and I have been successful copy/pasting the User report into Excel.  Yep, some clean up required. Well, might we just need a method to "Export" the User Report?  I don't know, I am just thinking out loud.  I do appreciate that you raised the question.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Improved Printing of Gradebook User Reports
ResponsesInList.Text: I completely understand your point on being online, but that is really only a good point when talking about users that always have access and college students.  In a K-12 rural environment we have lots of users that may not have access.  Additionally, when staff do parent/teacher conferences, parents want to see and go over the grades and what their students can improve.  We need a clean way to print their grades to review and send home with involved parents. As a tech director I can certainly export to excel and  print (although that is alot of work for 100+ students.)  That is not however the way I want all my staff to do it, as they can't all do that. It just seems it should be a cleaner product straight out of Moodle.  In previous versions (1.9) it certainly was.  I have a great staff member working on CSS to try and fix it! Brian

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Improved Printing of Gradebook User Reports
ResponsesInList.Text: While exporting the user grade book may work in the short term, we were able to work with the CSS code to modify the user report when it comes to the printout only. You can make these changes to the report with CSS mods in the display of the page as well. We elected to make our changes to the printout because we use the printouts during parent-teacher conferences in a k-12 environment and needed a more simplistic example of student work for parents. Below you will see the code changes that we did for our report. Similar changes can also be made by using the inspection tool and removing items using the display: none; option like you will see below. The first line, @media print{ will make the changes only to display in the printout. Removal of this line will cause the changes to take place in the html. The code should be placed in the Custom CSS editor section of your theme. @media print { /*remove breadcrumb from print out*/ .breadcrumb { display: none; } /*@end*/ /*remove selection boxes from printout of user grade report*/ .form-search input, .form-inline input, .form-horizontal input, .form-search textarea, .form-inline textarea, .form-horizontal textarea, .form-search select, .form-inline select, .form-horizontal select, .form-search .help-inline, .form-inline .help-inline, .form-horizontal .help-inline, .form-search .uneditable-input, .form-inline .uneditable-input, .form-horizontal .uneditable-input, .form-search .input-prepend, .form-inline .input-prepend, .form-horizontal .input-prepend, .form-search .input-append, .form-inline .input-append, .form-horizontal .input-append { display: none; } /*@end*/ /*remove administration block from side of print display*/ aside{ display: none; } /*@end*/ /*remove separate group label from printout*/ .form-search label, .form-inline label, .form-search .btn-group, .form-inline .btn-group { display: none; } /*@end*/ /*remove select all or one user label from printout*/ .path-grade-report-user #graded_users_selector .singleselect label, .path-grade-report-user .view_users_selector .singleselect label { display: none; } /*@end*/ /*remove nav bar from printout*/ .nav-tabs > li, .nav-pills > li { display: none; } /*@end*/ /*remove middle nav bar from printout*/ .nav-tabs, .nav-pills { display: none; } /*@end*/

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Improved Printing of Gradebook User Reports

ResponsesInList.Title: Adding a "Help" button
ResponsesInList.Text: Is there a way to add a help button that opens a drop down window for adding instructions for an activity? Or is this something that must be customized through CSS ? Thanks.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding a "Help" button
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Dave, No need for playing with CSS, if you can install the Generico filter plugin. It comes with a number of bundled widgets one of which is a toggle switch, that lets you do exactly what you want to do. I use a modified version, Gradient_formatted_toggle, that let's me change the color to match my theme. The really nice thing about using the toggle filter is that you can then add other Generico filters such as tabs and tab items.

ResponsesInList.Title: Calendar: inconsistent visibility of group events
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, I noticed that a teacher will only see group events of groups he doesn't participate in if he views a certain course in the calendar. If he views all courses in his calendar, he only sees group events of groups he is in. Does anyone know why this difference in visibility exists? It seems arbitrary. This is the code that shows all group events to teachers if they are viewing only one course: https://github.com/moodle/moodle/blob/4bd4b46070b3906e5b1fd3126b524b9fc2ba2271/calendar/lib.php#L2084-L2090 This is the commit that introduced it: https://github.com/moodle/moodle/commit/7fd5786e6f24db2a6c702062705e33bef514bbac#diff-3762eee05a549dc356ad7f041fdf86f2 And this is the Tracker Issue for it: https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-28557 To a teacher this can be very confusing. If he has events for all courses displayed and creates a new group event (and isn't himself in that group) the new event won't show up for him. He needs to know that he first has to select the course that that group belongs to in order to see the event he just created. Do you agree that this is not very intuitive? Would it be better to just show all group events for each course to teachers when they view all courses? What would speak against this?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Restrict access
ResponsesInList.Text: It is possible I do not fully understand your set-up, but it should be quite straightforward. Setup your course with three activities . Activity 1: Module 1 - SCORM content 1 Activity 2: Module 2 - SCORM content 2 (Restrict Access condition = student must view Module 1) Activity 3 = your certificate (Restrict Access condition = student must view Module 1 and Module 2) The only problem that comes to mind, it what "completion" rule was used on the SCORM content file. ResponsesInList.Title: Add tag interaction - question bank
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi there, So far I've never used tags until Moodle 3.5 brought them into the question bank which is a great feature. However I find the interaction rather poor. While on the screen If the user click save changes no new tag will be added. Instead, one should hit enter, and the save changes. This might me confusing and at worst might prevent users from using - at least they'll need guidance. Since this is a new feature - at least at the question level - I wonder if couldn't be a better approach. Assuming of course this is might lead to bad UX. Thanks in advance, Hugo

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Add tag interaction - question bank
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you, Hugo, for sharing this with us. I agree that what you described is not the best user experience. We have made some improvements to the question bank tagging in 3.5 such as the ability to add question tags at a course level or to filter questions by tags. We have used the same form element that is used in all places in Moodle to tag things. This in itself was a good decision as that makes the tagging fields consistent in the entire system. However, there are some UX issues (like what you discussed) with the tagging element (more correct to say with the auto-complete element) in Moodle form library. I encourage you to file this in our tracker at https://tracker.moodle.org/ . The good thing is once we improve the auto-complete element, everywhere in Moodle that uses that element will also be improved.

ResponsesInList.Title: Letting faculty remove multiple sections easily
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, I found this excellent discussion about the changes to add/remove topics/sections . Fortunately, faculty now have a way to automatically add multiple sections at once. However, we set up course to default to a weekly format with 16 sections. Previously, faculty could easily change to a topics format with even zero sections, if that worked better for their class needs. Now, going from 16 weeks to zero topics is a HUGE pain. Even going from 16 weeks to a more standard five topics is a big pain. This strikes me as a big issue and a bug. I see the reasoning for taking the number of topics/sections out of the course admin area ( https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-57769 ). However, I don't think that the current remedy is suitable. I know there are a number of trackers addressing this issue. However, I did not see an open issue to address the difficulty in adjusting the number of sections down. Granted, having to few sections is worse than having too many. However, too many sections are ugly and possibly confusing to students. Should I create a new tracker, or is there one I can vote up?

ResponsesInList.Title: Recurring Courses Resources
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm managing Moodle 3.4 in my university, Each assigned traditional class (not courses) has a Moodle Course regarding they may have a different teacher for different classes. The problem is each semester we have to provide a master class that maybe could change after semester ends. So, if there is a 33 parallel class in one course, we have to do 33 times import feature and make sure configurations are set (also for groups settings) multiplied by number of courses that has master class, I wonder anyone has the same problem, and an alternatively effcient way to do this?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Recurring Courses Resources
ResponsesInList.Text: Sorry, Marcel, I'm not sure I understand what you mean here, (the way you are using language is different than I would interpret it) 'traditional class (not courses) has a Moodle Course regarding they may have a different teacher for different classes.' Do you mean each lecture group, traditional class with all students, is divided into tutorial groups, 33 tutorial groups, each with a different Tutor? Then at the end of each semester, the entire lecture group is expected to complete a single Master Class assignment? Assessment? In this case, I suspect that the use of Meta courses might be more appropriate. The structure you would end up with would be something like 33 child courses connecting to 33 Tutorial Meta courses and ONE Master Class Meta course.  The Meta courses can be edited and changed to suit your need and only the enrollments in the Child courses will change. Of course, if 1 Tutor has more than 1 tutorial group, then you can reduce the number of Tutorial meta courses you need accordingly. This is not the only solution, but as I interpret your situation it should work.

ResponsesInList.Title: Choice of text editor
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello! I don't know whether this is the right place to make feature suggestions. – Sorry, if it's not. It's weird to me that I have to choose a text editor globally. It would be much nicer if I could choose between Markdown and a WYSIWYG editor while editing an activity on a per-text-field basis. My use case is that I would prefer Markdown in general, but sometimes a WYSIWYG editor would be easier to use. Could this be implemented? Thanks!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Choice of text editor
ResponsesInList.Text: This is a very different and complicated question, and requires a more full response, well more than I put here. The issue is what is available that is compatible in PHP and HTML5. This is not a really clear cut issue. A WYSIWYG editor can carry a much larger footprint than is desirable in Moodle, so the markdown editors are used instead. Agreed, a WYSIWYG editor would be more helpful but performance, I suspect, would take a big hit. Another issue is that there was a lot of discussion about which editor should be used around the time that v2.0 was released. Two main ideas were pursued, one was adapt TinyMCE or develop Moodle's own. Both happened. A number of very clever people were able to replace TextArea with TinyMCE in v1.8 or v1.9, and, shared it. Worked well, too. From memory, it became a core plugin, so that became the obvious candidate for v2.0 (I might have the timing wrong, but this is how I recall it.)  A little later, Atto appeared as the Moodle developed markdown editor to eventually replace TinyMCE. The idea, I understand, was that a core Atto was developed and released and other devs would be encouraged to create Atto plugins for Users to download and install themselves. Unfortunately, this doesn't seem to be happening quickly enough so we are stuck with a seriously underdeveloped Atto or a soon to be dropped TinyMCE. The issues are a lot more complex than this, I suggest, and like all precis, this is about as accurate as a child's hand drawn portrait, (i.e. its almost recognizable as a drawing ). Hopefully, I have touched on a couple of issues that give some clearer clearer picture for you.

ResponsesInList.Title: Markdown: Images and Tables
ResponsesInList.Text: Using the Markdown editor, I have come across two questions: 1) In the docs , entering an image is described. However, how do I upload an image for display on a text page in the first place? In the standard editor, uploading an image is dealt with directly. 2) Is there a way to display a table created in Markdown with rules? In the table I have so far (see attachment), the columns are not separated at all. Thanks!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Markdown: Images and Tables
ResponsesInList.Text: Really surprised you haven't had an answer to this yet. 1) The buttons on your editor, the one right next to the broken link and before the smiley face allows you to upload an image to where ever you want it to be. This is the "Insert or edit image" button. It comes up with the upload dialogue, which has a really poor visual impact for newbies, the actual upload button "Browse Repositories" is just not clear enough I suggest. Should have a name like "Select image" or similar. 2) The limitations of the Atto editor are becoming the stuff of dreams, really bad dreams.... but the changes to tables are even worse. You have to format the table as best you can when you add it to the page then enter the HTML editing screen and make whatever changes you want, or it may be possible to create a standard table in a text editor and copy and paste that into your document when you want one. Unfortunately, HTML Tidy might have something to say about it, but give it a try. The alternative is to use TinyMCE as your preferred editor, I do. viel Glück.

ResponsesInList.Title: Can I change the font if using markdown editor?
ResponsesInList.Text: I am using Moodle 3.4 with default boost theme. I am using the markdown editor, and would like to font bigger. Any way to do that?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Can I change the font if using markdown editor?
ResponsesInList.Text: Using Atto, you can do it manually. Click on Show/hide advanced buttons and the last button on the bottom row. Use an inline style tag to make it work, for example: This font is bigger This font is bigger AFAIK , the current limitations of Atto don't allow for an easy change in size. Of course you may choose to swap editors to TinyMCE, but I don't know how much longer that is going to be supported in Moodle.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Marking Page Much Too Narrow
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Paul, From comparing the look of my dev site while using a rubric, I would say that your theme is Boost. I have noted in other places and plugins that Boost seems to render things much narrower than other themes do. As an example, the onscreen keyboard layout for the typing tutor, MooTyper, the key tops look much smaller rendered by Boost than they do when rendered by Clean.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Marking Page Much Too Narrow
ResponsesInList.Text: I've noticed this in a few places with Moodle 3.2 (I'm on a plus build) where certain things are definitely narrower. I thought this might have had to do with our theme, and our developer noticed that Moodle 3.2 seems to think there are 3 columns of content instead of 2 in a few places- we noticed this on our quizzes where the question blocks were nicely centered but squished everything. He had to take a look a write a line of CSS to override that. (I posted about this in the quiz activity section last week). Additionally, I noticed that same phenomenon this morning on the Advanced Forum (I was in the processing of removing it any way in favor of the default Moodle forum activity) that had the same formatting issue. I've also noticed this with the media player plugins that ship with 3.2. It will center the mp3 player on the page which is unimportant in some instances (i.e. a quiz, pages with audio files on them) but rather strange in others. For example, if I create a resource for an mp3 file on a course page, but also embed the same file in the resource description and have it displayed on the course page, it is super way off to the right. We are currently using the Poodll filter for media files which works absolutely fine, but I was seeing what the default ones were like and it's slightly problematic. I converted our theme to Boost but then it wasn't rendering the file links in the player- I have to go and re-embed them I think (but there's a lot of that to do!).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Marking Page Much Too Narrow
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks all for your help and comments. The information from our IT helpdesk is as follows: 'The theme in use presently is UCL's own in-house version which is a combination of the "Clean" (see: https://docs.moodle.org/31/en/Standard_themes ) and "Essential" themes. It is not possible to change the theme. But, even if you could, it does not change the appearance of the rubric in the Moodle assignment. Hence, I'm afraid that the suggestion that I made below is only possible solution to your problem even though it isn't ideal. There is currently a Digital Education and Disability Services team looking into accessibility and Moodle more generally and I have passed on your dissatisfaction with the display of rubrics in Moodle assignments to them. However, if a change to the layout is possible, it's unlikely to happen before next academic year. If there are any other accessibility/display issues with Moodle that you would like to see addressed please log them via Remedyforce with the Summary title, "Accessibility and Moodle" and we will pass them on to the team. ... I don't think that the theme is affecting the way the rubric is displayed as such. It is just how the Moodle assignment has been designed to display it. However, if you open a student submission using the Grade button you may notice a "Zoom in/out of Region" icon/button with 4 outward pointing arrows (see screenshot attached). If you click on that icon your rubric will open in a pop-up window and although you can't enlarge it, you can use the scroll bars much more easily to get a much better view of your multiple row and column rubric.' To be honest, I don't really understand why it's not possible to enlarge the rubric. It seems like a very basic thing that makes a lot of difference to usability . The rubric is a great system for marking, but having to scroll backwards and forwards each line is frustrating and makes marking a bit of a chore.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Marking Page Much Too Narrow
ResponsesInList.Text: Does anybody have any other thoughts? Anything that can be done? I have another series of marking to do, and it is very frustrating having to do it like this.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Marking Page Much Too Narrow
Re: Marking Page Much Too Narrow
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Eoin! I'll send this to the administrators and see if anybody can implement this change. I'll keep you posted on what they say!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Marking Page Much Too Narrow
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Paul - thanks for raising this, and i get the feeling Rubric are not just an issue for yourself, but for many students/teachers. I came across the same issues when trying to improve the Assignment page usability in general https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=349021 In real world examples i've been exploring the rubric text are often very difficult to read, and having to scroll horizontally is pretty common for students and teachers, even at full width users with a large screens. Currently the rubric is using an html table for layout. Unfortunately this means the arbitrary amount of text, combined with the arbitrary number of horizontal boxes of arbitrary width and height, can very quickly lead to poor usability of the rubric in any theme. The table layout is also not great for accessibility - but that's a whole different forum post... Currently experimenting with displaying vertically. which seems to work better, but very much work in progress. I'll try post some ideas for making rubric less terrible in the Assignment module usability refinements thread when i get a chance. Thanks again Stuart

ResponsesInList.Title: Inconsistent NavDrawer highlight in Moodle 3.5
ResponsesInList.Text: I have created a tracker item, MDL-62545 , that mentions that in Moodle 3.5, there seems to be some inconsistency with how NavDrawer selections are highlighted.  I thought I would mention this here on Moodle.org to generate some discussions about this issue. F rom MDL-62545 : When I pick a course, it gets highlighted in both the Courses area and the upper area.  Great! (graphic #1) When I pick Participants within a course, Participants gets highlighted at the top, but the course becomes unhighlighted. Well, maybe okay.  But shouldn't the course remain highlight to designate that I am looking at Participants within a course? (graphic #2) Then, when I click on Grades, it does not get highlighted but the Course does remain highlighted.  Hmmm, this is inconsistent with what clicking Participants does. (graphic #3) Has anyone else noticed this issue?  Any ideas? I am referencing MDL-62545 here, and then referencing this topic within MDL-62545 .

ResponsesInList.Title: Accessibility block
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi. Is there any accessibility tool that I can use for the visually impaired learners? Right now I am using this block . But since we may be upgrading to Moodle 3.4, I was wondering are there any new tools to help them?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Accessibility block
ResponsesInList.Text: I've spent quite a while looking for Moodle ones, but couldn't find any other than the Accessibility block. We've now installed the free Orato text-to-speech tool ( link ) on most our school computers and are recommending visually-impaired students install it on their home computers as well. We're also teaching learning support assistants to use Ctrl + mouse scroll to quickly zoom in and out of text. Haven't found a solution yet for colour overlays, other than messing with the monitor's colour settings. The "ATbar" used in the Accessibility block can also be downloaded as a plugin for Chrome browsers ( link ). Not sure if it's being updated at all.

ResponsesInList.Title: Default course setting for Weekly format
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, In Moodle 3.4, I find a wonderful option "Calculate the end date from the number of sections " for Weekly format course. This option really can solve my facing big problem. My problem is many teachers reported the course disappear suddenly in the middle of semester. Actually, my teachers always misunderstand the new overview and also the calculation of course end date for Weekly Format in Moodle 3.3. Their course have lack of weeks and so the course end date become before the real "end date". We do many document and promotion to talk about this but really really not work! My suggestion is Moodle can improve to let this option be a Default course setting. I prefer to set default as False and teacher must actively tick it to enable the function. It is better than default True which let many teachers ignore this option but still add wrong number of weeks (sections). Is it possible? Thanks!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Default course setting for Weekly format
ResponsesInList.Text: You may want to go and have a look at this discussion, in another forum, by Chris Kenniberg, it's called 3 Ways to Stop Blended Learning In its Tracks . The comments there are useful for discussion on how you may be able to approach people who complain about how they do the wrong thing. They blame their tools, Moodle, rather than accept responsibility for their errors and learn how to do it better. I know, I am being very harsh here, but I would expect that their courses are their responsibility, and it is up to them to make sure it works properly. If you are using Weekly Format, then an end date is almost mandatory, I have not run into this problem before, mainly because people work out their timings beforehand using a calendar, I suspect.

ResponsesInList.Title: Add link to language preference settings to language menu
ResponsesInList.Text: Many of our users are confused when Moodle returns to the default question upon next login, after they changed their language via the language dropdown-menu in the navbar. I think it would help to clear things up and improve accessibility if a link to language preferences was added to the language menu. Also, this would make it similar to the message and notification menus, which also feature direct links to message and notification preferences in Boost. Another improvement would be to include another string in the preferred language menu to make it clear to users that this changes the default language upon next login, since it is counter-intuitive that you can change your preferred language there and nothing happens. Or maybe it would be even better to get rid of the  "preferred language" setting altogether, and just make the language-dropdown menu change the preferred language as well as the language for the current page? That might be the most straightforward solution...

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Add link to language preference settings to language menu
ResponsesInList.Text: My understanding is that Moodle compares the available languages of the site with the language settings of the client's browser and delivers in the best match. If no matches, then in the Default language. For this to happen, the Auto-detect Language setting needs to be on. After the user has logged on, the profile is checked and the preferred language is named there, which is supposed to force a change the language used. If the language setting of a course is different then the client will show that language. Well, that is what I get from this Languages forum discussion , and Koen and Sevérin both know a lot more about this than I ever will.. So it seems there is more than just one setting that needs to be changed.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Add link to language preference settings to language menu
ResponsesInList.Text: but when does language auto-detect even kick in? the preferred language in the user profile is always set to something (there is no "not set" option), and auto-detect does not seem to override this option

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Add link to language preference settings to language menu
ResponsesInList.Text: Isn't there an auto-detect language setting in the client? I know in Chrome, for example, there is a Language setting in the advance settings that allows you to set your preferred language. I would assume that would be one of the first things Moodle would check, and likely set the auto-detect at that point. Just make sure the user sets their preferred  language in their profile. That might help you think?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Add link to language preference settings to language menu
ResponsesInList.Text: There is good information in the language documentation . See this flowchart .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Add link to language preference settings to language menu
ResponsesInList.Text: well if there is an auto-detect feature it does not seem to overrule the preferred language set in the user profile, which is exactly my problem. the preferred language for users was automatically set to english up until recently, so i have a couple of thousand users that have english by default, and i guess a pretty large number of those will never find their way into moodle profile settings and just keep on wondering why moodle resets to english after they picked german from the language menu... i do not want to set all users to german via the database , since that might annoy the few hundred english speaking users we have, i was hoping there would be an "unset" feature that just erases any setting already present in user profile, and then lets auto-detect set a new default?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Add link to language preference settings to language menu
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Stefan, You could create a tracker issue to ask the creation of the "Default language" choice, in the list of languages. In the short term, you could also try to delete the language value in user preferences (for one/some users), to see how Moodle handles that case... Séverin

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Remove enter button page from SCORM launch

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Remove enter button page from SCORM launch
ResponsesInList.Text: you can use the setting "student skip content structure page" in your SCORM settings page and the page will be skipped for users with the student role (but not teacher/admin)  - but... if you are using the "new window" option in your scorm settings this may result in pop-up blockers preventing the pop-up from loading.

ResponsesInList.Title: Allowing non site admins to upload bigger files
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi! In my current site, only site administrators can upload files up to the size limit set on php, which is 200mb, But course creators for instance, cannot.  They can only upload up to 2MB. Is this still PHP settings other than the Max file size I set up tp 200MB? Site details: Moodle 3.4 Windws 2016 and PHP running in IIS , which allows up to 1GB, but users of course dont know that =) PHP7.2 THANKS! J.Guzman

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Allowing non site admins to upload bigger files
ResponsesInList.Text: .....And have found my problem and fixed it.  This has to do with the course (that specific one) being a legacy course.  We have been using moodle since 1.9 and some of the older courses were backed up and hammered...errr.. restored into the  new version 3.4. All works fine with those but for some reason, the course settings had a 2MB limit on the course, so I went to Course Administration> Edit Settings and scrolled down to Files and Uploads to change the value to the desired one . I hope this helps somebody else. Although I guess my site is one of the few with legacy courses forced into a new version. J.Guzman

ResponsesInList.Title: Closing SCORM page direct settings - Moodle or Storyline?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Closing SCORM page direct settings - Moodle or Storyline?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Jeyda, this should be done in SCORM, closing the window at completion of the activity is part of the code of the package. It may throw up a confirmation box from Moodle, but that would be all. The page on which the SCORM is activated would unlikely to be able put in a redirect, as it would be a very tricky thing because of the nature of the HTML link pointing to something inside Moodle. A PHP coder might be able to help here, but....

ResponsesInList.Title: subject without teachers
ResponsesInList.Text: I want to list all subject without teachers

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: subject without teachers
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Selma, unfortunately, you have not provided much information about you Moodle. Version, theme, and so on will often have an impact onhow you can retrieve information about your courses. In the most simple case, you may be able to generate such a report from the database if you install the adhoc report plugin from the OU. If this is not possible and you have phpMyAdmin or some other query tool to search your database, then you will need to build a query using that tool. The database has changed significantly since the last time I have done anything like this so I don't know which tables you might need to define connections for building such queries. Someone in the Developer's forums should be able to provide more information.

ResponsesInList.Title: Unzipping uploaded files moodle file activity
ResponsesInList.Text: Greetings, We have Moodle 3.4, and we created a course, then add a file activity, then we drag and drop a zipped file into this activity, and then we need to unzip it. But when I click the unzip button, nothing happened. Please advise!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Unzipping uploaded files moodle file activity
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes, that is likely. It is my understanding that SCORM files are uploaded this way, but that is all. The file itself is it an entire course file or just a single page of text, text and images, text, images and multimedia files? If it is just a text file, unzip it, then upload it or copy and paste. If it is text and images, or text, images and multimedia, can't help you there. Unless you want to, in your course, create a page, add an image and/or multimedia files, back it up and then download it. Change the download file type to zip and unzip it. Use this file as a shell, changing the xml code as required. Zip it up and change the file type to mbz, then restore.  (This used to be simple but since v2.0, it is not as easy as it used to be but the security restrictions should be able to be gotten around, look for the patterns for file linking.) If it is an entire course, and it has all the Moodle required xml files, in place, change the file type to mbz and upload it as a restore. There is probably an easier way of doing this, but I don't know it, based on the little information provided.

I'm working on a deadline and the shortfalls of moodle are really frustrating.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: NB! Calendar on front page
ResponsesInList.Text: It is possible that a theme may be able to help here. Have a look through the available themes and see if you can find something. The Fordson theme, for example has a button under the header bar that links directly to a full page calendar, that might be closer to what you are looking for. The calendar block is a plugin, and as such is likely to be placed either side of the course page, this is why you might find it an annoyance to only get the block on the left or the right and not in the centre.

ResponsesInList.Title: Adding a box to check before students move onto a quiz
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm very new to using Moodle and am creating several pages and quizzes for my company.  I want to have a box for them to check at the bottom of the page before they move on to the quiz that says they are taking responsibility for the content.  The version I'm using is 3.4.  Is there an easy way to do this? Thank you.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding a box to check before students move onto a quiz
ResponsesInList.Text: Tim Hunt wrote an excellent a cknowledge plagiarism statement access rule , available as an additional plugin for Moodle 2.6+ . See also the site policy documentation .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding a box to check before students move onto a quiz
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you, this will hopefully get me in the right direction.  It's close to what I need to do.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding a box to check before students move onto a quiz
ResponsesInList.Text: Jeff, Another possibility would be to present the statement of responsibility using a Label resource with its completion settings set to allow students to manually mark as complete - then restrict access to the quiz based on the completion condition of the statement. This would give a checkbox to the right of the statement, and checking it would "unlock" the quiz. You statement may need to include something like, "by checking this box, I agree...". David

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding a box to check before students move onto a quiz
ResponsesInList.Text: Should this plugin go into the standard Moodle package?

ResponsesInList.Title: Quiz submissions
ResponsesInList.Text: Is it possible for the tutor / teacher on a Moodle course to change the status of a submitted quiz from submitted to unsubmitted so that a student can continue working on their attempt? I have been asked to raise this by a tutor at our university. The quiz in question was set to 1 attempt only. A couple of students needed to be given the chance to reattempt the quiz, We know that you can set a user override for a student, for example, giving them 2 attempts. You can also delete a student's attempt within the quiz results screen so that they can then have another go. However, is it possible to simply change the status of the submitted quiz to unsubmitted so that the student can continue working on their attempt? If not, I don't know if it would be possible for something like this to be added in some future iteration of Moodle? Or, are there very good reasons why this is not a good idea? Any answers on this, even if this is just to explain the rationale for not allowing a tutor to change a students submitted quiz from submitted to unsubmitted, would be really helpful and I can then go back to the tutor with what can be done or a reason for why this is not possible. Thanks in advance.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Quiz submissions
ResponsesInList.Text: The difficulty is that when a quiz attempt gets marked as submitted, it is not just a simple change in the quiz_attempts table in the database , but also normally some updates in the question_attempt and question_attempt_steps tables for all the questions in that quiz attempt. It is possible to undo all the database changes that happen when the attempt is submitted, but it would be a bit fiddly to get right, and so no-one has had the time or inclination to implement it. However, it certainly would be a good idea to make this possible, but it is not going to happen until someone has a strong-enough motive to do the work. So: Good idea in principle. Only not been done before because making it work would be hard and time-consuming. In the mean time, just give students a second attempt.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Quiz submissions
ResponsesInList.Text: Many thanks for your reply Tim. I will pass this back to the tutor.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Quiz submissions
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Kristian, I'm not sure whether this would answer your question, but it from Moodle 3.4 onwards, it's possible to override a student's activity completion status from the Activity Completion report. This should reset the number of attempts for a specific user, as the completion status returned to it's original value. As long as the quiz is available (no end date, or end date in the future), the student should be able to retake the quiz. https://docs.moodle.org/34/en/Using_Activity_completion

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Quiz submissions
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Joost, This is very interesting. Looking forward to trying this out when we get out next Moodle upgrade. We're on Moodle 3.3 at the moment. Thanks very much for your reply.

ResponsesInList.Title: Removing bottom navigation links
ResponsesInList.Text: Is there a way to remove or deactivate the navigation links that appear at the bottom of the pages, activities , etc..?? These can be VERY confusing for people, especially when a topic contains an activity or book with multiple sections and a person uses those bottom links instead of following through the activity itself.  I have had several people complain of missing parts of an assignment because of clicking those bottom nav links and being taken to the 'next topic' instead of the next section of the activity. Of course this can be a process that is learned over time, but those links are serving no purpose for us and only add to confusion. If it is possible to remove them, I would sure love to know how. Thanks

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Removing bottom navigation links
ResponsesInList.Text:
On the Fordson theme you can hack the columns2.mustache file and remove this line: https://github.com/dbnschools/moodle-theme_fordson/blob/master/templates/columns2.mustache#L103 
```text
{{{ output.activity_navigation }}}
```
 That is what brings in the navigation for Boost-based themes.  Look for it in the template files of your theme.

ResponsesInList.Title: AJAX errors after session timeout + Chrome restart
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, when you launch Chrome with a Moodle tab from yesterday still open you get multiple "servicenotavailable" error boxes. If you then reload the page, you get redirected to the login page. Users shouldn't see this "servicenotavailable" error if the problem is that they're not logged in. This occurs on Moodle 3.4.1 (Build: 20180115) running on CentOS 7.4.1708 with Apache 2.4.6, MariaDB 5.5.56 and PHP 7.2.2 when accessing it with Google Chrome 63.0.3239.132. I have already tested and debugged this and found out the reason for the error: In this case it is AJAX calls being performed while the user is not logged in. The user is not logged in because his last session timed out. Normally when he opens a Moodle page he would get redirected to the login page. However, what happens here is: Chrome opens the Moodle page when being launched because that page was open when Chrome was last closed. But it doesn't refresh the page by sending a new HTTP request which would redirect the user to the login page. Instead it displays the page as if the user was logged in which leads to the AJAX calls failing. How do I prevent this from happening? Just using  another browser or changing some browser settings won't work for us as we don't have control over that. I also don't want to "hack" Moodle's core code as that would make it harder to maintain. Any help appreciated, Thanks

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: AJAX errors after session timeout + Chrome restart
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Tim, Is the problem you describe covered by MDL-56896 ? If so, please could you comment on it. If not, feel free to create a new tracker issue.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: AJAX errors after session timeout + Chrome restart
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Helen, seems like that's exactly my problem. I wrote a comment on it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Calling Moodle Site Admins and data privacy officer for GDPR-compliance testing
ResponsesInList.Text: As you might know, we recently released Moodle’s approach and plan to GDPR . To support Moodle sites in the EU to become GDPR compliant, we have developed features which will be installed as plugins, initially, for Moodle 3.3 and 3.4. The features will then become part of Moodle 3.5 release which is a Long Term Supported (LTS) version of Moodle. We now would love your help to test the GDPR features and get feedback on what we need to improve by March 2018. What is involved? Around 10 - 15 minutes of your time to complete: A quick card sorting activity A usability test based on our prototype features Want to get involved? Then we would love to have you on board by: Selecting a date and time that’s suitable for you to do test via this calendar link. Sharing this message through your own communication channels to peers and colleagues who would be suitable to assist in testing! Hurry, book your spots, as we would like to ideally get our Moodle GDPR testers by COB (in your countries) on Friday 2 February!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Lost in courses list after moodle change
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear A B, I understand your frustration about the UX improvements to Moodle, as it may look different from what you're used to. A constructive approach to solving your issues would be the best course of action to take. As far as I understand it, your main issues are with the new My Overview block that has replaced the old block Course Overview as core. This block can still be installed and used instead of the one you're somewhat unhappy with, if you're a systems administrator for your Moodle. If you're not the systems administrator, you could point the person in charge of this to the correct plugin, so he/she can install and enable it. There's just one caution: at some stage (in a little over 2 years), the legacy Course Overview block will cease to function, with the release of Moodle 3.7. I strongly hope that you will have gotten used to the new and improved My Overview block by then and that you can see some of the positives of this new redesigned block: - a timeline for detailed information on what's expected when - sorting courses according to Current, Future and Completed - more detailed course completion details - ...

We have an external course provider that says this doesn't happen on other sites.   They provide the files and we restore the zipped files.  We manage to put up about 6 (totalling 1.2gb) then Moodle stops. Running a course size report shows that these courses are the largest. Any help much appreciated.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course pages editting disappears
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Sandra, Seems you have a lot (maybe even too much) media that has to be loaded on opening the course main page. In regular Moodle course formats like Weeks or Topics, everything is loaded upon entering the course, which may cause problems if there are a lot of huge files to process (image, audio, video). If there's a timeout because of the sheer volume of data to be loaded, you may need to have a look at how the media files are incorporated in your courses. Embedded external media works better than having the complete files as part of your courses.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course pages editting disappears
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Joost. That was my suspicion.  It is just that the supplier says they do not have any problems on other sites... kind regards, Sandra

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course pages editting disappears
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Sandra, You could ask your supplier how those other sites have been configured. It could be that there's a memory limit setting that's significantly lower than what they're used to seeing in other sites. If that's the case, there's probably a few community members in the Hardware and performance forum you could consult.

ResponsesInList.Title: Navigation and Other improvements
ResponsesInList.Text: We are exploring some big changes to our Fordson theme directly related to usability .  Most noticeable is the changes to navigation. Our next release will have the following usability improvements: All Moodle navigation and course navigation is located in the top navbar. Activity Module menu is still located in the gear in the upper right of the module page as it makes sense to have the module menu within the module you are wanting to edit. My Course drop down displays list of enrolled courses in the top navbar. New "This Course" drop down menu displays what was previously in the Nav Drawer.  This is all that is needed to hop around the weeks and topics of a course. New icon buttons in top navbar: Course Management, Course Dashboard for students, Site Administration, and Easy Enrollment Course Codes (if you use the Easy Enrollment plugin). Course Management and Course Dashboard for students will now open in a new modal pop up from anywhere within the course. Turn Edit on is always visible.  Clicking button will return the user to the exact spot on the page they were at previously.  No more scroll to top, click edit, scroll back down. No more nav drawer.  All menu items are accessed via the top navbar either in a drop down or the modal pop ups. Blocks remain where they are and when editing is turned on the Add a Block box is right there where you need to add blocks and not hidden somewhere on the other side of the page. The page layout is two columns content and blocks. The course title is now a link that will take you back to the course homepage.  Sometimes breadcrumbs get messy or people don't use them.  They are lost trying to get back to the course homepage. This Course drop down also contains the following quicklinks: Course Homepage, badges, competencies, and calendar for the course. Button icons in the top navbar have tooltips so that you know what they do without someone having to tell you. We think consolidating all the navigation in one area is a huge usability improvement.  We are excited to share the improvements but would like some feedback for more enhancements. If you have a development site and want to checkout our latest changes try this: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1RjrD8orVX7CdSQU8u6_OwrybA6YtTlKs/view?usp=sharing

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Navigation and Other improvements
ResponsesInList.Text: ANd here is what a site admin/teacher would see in terms of buttons and navigation at the top.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Navigation and Other improvements
ResponsesInList.Text: Very nice work here. I really like the fact that the menu is always available and the interface is clean, unobtrusive and responsive.

ResponsesInList.Title: Assignment module usability refinements
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, doing a quick ux/ax and information architecture review. Focusing is on the assignment activity module in moodle.... As a teacher when viewing the assignment mod moodle displays this table : This all seems to take up a lot of screen height, uses a table for layout, and is not optimised for accessibility. For a teacher the tabular data is: the number of participants in the assignment the number who have submitted work to the assignment the number of submissions that need grading the due date of the assignment the time remaining Could we possibly display this information in a more accessible and user friendly way? From an information perspective there is a lot of data redundancy here which can be improved on, from a usability perspective the information could be optimised, and this seems a completely inappropriate use of tables in terms of accessibility. Breaking it down : The due date is currently buried, but is perhaps the most important data for both students and teachers. Participants and submissions can be a single information point. Actions the user needs to take now, such as grading that needs to be done, should be obvious. Implementation concept : This is just a quick ux design mock up an idea on improving the assignment activity in the Snap theme , so all comment are most welcome. Does this give the same information in a better format? Feedback very much appreciated. Cheers Stuart Lamour

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Assignment module usability refinements
ResponsesInList.Text: Nice, makes sense to me. One tweak (other than deleting the spaces before the colons ) I would prefer, is to keep the indication of time left e.g. Due: In 1 day, 2 hours and 15 minutes (14 March 2017, 5 pm) or, if already past due Due: Closed (12 March 2017, 5 pm) From your mockup looks like plenty space to accommodate it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Assignment module usability refinements
ResponsesInList.Text: In a similar way, can we improve the assignments page for students? Currently they see a lot of information, split between 2 sections - Submission Status and Feedback. Can we apply a similar logic for students and display this data in a less cluttered way? Extracting the same headline information we display for teachers leads to due date, submitted and status as the first elements. Details about the student's submission could possibly be separated from Submission Status and Feedback into a their own section. Feedback information is currently split between the 2 sections - Submission Status and Feedback. Moving all the information related to feedback into the Feedback section feels like a an obvious approach. Perhaps the most important elements of feedback for a student are the grade and a teacher's comments, so displaying this above any rubric/grading criteria might make more make sense? For the next stage I'll do user testing to make sure these changes to the page information architecture are helpful for real students, but in the meantime would welcome any comments. Here is a before/after screenshot of work in progress.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Assignment module usability refinements
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Stuart, Looks clearer in a lot of ways, the after image. How about splitting the 2 screens into 2 tabs to be displayed under Details? So: Details [detail info block] [Tab1 - Your submission] [Tab2 - Feedback] --- And maybe it would be useful to already display a grade (if available) in the detail info block bit.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Assignment module usability refinements
ResponsesInList.Text: Looks much better, and saves a lot of room. I do have a question about the "View all submissions" and "Grade" - why is one a normal link and one a (flat style) button? I see this all over Moodle and have never understood it. Why should "Grade" be a button and not a link, and vice versa? If there were a clear dominance of one of those as a choice - if %80 of the usage was to click "Grade" - then why put them side by side at all and not in separate locations on screen? But even then, if one is more commonly used, why not have two buttons here anyway?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Assignment module usability refinements
ResponsesInList.Text: Further iterations on the student view: And the teacher view: All that data that is displayed by Moodle assignments displays, but hopefully in a much more user friendly way Snap 3.3 with these improvements to the assignments page will be available soon for the Moodle plugins db, and right now on github.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Assignment module usability refinements
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Stuart, Thanks for sharing your mockups to the community for comments. I like what you are working on here. I have a few suggestions. I'd suggest that once a teacher has returned feedback to a student, that it should be displayed in the most prominent way. An issue with the current design is that students have to do a lot of scrolling once work has been returned to find feedback. Once work has been returned I think the feedback should be the most important thing. I like how in your mockups student submissions are displayed. This is a features that Blackboard has that Moodle currently does not. It could do a few things for instructors and students. First of all, it would be a benefit for students to see their work as soon as they upload . It could help reduce the "I submitted the wrong file" excuse. There would also be a secondary advantage to showing a converted PDF to the students. For those of us that are using Google Drive integration to create PDFs in Moodle 3.3 or higher, faculty have noticed that they have to wait for PDFs to be created on demand, slowing down their grading workflow. If the PDF was created when students submitted, it would save the instructors a few seconds times the number of students they are gradeing. I'm curious what you are doing with these mockups. Are you opening a tracker, and offering to create a patch for Clean and Boost, or are you developing this on the theme level for your SNAP theme and future Moodlerooms Themes?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Assignment module usability refinements
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ed, totally agree and we try and do that with the redesign in Snap. If feedback is available it is shown on the page directly under the activity description, along with who the feedback is from and the date it was given. Not sure we can do much in a theme about the way assignments are processed when converting formats - but lets see what happens in future iterations. The screenshots are from the latest version of Snap, which is available from the moodle plugins DB with the full release at the end of December. Best wishes Stuart Lamour

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Que características necesito en cuanto a hardware.
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Angel, Moodle forum posts in English language are best here. If "Solo hablas español", tal vez te convenga más el foro de Moodle en español . The best hosting I would recommend is a Moodle partner in your own language and, if possible, in your own country. 300 simultaneous quizzes might be very hardware-intensive (expensive), but less so if the questions are shown one at a time and the quizzes are slightly spread in a few minutes period. Will the students use a gigantic computer lab? Will they use their own home computers? Do you have an example quizz to illustrate how many large images are there? Making many exams in Moodle is a frequent situation in UNAM. I would suggest you to visit the UNAM Moodle admins and developers free site .

ResponsesInList.Title: How to let assignment checkboxes act like submissions?
ResponsesInList.Text: v. 3.3 on moodlecloud. Trying to track assignment submissions that are not submitted on line (i.e. they are turned in to the teacher in the classroom). We allow the student to mark the assignment as done via the checkbox on the assignment. Under Submission Setting on the assignment, we have “Require students click submit button” set to “No”. Under Activity completion / Completion Tracking, we have selected, “Students can manually mark the activity as completed.” When the student looks at the Course Overview on his dashboard , in the timeline view when sorted by dates, they see all assignments.  This would be fine except that even those that they have marked complete (with the checkbox) are still showing here, and there is a grayed-out “add submission” link beside these submissions. We can see no way to get these assignments be removed from the student’s course overview, with this configuration.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to let assignment checkboxes act like submissions?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Kim, If I'm correct, overriding activity completion as a teacher is one of the new features of Moodle 3.4. It may well be that that is what you're looking for, as you can see in this video: Moodle 3.4 will probably soon be available for MoodleCloud users.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to let assignment checkboxes act like submissions?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Joost, Thanks much for your thoughtful response.  Unfortunately, that’s not really a feature we’re looking for.  We do want the kids to be marking the assignments as complete. In brief, it seems that the check-boxes students use to mark assignments as completed are not used to evaluate whether or not an assignment should be removed from the Course Overview in Timeline view. The only way we can seem to get this working is to enable a submit button, which then requires a submission type (online text and/or file) to be enabled for the button to become visible.  This is more than we want to have the students do to inform us that they have completed the assignment. Perhaps there is a setting, or combination of settings, that exists that would enable this to happen, but we’ve not figured out the correct combination. Again, we want a student to check an assignment as complete, and the result should be that the assignment is removed from Course Overview in Timeline view on the student's dashboard. Any ideas? Thanks, Kim
