ResponsesInList.Title: Possible to hide Group mode icons in course edit mode?
ResponsesInList.Text: Most of our users preferred the old Moodle layout where it was possible to deactivate the edit dropdown menu and instead show icons for frequently used actions next to all activities when edit mode was turned on. Unfortunately, the admin setting that allowed for this has been removed around Moodle 3.x for reasons I never understood, but sadly, requiring ever more clicks for the same actions has been a constant development for the Moodle interface. Now we are using Moodle 3.3.1 and Boost theme, and the only icon that is still shown next to the edit drop-down menu is the group mode icon: I find this rather inexplicable, as group mode is not a setting that is frequently changed. To make matters worse, I regularly encounter teachers that mistakenly changed the group mode of activities without even noticing, probably because their mouse click missed the "edit" dropdown menu by a bit... For this reason, Id like to deactivate these group mode icons - is there a way to do this without changing core Boost theme files manually?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re-attempting assessments made in Articulate Storyline 2
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi there, I have a task at the moment which is requiring me to allow people to attempt an assessment and leave and then re-enter the assessment. The assessment itself is a SCORM 1.2 package built in Articulate Storyline and is sitting on a moodle 3.1 platform. The requirement is that a learner can enter the assessment which holds 37 questions, complete 10 (for example) come out of the assessment and go back in to that same attempt to finish it off and submit a grade. They are only allowed to submit the assessment twice. I've tried to figure this out all day and am not getting very far - can anybody suggest anything or help out at all? Thank you Rachelle

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Re-attempting assessments made in Articulate Storyline 2
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Rach, Not sure if I am on the same page, but it might be worth checking to see if 'Force New Attempt' is set to 'Yes' in the Scorm settings in Moodle. If it is, then each attempt will be considered as complete and re-visits will be forced as a new attempt. I think...! This from the help: "This setting hides the "Start new attempt" checkbox and prevents review mode. SCORM allows a student to return to the same attempt at any point and a new attempt is not possible unless the previous attempt has been set as "completed", "passed" or "failed". If the SCORM package does not do this, the student will always re-enter the same attempt."

ResponsesInList.Title: Activity module icons
ResponsesInList.Text: The topic of activity module icons has been raised a number of times in different forums, and it seems as though Moodle HQ is set to modernise the appearance of icons for the release of Moodle 3.4 (see MDL-58355 ). As someone with an interest in graphic design and how it relates to UX, I would like to gather some opinions about how activities are currently represented on the course page and how they might be improved to provide a more visually consistent and intuitive experience. The current set of icons have been around for a while and feature a variety of shapes, colours and level of detail. Third-party activity modules introduce even more visual variance to the course page. Personally speaking I would like to see Moodle adopt some of the design principles expressed in many modern apps by enhancing uniformity regarding the shape (and perhaps the colour) of activity module icons. It might also be worthwhile to provide a set of standards (or guidelines) to the developers of third-party modules regarding how to best represent their activity on the Moodle course page. Below is an image from a popular social networking app. The uniform shape and size of the avatars creates a balanced look, and the lines dividing each contact dissolves on the left side of the screen to prevent the content from appearing too compartmentalised. Could a similar design enhance the appearance of the course page?  What about completion tracking? Are there ways to improve how completion status is reflected on the page? Any additional thoughts or ideas would be greatly appreciated.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Activity module icons
ResponsesInList.Text: I use the Feedback activity for a number of form-filling-out processes (haven't use made use of the Dataform plugin), so I would like it if the Feedback icon looked more generic to input activities.  A bullhorn sometimes comes off as rather imperious.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Activity module icons
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm interested too. I don't know much about the third party icon situation, but I just thought I'd throw in that I really like the very simple Coursera icons that are actually grey by default, but go green once you have done that activity or read/watched that resource (screenshot attached).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Activity module icons
ResponsesInList.Text: This is a great idea.

ResponsesInList.Title: Closing dialogues
ResponsesInList.Text: We were doing some usability testing, and we noticed that, when a dialogue was open in a page, some users were clicking on the grey background area, expeciting that to close the dialogue. Therefore, we created MDL-60207 to change Moodle to match users' expectations. Does anyone have any comments about that?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Closing dialogues
ResponsesInList.Text: I agree, I would expect modals to close when I click in the grey background. It's always annoying if sites don't support that, because aiming for the close button is usually harder, especially on touch devices. There are exceptions, though. For example, critical warnings should not be dismissible by touching the background. In that case it is okay to raise attention to the message this way, as it cannot be closed as easily. Also, if a modal is a form, it would be too easy to close it accidentally by touching the background. I think in that case Moodle should also keep on relying on the close button (or buttons of the form).

ResponsesInList.Title: Capability issue with gradereport
ResponsesInList.Text: An error (possibly introduced during upgrade of 3.3.1 -> 3.3.2) is affecting our Manager roles (not the System Admins) whilst viewing a User Profile from Browse List of Users. The following errors are displayed (alongside additional stack trace): Capability "gradereport/report_completion:view" was not found! This has to be fixed in code. Capability "gradereport/report_log:view" was not found! This has to be fixed in code. Capability "gradereport/report_outline:view" was not found! This has to be fixed in code. Capability "gradereport/report_stats:view" was not found! This has to be fixed in code. Capability "gradereport/report_usersessions:view" was not found! This has to be fixed in code. Moodle documentation on the Grader Report ( https://docs.moodle.org/33/en/Grader_report ) indicates there is a single Capability available of grader:view ( https://docs.moodle.org/33/en/Capabilities/gradereport/grader:view ) Having checked the System Admin | User | Permissions | Capability Overview, I can find only the following capabilities, the errors above are missing! gradereport/grader:view: View the grader report gradereport/history:view: View the grade history gradereport/outcomes:view: View the outcomes report gradereport/overview:view: View the overview report gradereport/singleview:view: View report gradereport/user:view: View your own grade report Our Manager role is Allow on all of these. The stack trace indicates capability code is missing from line 2423 of /lib/navigationlib.php see attachment for full error stack. I've also had a look in the theme | navigation c ustomusermenuitems as this is the only other area I can find that talks about 'Grades' and 'Reports'. I would really value any ideas as to where to start on fixing this? Many thanks.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Capability issue with gradereport
ResponsesInList.Text: I have exactly the same issue, following a 3.3.1 -> 3.3.2 migration. I would appreciate directions to fix this, Thanks,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Capability issue with gradereport
ResponsesInList.Text: This does look like some kind of bug ... I'd advise you to file a report in the Moodle Tracker (and link to that from here).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Capability issue with gradereport
ResponsesInList.Text: Great advice, thank you. The has been logged at Moodle Tracker as MDL-60314

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Capability issue with gradereport
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Nathalie, Up-voting the bug at Moodle Tracker as MDL-60314 might speed up a fix. Just a thought.

ResponsesInList.Title: Toogle visibility of Restrict access rules
ResponsesInList.Text: In older versions of Moodle, there was a very recognizable dropdown box for toggling visibility of Restrict access rules, that immediately drew your attention when setting these rules up. From 3.1 onwards, this was changed to the 'eye' icon with just an Alt message describing the function of the button. This is not really intuitive and it may take a course creator or teacher some time to find it altogether. Is there any way to improve usability of this feature?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Toogle visibility of Restrict access rules
ResponsesInList.Text: What did the old UI look like? As far as I know the display of adding conditional restrictions has not changed since they have been introduced. We do have a patch that is changing the way the conditional restrictions are displayed to end-users: https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-59653

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Toogle visibility of Restrict access rules
ResponsesInList.Text: For much older versions of Moodle (around 2.5 - 2.6) I found there used to be a very clear dropdown menu for every condition added, prompting the teacher or course creator what to do (display the conditions and the activity greyed out; or hide the activity and the availability conditions altogether). In current versions of Moodle, 2.7 onwards, this very visible option has been replaced with the 'eye' icon. Before 2.7: and I get that this is not the best UI, but I also think the current approach needs a bit more information for the teacher / course creator, so he/she can use this very useful tool adequately.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Toogle visibility of Restrict access rules
ResponsesInList.Text: We are working on a patch that adds a help icon to try to explain the eye icon. What do you think?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Toogle visibility of Restrict access rules
ResponsesInList.Text: Still requires an extra click, and users don't regularly click those help buttons. I would rather go for a view like this: Restrict access Rule Hide/show rule to students Delete [description of rule1] eye icon to toggle visibility cross icon to delete rule [description of rule 2] eye icon to toggle visibility cross icon to delete rule

ResponsesInList.Title: Cron in cluster environment after upgrade to 3.1.6.
ResponsesInList.Text: Good morning, everyone, We have a four Red Hat 7.3 cluster with Moodle 3.1.6 and I cannot figure out if we can schedule the execution of cron.php in all of them or we have to keep scheduling just in one. Moodle 2.7 Upgrade documentation ( https://docs.moodle.org/27/en/Cron ) shows the below information: Cron in Moodle 2.7+ Cron has received a major update and now has support for both scheduled and adhoc tasks - MDL-25499 . The benefits of these changes are: The schedule for every task can be configured by the admin. See Scheduled tasks Tasks can run in parallel Cron processes use locking to prevent the same task running at the same time by different processes A result of this is that cron can be run much more often, which means (for example) forum posts can be sent out sooner. Admins can keep cron running at the same schedule as before, but it is strongly recommended that they increase the frequency of running cron to at least once per minute. But I don't know if the cron.php can be run in different servers since it can be run in pararell, or it just can run in parallel in the same node since it is recommended to run it every minute. Thanks in advance, Ángel

ResponsesInList.Title: Calling Teachers/Instructors with course editing rights to participate in Moodle HQ Usability Study
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Moodlers, Firstly, thank you for those who took part in our recent usability study, focussing on course administration settings in Moodle. If you would like to find out next steps with that piece of research, please refer to our post on moodle.org. We’d love to get your feedback, ideas and thoughts again! Now, we  would like to once again invite interested Moodlers to participate in another important usability study, running from Friday 11 August to Friday 18 August (note: the study will close 7:30 AM UTC Friday 18 August). We would like to hear from English-speaking Teachers/Instructors, with editing rights to Moodle courses (or administrators who frequently access Moodle course settings), to join a usability study that will help with future Moodle development. What’s involved? Involvement in this research study means: Spending  approximately 15 to 30 minutes trying out a prototype and giving us feedback, and/or we might interview you about your current experience using Moodle. A Moodle HQ researcher will set up a remote screen-sharing session with you on your own computer. Sessions may take place outside of typical business hours depending on your local time zone. We’d like to hear from you if: You can participate in the sessions online using Zoom Meetings (which involves sharing your desktop screen and audio) You have access to a microphone and a broadband internet connection You provide consent for Moodle HQ to record video and audio of your interactions using Moodle on your desktop screen. Please note: all video and audio recording will be strictly confidential and not be shared with anyone /other parties outside of Moodle HQ. If you’re interested in participating, please sign up using the link below: https://calendly.com/moodle/editing-teachers *Note research sessions will be run Monday - Friday

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Calling Teachers/Instructors with course editing rights to participate in Moodle HQ Usability Study
ResponsesInList.Text: Hey everyone, Thanks very much to those who volunteered for this study. Really appreciate the time and effort that many of you took to give feedback. For your information, we collect the data you provided to help us continue with our UX work in Moodle to make our learning platform interface more user-friendly and easy to navigate for our educators and learners. We still need more user feedback and experience to help us with the next stage of our work, so I’d like to invite you to a second usability study from today through to Wednesday 20 September. For more information and to sign up, please see this post https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=358290#p1445113 Thanks again everyone - look forward to working with you all again!

ResponsesInList.Title: Calling Teachers/Instructors with course editing rights to participate in second round of Moodle HQ Usability Studies
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Moodlers, Firstly, a big thank you to those who volunteered in the first round of our usability studies. Your feedback has been super helpful to guide our UX work in Moodle. We’d now like to invite you to sign up for the second round of usability studies. This study is also open to new Moodlers or those who’ve missed out on the first round and would like to be involved! As always, we’d love to get your feedback, ideas and thoughts too! Our second round of studies start from now through to Wednesday 20 September (note: the study will close 7:30 AM UTC Wednesday 20 September). You can sign up and get involved today! Once again, we would like to hear from English-speaking Teachers/Instructors who have editing rights to Moodle courses (or administrators who frequently access Moodle course settings) to participate. Your involvement will help with future Moodle development. What’s involved? Involvement in this research study means: Spending approximately 15 to 30 minutes with a Moodle Researcher, trying out a prototype and giving us verbal feedback, and/or we might interview you about your current experience using Moodle. A Moodle HQ researcher will set up a remote screen-sharing session with you on your own computer. Sessions may take place outside of typical business hours depending on your local time zone. We’d like to hear from you if: You can participate in the sessions online using Zoom Meetings (which involves sharing your desktop screen and audio) You have access to a microphone and a broadband internet connection You provide consent for Moodle HQ to record video and audio of your interactions using Moodle on your desktop screen. Please note: all video and audio recording will be strictly confidential and not be shared with anyone /other parties outside of Moodle HQ. If you’re interested in participating, please sign up using the link below: https://calendly.com/moodle/editing-teachers *Important note: If you sign up for a timeslot and are not able to attend, please be sure to cancel or reschedule ahead of time. Time slots are limited and we’d like to give as many people the opportunity to participate.

ResponsesInList.Title: Participants view should be merged with Enrolled users view
ResponsesInList.Text: I don't see the point of the division between Participants view and Enrolled users view that has been introduced with Moodle 3. What's the point of having a participants view that does not allow you to add more participants? All it does is confuse our users ("where can i enrol students?" is asked constantly) by hiding an essential action. I think the whole direction that the Moodle interface has been heading for is questionable, requiring more clicks for the same actions with every version, and hiding essential actions in ever more obscure menus. The two worst examples of this are the elimination of the possibility of displaying edit icons instead of the edit dropdown menu (an additional click for EVERY action!) and hiding the turn edit mode on button in a dropdown menu (another additional click...), but I will post about those separately.

ResponsesInList.Title: Better Workflow for Grading Lesson Essays

It would be best if the instructor has the option to grade the essay questions in bulk one after the other sequentially similar to the manual grading in the quiz module. Thanks for considering this improvement.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Better Workflow for Grading Lesson Essays
ResponsesInList.Text: If you have that many essay questions in an activity such as Lesson, wouldn't it make more sense to use the Quiz activity, which has a better workflow for manually grading essay questions? Lesson works well as a basic branching scenario, but isn't the best for grading such complex texts (I doubt it was designed to be used for this).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Seeking Volunteers for Moodle HQ Course Administration Research Study
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello everyone On behalf of Moodle HQ, I just wanted to say a big thank you for all your help in completing our card sorting activity on course administration. We had a great response, with over 300 participants in just under a week, completing the activity. I just also wanted to provide a brief summary of some next steps with the feedback you’ve provided: The UX team at Moodle HQ (mainly Barbara and I) have, and will continue, to go through the feedback that we received from the card sorting activity. Part of going through the feedback will be to gain insight into usage patterns to help identify current gaps and pain points in course administration. We will summarise the trends into a report which will then be used to inform future experience design work associated with course administration in Moodle. Thanks again to all Moodle community members who participated and shared the invitation to participate in the research activity. We really appreciate your continued support of our open source project. I look forward to working with everyone again and getting your valuable input for any future research activities .

ResponsesInList.Title: Improve access restrictions display
ResponsesInList.Text: We extensively use restriction access to restrict course modules based on groupings. Thus the display of content to the users has many repeated lines of text indicating what groupings each content is restricted to. See: We have submitted a patch (MDL-59653) which will collapse all that information in a modal window when you click on "Restricted". See: Here is a video of the feature in action: Please vote/comment on the tracker or this forum post about your thoughts and ideas. Would love to see this cleaner implementation in Moodle.

ResponsesInList.Title: A simple dashboard block for file download
ResponsesInList.Text: As an administrator I want to expose a dashboard block to all users which contains files (pdf, word, etc.) that any logged in users sees and can view and download the file from. Any good suggestions? Moodle 3.3.1

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: A simple dashboard block for file download
ResponsesInList.Text: While not exactly what you want, some themes have a "This Course" drop down which displays a listing or grouping of activities and resources.  For instance if you click on Resources from this course menu it would list all files, books, pages, and resources.  Not exactly what you want but close. What's nice about this is that it also shows what topic the file/resource/activity resides in. This type of functionality helps quickly locate a quiz or assignment when working in large courses.  Having the topic also helps give the user context for the resource/activity.  Fordson, essential, adaptable, and others have this built in.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: A simple dashboard block for file download
ResponsesInList.Text: Are these files you will have added for them to download? Perhaps you could use an HTML block, add it to the default dashboard for all users and upload your files into that block as links?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: A simple dashboard block for file download

It doesn't have any effect at all. The navigation block still appears. Any suggestions? Best regards Paul

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Hiding navigation block on the frontpage
ResponsesInList.Text: I tried this on our sandbox site demo. moodle.net . Please see Blocks FAQ I didn't change the default front page role. I turned on the editing and went to the navigation block and then Permissions and clicked the X to remove guests from being able to view the navigation block. When I logged out again, non-logged in users (ie anyone who just comes to the site) do not see the navigation block.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Hiding navigation block on the frontpage
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Mary, thank you for your prompt reply. This is exactly what I have done. Nevertheless this problem appears in my instance, so I need to carefully check my system configuration. Thank you and best regards, Paul

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Hiding navigation block on the frontpage
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Paul Did you try removing guest view permissions of Navigation block within Front Page Settings ? I tried removing guest view permission from the Navigation block on another page and it did not work. Only when I removed guest view permission from the Navigation block within Front Page Settings did Navigation block stop displaying on the Landing page. Charles
role: Picture of Charles Krengel eLearn Solutions

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Hiding navigation block on the frontpage
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Paul, I realise this is old now, but it may help others as I've stumbled across it from a search - I think the reason yours was not responding to removing the guest permission from the navigation block was probably due to either one or more of these settings being something other than the default values: Site administration --> Front page --> Front page settings --> Default frontpage role Site administration --> Users --> Permissions --> User policies --> Role for visitors *and* Role for guests I am not 100% certain which combinations would work in your specific scenario, but the removal of guest permissions on a block has the desired effect when these settings have default values. Regards, Martin

ResponsesInList.Title: 500 error for some pages, but fixed upon refresh
ResponsesInList.Text: I have Moodle 3.2.2 on a box with Windows Server 2012, IIS 8, PHP 7.13, and a database in MySQL 5.7. This is a second Moodle site that we have created to serve as the new training platform for our company. We're able to login, configure the appearance, set up users, and courses, but there is one problem that I have not been able to figure out, and it's working against me as I fight to keep Moodle for our business. When logging in, if the user mis-types the user name or password, and clicks Login, it shows a 500 internal server error. If I refresh the page, it takes me where it should have taken me (the login page with the invalid message). When uploading a file to a course, after clicking Save, I have the same problem, but if I refresh, it takes me where it should have taken me.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: 500 error for some pages, but fixed upon refresh
ResponsesInList.Text: We are now getting reports from all over about this error. This seems to be getting worse. If someone tries to open a quiz, 500 error, until we refresh. If they try to open a page resource, 500 error, until we refresh.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: 500 error for some pages, but fixed upon refresh
ResponsesInList.Text: Turn on Debugging so you can see the error message.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: 500 error for some pages, but fixed upon refresh
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you for your reply, Tim! One error has been eliminated, but the others are still happening, and I have narrowed it down. I did turn on "Developer" for Debug Messages and when we upload a file to a course and click Save and Display, or when we initially open the file as a student, we get the attached error: cannot execute event observer 'accredible_course_complete_handler' For those curious about how I may have solved the 500 error that we got when logging in with invalid credentials, keep reading. So we have two Moodle systems operating side-by-side on the server. We will eventually retire the old one, but for now, we need to keep it alive. Previously the old Moodle was running from the Default Website which reads from wwwroot . The new Moodle was running from another website that read directly from the new Moodle app folder. I wanted to swap them around and put the new Moodle in the same "seat" (with the same parameters) as the old site so that it was under the official URL , but also because the old Moodle was working properly. I also fixed some permissions issues in the Moodle app directory. Once I did these things, the 500 error when logging in improperly went away, and the 500 errors that happened elsewhere were giving us specific error info.

ResponsesInList.Text: We may have found the culprit. I'll post more later, but it's possibly the accredited plugin that we had installed. We have removed it and I'll test it either today or Monday. There was a 500 error when we unlocked the completion of a resource and saved it. I had Developer mode on for errors yet there wasn't any info beyond 500 which tells me that this is not a php error.

ResponsesInList.Title: Activity Completion Tracking
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, I'm posting this under usability as that's where it is a problem for me - but forum admin might decide it sits better elsewhere. I have courses with groups of students undertaking separate activities - lets call it differentiated learning. I'm preparing for upgrade to version 3.3 and want to fine-tune activity completion so that the course notifications are more accurate. Currently it works as follows - when students view a resource, take a quiz or whatever the completion box is ticked and it is tracked on the activity completion report. Unfortunately, the activity report doesn't take account of whether a student is permitted to access a resource - it just lists everything that has a completion option, even if the student isn't able to complete (for example because they don't belong to the only group with access). Once we move to 3.3 I'm anticipating this might go catastrophically wrong, with students panicking as Moodle tells them they've only completed 1/3 of the course activities, but they can't see anything that they haven't done. What I think SHOULD happen is that when the activity report displays, it is individualised for each student. If as a result of activity restrictions a student has no access to an activity, the report should have a gap (instead of a tickbox that will never be ticked) - and that the completion notifications and tracking should likewise only consider the activities available to that student, regardless of what else might have completion tracking switched on in the course. Can anyone enlighten me about whether this issue has been addressed in the 3.3 version of Moodle - or if there is a workaround? If there isn't a solution I'll raise a bug report as this will impact really badly on student perception of the new Moodle progress notifications if it hasn't been thought through. It's bad enough as staff wanting to check progress and having to constantly refer back to see why students haven't completed tracked activities, it'll be far worse if students are being told they haven't done something they don't have access to. Regards, Gordon.

ResponsesInList.Title: Odp: [3.2] Mass send e-mails with logins and passwords to manually createdusers
ResponsesInList.Text: I think I figured it out: Site administration > Plugins > Enrolment > Flat file (CSV) You need to enable the enrolment Flat file plugin first, then go into its settings and check "Notify enrolled users" . The site started sending e-mails after that.

ResponsesInList.Title: Quiz results navigation
ResponsesInList.Text: We recently upgraded from 2.8 to 3.2.  Many of the new features are great.  However, it also seems you are taking a page from Microsoft's development book.  By that I mean, taking commonly used items that were 2 or 3 clicks away to ones that are now 4 or more clicks away and/or moving them to a completely different location.  In most cases, it is probably just getting used to it.  I do like the new Admin menu layout, though it has its own issues. Enough quibbling, down to specifics. We are using the default 3.2 theme (Boost?) and working on making everything compatible with the Mobile app. In 2.8 (at least in the theme we used), click on the quiz and get the quiz admin menu.  Select Results->Grades, Responses, or Statistics or other quiz related function are accessible with no problem with the ability to bounce back and forth with ease all basically in the same area. In 3.2, click on the quiz, then click on the gear, then click on your function.  The problem comes in if you select Results-> Grades to see how the latest group did or completion status, then if you want to see the students' responses or check for commonly missed questions, since the gear or any selection menu is not available (first image below), you must click back to the quiz then click on the gear to change function.  You must do this for each change as the gear only appears, and the menu is only available, on the first quiz page (second image below).  In the first case below, clicking on Grades or Results does nothing useful by just taking you to the current page. Image 1 Image 2 Overall, I like the Boost theme, though I may try others due to this large PITA.  Is this a bug or intended operation?  If intended, why and please fix!  In any case, how can I get the all contextual menu operations on every page? In a similar vein, I have also noticed on the Admin menu that when items are selected some of the bread crumbs have links and others do not.  This too is bothersome as to go up a level you must go up two or more levels then come back down.  Based on the below, in order to let's say add a cohort, I must go to the main admin menu, then select Users, then select Cohorts in the Permissions section instead of just clicking on Users. Yes, I could make bookmarks, but in a short time the number of bookmarks would become unmanageable and useless. Any suggestions would be helpful.  Theme modification, other than adding/removing blocks, is not currently in my wheelhouse and I do not have access to the php files anyway. Sorry for the long post.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Quiz results navigation
ResponsesInList.Text: This is a known issue with the boost theme, that it took a lot of feedback from users before Moodle HQ would accept was a bug. There is now MDL-58120 to discuss it. One small part ( MDL-57510 ) was improved for Moodle 3.3. Hopefully more to come.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Quiz results navigation
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks.  At least it is being looked into.

ResponsesInList.Title: Course Management Panel
ResponsesInList.Text: With looking at our move to Moodle 3.2 and Boost our teachers were feeling like there were sometimes too many clicks to do important things in their course.  They are also not a fan of the way the Course Administration links are laid out.  I listened to feedback and added a new method for them to access and interact with the Course Administration. We utilized the bootstrap collapse feature to show and hide a panel just above the main content of the page.  We placed a link there that toggles the new Course Management Panel. When the link is clicked it toggles the display of the menu which is broken down into the following groupings for Course Admin Links:  Badges, Question Bank, Course Settings, and User Links.  We believe these groupings will help teachers discover and access the links they need quickly and efficiently. We also hide the default action/edit cog as to avoid confusion of another place to access the same links when using the Course Management panel. We think this is a cleaner and simpler way to present all the course administration links to teachers.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course Management Panel
ResponsesInList.Text: Is that code available somewhere? mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course Management Panel
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes.  It's part of our Fordson theme.  Moodle 3.2 and 3.3 compatible versions. It uses mustache and is a Boost child theme. Here is a sandbox just upgraded to Moodle 3.3 Beta.  It also has our Easy Enrollment plugin which is in the works.  This plugin will streamline getting users from the homepage to enrolled in a course using 6 digit enrollment codes just like Edmodo or GClassroom.  Even does QR code enrollment. http://moodlesandbox.dearbornschools.org

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course Management Panel
ResponsesInList.Text: Today I added additional integration between our new Easy Enrollment plugin and our Fordson theme. This integration builds on the Course Management panel area by adding a link that shows the teacher all their 6 digit enrollment codes for their course. One click and they know how to get students into their course from the moodle homepage. This video explains the process of going from the homepage to enrolled in a course or group within the course. For k-12 we think these two items - Easy Enrollment and Fordson theme - are key to addressing some usability concerns in K-12.  The layout, navigation, and enrollment process to get students from the homepage to learning has been streamlined to be as efficient as possible.  We also made it very intuitive for teachers to discover and manage their enrollment codes.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course Management Panel
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Chris. The easy enrollment plugin, the Fordson Theme's innovative "Course Management tab" and their integration is a step forward in usability. I  like how it speeds up or lightens the teacher's administrative aspect of Moodle. Well done.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course Management Panel
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Frankie!  We've been working hard and taking a serious look at how we might facilitate better adoption within K-12.  I've posted this elsewhere, but you can now try it out: We put our Easy Enrollment plugin up on github and submitted it to the plugin directory.  Please check it out and let us know if you find any issues.  For the best experience use Fordson V1.4.4.  It has the best user experience with our easy enrollment plugin. Download Fordson: https://moodle.org/plugins/theme_fordson Download Easy Enrollment: https://github.com/dbnschools/moodle-enrol_easy The two plugins are designed to work in harmony.  We do not have any documentation on how to use Easy enrollment with other themes as you need to hack the homepage to display the Enrollment form and our intent is to have them made into a plugin set. Directions: Install Fordson version 1.4.4 Install Easy Enrollment.  On the settings page be sure to turn OFF QR Code if you do not have SSL on your server .  QR Reader requires SSL. Go to Plugins > Enrollment > Manage and turn on the Easy Enrollment plugin This will display the Easy enrollment form on the Site Home for Fordson. Go to your courses and add Easy Enrollment as one of the course enrollment methods.  You can also just add a new course and make sure easy enrollment is activated. On your Course page you should see "Enrollment Codes" button in the upper right area of the page for any course which has the easy enrollment method enabled. Copy an enrollment code and try having a student use it from the Site homepage enrollment form.  Once the code is entered into the form click the enroll button and you should be instantly taken to a course and enrolled as a student. Teachers can now give out these codes to students and they can "easily" enroll in the courses. We included the ability to set dates for enrollments so that a teacher can turn off the ability for more students to enroll if desired.  It is all on the enrollment codes  page inside the course.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course Management Panel
ResponsesInList.Text: Chris, I like this very much - it is definitely along the lines of our previous discussion about the course admin menus. Flat is better. My only suggestion here would be: 1) Add a separate column for Reports. Basically just flatten out the whole Reports tree. The more important reports I think are completion related, Activity and Course, as opposed to the course logs, and those are not there.  A flat report columns solves that. 2) Move Badges under Questions or vice versa to one column. Those both have a small and fixed number of options and it will save a lot of real estate and make room for the Reports one. Really nice work on Fordson. Love the direction you are taking it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course Management Panel
ResponsesInList.Text: Randy, Once again, you offer excellent advice.  Thank you.  I will ask  our team and see what they think and see if we can tweak it a bit to include mire direct links to reports if that seems more useful. Another idea I had was for "plugin detection" where if Fordson detects some of the more popular plugins for reports or attendance or things of this nature it would automatically display those links in course management. Just a thought.  I also don't want to make it overly complicated or cluttered.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course Management Panel
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Chris, I really like this information architecture improvement. Something similar from the Sussex University site back in 2011 or so Totally agree the edit drop down (and admin menu in other themes) needs clear section titles and actions grouped in a more user friendly way to reduce the clutter. Not sure how, but it would be great to get information architecture improvements into core. Nice work making moodle better for your users, Stuart

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course Management Panel
ResponsesInList.Text: I really like the way Moodle is going with some of the design, usability, and theme stuff.  Boost was exactly what we were looking for and some of the advancements in usability are really helping our teachers and students.  I've hated the navigation and administration blocks for many years!  I always wanted a single column with no real need for blocks unless it was content/learning related.  Boost delivered. It would appear you were ahead of the times with thinking of organizing the course links and a new dashboard page for course setup. In an ideal world if I had the coding skills to do so I would make these links and a few other items into a separate "Tab" on the coursepage which would be essentially what I have with other pertinent information for the teacher to track assignments and grading stuff.   This separation of management and learning materials makes sense.  The fact that the links are organized and visible all at once is also a win for teachers. This dream of separating the learning materials into one tab and management on another is why I switched up the layout of Fordson in the most recent versions.  I suspect at some point I might get the time to work on it and I wanted the theme to be ready with a design that might lend itself to utilizing tabs or a tab like structure.  In the meantime, I got some of the initial work done in developing the Course Management toggle.  And maybe this is as far as it needs to go at this point so that things can remain simple.

ResponsesInList.Title: Course view VS program view
ResponsesInList.Text: I've searched through the forums and didn't come up with anything on the topic.  I work for a medium-sized university and have often been asked how to make Moodle more "program oriented", as opposed to course centric.  I'm looking for ideas on how to make it more clear to teachers and students what programs they are enrolled in and simplify navigation between courses that make up a program (or several different programs...). Could this be done using a customized block that would be added to each course? Could this be done by customizing the "My" page so that, instead of showing a long list of individual course, it would show a program container/section, under which individual courses would be shown under it? Some users have used meta-courses to create "program home pages" and then enrol other courses into them, but that only adds another site to a user's "My" page and doesn't really help them know where to go. I'm interested to know what others are doing to address the issue.  Thanks.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course view VS program view
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Marc, Have you considered trying to use tags? Tags can be added to a course on it's setting page. Seems like a "program" tag could be added to each course of a "program". When someone clicks a program tag, they would then see a page listing all the courses with that same tag set. Also, many of the activities are getting tag capability in Moodle 3.3. Not sure if it would be practical, but might be worth testing. Also, there is already a tag block so it would be easy to test/try out and see if it would work.

ResponsesInList.Title: Live Assessments
ResponsesInList.Text: Greetings to all, I wanted to know if and how I can have instant feedback while conducting live training sessions.   I would present material, have each student log into our Moodle site, then take an assessment while sitting in class.  Then I would take the scores from the assessment to guide the next training sessions for a particular day.  I know other company's let you see live results (ex. WebX).  Any information is greatly appreciated. Sincerely, Jay

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Live Assessments
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes you can do this

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Live Assessments
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you again for the reply.  I figured I would present the material, stop at a certain point, have students log in, go to a specific link on our Moodle page, take the assessment, then I could see what the results were.  Does that seem like the logical steps I can take?  If not, what would you recommend (any guides are greatly appreciated)? Sincerely, Jay

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Live Assessments
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Jay, You can do exactly what you mentioned, and Moodle has a number of things you can use to "assess" with. If you pause during your presentation you can use Questionnaire, Feedback, online text Assignment, Active Quiz, Realtime quiz, Forum, or Workshop. One other that can be used while you pause, but can also be used during the presentation is the Hot Question plugin.

ResponsesInList.Title: Course Navigation
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi everyone, I couldn't find a topic that seemed to be directly about navigation, so I have created this new one. I basically just wanted to share a blog post I recently added on how less is more. I know we say it all the time, but do we really mean it, and do we fight for it when it comes to the crunch. It is so easy to say ok to many suggestions and keep adding features and handy links etc. but what is the compromise to usability ? I've done a mockup (which I actually created a while ago) that hopefully challenges what really needs to be on the course landing page, based on the less is more principle (also known as interference effects in psychology). I've inserted the first page, but do have a quick look at the rationale on the blog. This is very rough, but happy to hear thoughts about this mockup which also incorporates some pretty standard web navigation techniques used these days. Click here to go to the blog post. Thanks, Tara P.S. If anyone could somehow get 'Open in a new window' to be the default mode when creating a link in Moodle, I would be FOREVER grateful!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Course Navigation
ResponsesInList.Text: Also... this is a great article by one of my favourite designers... 12 Digital Product Design Principles

ResponsesInList.Title: Suggested usability improvements for myoverview block
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, We've been looking at the new myoverview block with interest - we really like the concept of the timeline of activities that has been introduced. We've looked into our database at our institution to pull out some statistics on course enrolment and course information and can foresee two usability issues with this new component: Users with many enrolments will struggle to find their courses and have no way to search, order or hide courses from display in the block Presently, when viewing your enrolled courses within the 'Courses' view, a user is able to see six enrolments per page and these are categorised by 'In progress', 'Future', 'Past'. For users with a large number of enrolments, navigation is incredibly manual - we suggest introducing filtering, searching and the ability to hide or mute a course from view Courses names are not always displayed well within the block and is especially problematic for long course names. We've found that the longest course name in our database is 210 characters in length. As the myoverview block displays the course fullname, the 210 character course is often cut-off or causes a lot of wasted space within the block: As such, we've lodged two tracker items: MDL-58579 - Allow searching / filtering of courses in myoverview MDL-58585 - Long course names are not display correct on myoverview block I am posting here to see whether there is any support in the community for these enhancements? Regards, Greg

ResponsesInList.Title: Seeking Volunteers for Moodle HQ Calendar Research Study
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Moodle users, Moodle HQ would like to invite  English-speaking Moodle users to sign up for research studies that will help us plan for future Moodle Calendar product development. Involvement in the research study means: You’ll spend approximately 15 to 30 minutes trying out a prototype and giving us feedback, or we might interview you about your current experience using Moodle. A Moodle HQ researcher will set up a remote screen-sharing session with you on your own computer. Sessions may take place outside of typical business hours depending on your local time zone. We’d like to hear from you if: You can participate in the sessions online using Google Hangouts (which involves sharing your desktop screen and audio) You have access to a microphone and a broadband internet connection You provide consent for Moodle HQ to record video and audio of your interactions using Moodle on your desktop screen. If you’re interested in participating, please sign up using the link below: https://calendly.com/moodle/calendar

ResponsesInList.Title: New K-12 Easy Enrollment when LDAP or External Database is not Used
ResponsesInList.Text: At K-12 we have a usability issue with getting our youngest and sometimes our oldest kids to the proper course with the proper enrollment key and finally, enrolled in a course.  We do not automate enrollments beyond LDAP authentication since teachers use Moodle for a variety of reasons which we don't want scripted. Sure you can use a CSV file but better be sure you have all your commas in order. We have long dreamed of having a simpler way of getting kids into courses where they do not have to browse or search 100's of courses.  Bigger sites create headaches for younger kids. We are in the process of developing a new enrollment plugin which mimics the functionality of Google Classroom and Edmodo.  It is almost 100% functional now but we are testing still.  It uses 6 digit codes that are entered on the homepage of Moodle and instantly enrolls the user into a corresponding course or group within the course.  It also functions independent of other enrollment plugins so you can utilize manual or even self enrollment if you desire.  This plugin ignores those enrollment keys and uses it's self generated codes. We believe this will greatly simplify getting kids from the homepage to the learning content. To take this one step further... we can even enroll students with a QR Code!!!!!! Video coming shortly as we just got this functionality working.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: New K-12 Easy Enrollment when LDAP or External Database is not Used
ResponsesInList.Text: QR Code Working:

ResponsesInList.Title: import groups
ResponsesInList.Text: I am trying to help a faculty member load a large amount of students to Moodle groups. I cannot figure out if or how to use the import groups feature in the groups tool. Upload users is NOT am option for us in our instance!!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: import groups
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Nancy, The import group feature is to import the groups themselves, not populate the students who are in those groups. If your group members are fairly randomly selected or selected based on alphabetic order and if the groups have not been set up yet and if you can use a group naming which is simple and sequential such as Group 1, Group 2, Group 3, etc. you can auto create your groups and have the system  assign so many users to each group. That is the only other way I know to drop your users into groups without using the upload users function.

ResponsesInList.Title: Number of years in date selection forms
ResponsesInList.Text: As a Moodle support person I've been a bit concerned about the number of years that now appear in the pop-up menu when someone needs to set a date for something. The default is from 1900 to 2050, which puts 150 options in the list. In most cases dates are set in the future, and as Moodle is used for teaching they are not set very far in the future. I'd suggest that in most cases no more than 5 years are needed in that list. Currently it seems that changing the default years involves changing the 'code' in .../moodle/calendar/type/gregorian/classes/structure.php, lines 81 to 97. Are there cases where such a large range of years is needed? Is there an easy way to change the default years, for those who can't access the code on their server ? If not, I'd like to propose adding the default dates to the config file, which I have tested out on a local Moodle server. Thanks

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Number of years in date selection forms
ResponsesInList.Text: Depends where that code is called (can't say I've looked into it). For example, what about peoples date of birth or history questions or date started at a company etc.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Number of years in date selection forms
ResponsesInList.Text: These days, it is controlled by get_min_year and get_max_year in calendar/type/gregorian/classes/structure.php . Not sure what else would be affected if you changed that. Since it defaults to the current year, normally you don't have to scroll far to find the year you want in the menu, but you can still pick dates a long way in the past or future.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Number of years in date selection forms
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Just H. Can you point to some exact pages in Moodle with examples? Thanks Mal.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Number of years in date selection forms
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Tim, It is a minor issue but the huge list is cumbersome, it shouldn't be if it's not necessary. I can see this particular date selection form in several settings pages for Assignments, Quizzes etc. In all those places only a small number of years is needed. Know of any other places? In the Admin pages, we can add a date field to the user profile. In that case the min and max years can be selected from a list (drawn from the default min_year and max_year). So we can assume the date form function can respond to local variables as well as the default ones. So seems to be variuos possibilities for setting these years? Mal.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Website Administration - different languages?
ResponsesInList.Text: Ok, two issues here.... Not sure about the second - which in truth is completely separate from the thread title and should be posted on an appropriate forum. The first depends on if the points with the language issue are a contributed plugin or core.  If the former then you'll need to contact the developer to ask about M3.2 support via AMOS for the plugin.  If core then go straight to reading: https://docs.moodle.org/dev/index.php?title=AMOS_manual&redirect=no .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Website Administration - different languages?
ResponsesInList.Text: Solved it. Uninstalled language pack, reinstalled it and reloaded it. Works. Thanks.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Website Administration - different languages?
ResponsesInList.Text: Updating language packs is also possible if you manually run cron.php on your site. Saves you the trouble of uninstalling/installing.

ResponsesInList.Title: Adding activities to a page - what do you think?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Does anyone else think it would be great to be able to easily add an activity to a Moodle resource page? If you copy and paste the links from any section into a page they work and look like activities , although they are just hyperlinks to activities in a topic or orphaned section. I realise this is the same as manually creating links to activities elsewhere. This might look like this, i.e. it looks like a topic section but it is a page with activity links on it: I believe allowing "add activity or resource" on a resource page would be a powerful way of allowing activities to be nested or tucked away into pages and would be a simple but valuable improvement to Moodle that would improve usability further. So a page would look like this mock up (note: Add activity link): We (i.e. our tutors) really liked Sam Marshall's (OU) subpage plugin ( see here ) , however this is a non-standard additional feature that is being phased out and therefore one we are having to stop using and won't be able to make use of in the future. This allows subpages with activities to be created, although these are separate to standard resource pages. I would welcome any thoughts, ideas, alternatives or pointers to anything that may already exist and comments on the feasibility of this suggestion. All the best & Happy Moodling, Jim

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding activities to a page - what do you think?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Jim, I could definitely see use cases for this, we currently use the "show one topic at a time" to get some kind of sub pages within our courses. My only thoughts about potential issues ATM are about distinguishing between a page with resources / activities and those without. Jon

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding activities to a page - what do you think?
ResponsesInList.Text: The Flexible sections course format does a similar sort of thing - well not quite - but it allows for grouping together items within a link.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding activities to a page - what do you think?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Mary, Thanks for your suggestion. We are exploring other course formats and have looked at and experimented with the Flexible sections format and this may be useful for some scenarios but isn't quite what we're looking for here. We make quite a lot of use of the collapsed topic format and grid format and the flexible sections format can't be used with those, as it is one format or the other. Being able to add activities and content to pages (or "subpages") would provide a neat way of nesting content so that a topic section wouldn't need to take up too much space on the screen. See what others think? All the best Jim

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding activities to a page - what do you think?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Jon, Thanks for your support and comment - I suppose the page title might help to guide the user (e.g. "Section 3 activities") but I take your point, as you might expect a different icon. All the best, Jim

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding activities to a page - what do you think?
ResponsesInList.Text: I agree with you Jim, we are in the same situation. We are mainly using the collapsed topic format, and some of the courses have gone so big that we need to find a way to better organised the courses to improve learners' navigation, improve teachers's experience when editing the course and also loading time of the courses. We have are using the 'subpage' module but as you said it  is a non standard feature... . Any suggestions welcome! Merci Annick

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding activities to a page - what do you think?
ResponsesInList.Text: It seems obvious, it seems too simple - but does anyone know why activities can't be added to Moodle pages (i.e. resource pages) and perhaps how much of a change or how much development would be needed to develop this feature? Thanks Jim

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding activities to a page - what do you think?
ResponsesInList.Text: I wish we could do that. I also wish we could add activities in a Label. If you could do either one, then using various Generico filters you could convert a long "scroll of death" course down to practically nothing, just a few accordion levels, tabs or buttons that would expand or collapse with a click. Of course you can already do this with just content, whether it is text, pictures, audio, or video. Just cannot put the actual activities in with the content.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding activities to a page - what do you think?
ResponsesInList.Text: Please vote for this really useful feature here: https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-13908

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding activities to a page - what do you think?
ResponsesInList.Text: Nothing new here... but I've always loved using Orphaned categories as you mentioned to achieve some type of organization.  In our Cyber Library, we organize all the content into 6 categories using the Grid Format (so only 6 visible topics). However, within the 6 categories are buttons in the form of image icons that are hot-linked to orphaned Toipcs, (where all the content is actually housed). It's been working great for us. So initially it only looks like there are 6 Topics in the course, but each topic links to other orphaned topics. Almost like having the Grid Format with in the Grid Format  :D  now that would be a neat plugin! ---> --> One problem with this is if it's nested too deeply, then what you end up with is a Choose Your Own Adventure situation where your users may not naturally be navigating to all the content in any type of sequence... i guess it all depends on what one is trying to achieve.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding activities to a page - what do you think?
ResponsesInList.Text: I've thought of this problem a little differently: how to have inside section navigation .  The scroll of death occurs at the section level. My current version of this is simply using Bootstrap tabs, as above.  You then have 1) section to section navigation down the course menu and 2) inside sections navigation via the Bootstrap tabs, there are downsides to this. But it is the quickest and simplest I can come up with at the moment. Jim, this may not work with your staff if they have lots of 'activities'.  How I cope with this is I put only one forum per course (generally) and the tasks are set up where I say "Week 3 post: reflection" in the tab, and they just go to the forum and do the post. If I need to point to a tab I say "go to Major assignment > Teach".  There are ways to get inter tab navigation, but I have not had time to sort this. Notes: Ideally I'd like sections down the side, and subsections navigation along the top .  This is not a complex solution, just requiring coding (which takes $$) one reference "specifiy which sections are inside a section" notes here: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=341983 and here: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=316278 The solution will be for a plugin or a format. (I'm not sure if core Moodle is interested in this issue, at least I have seen no evidence of this) There are complex solutions with accordions etc, but most of them are not responsive and don't meet my needs. (ie Simple inside section navigation) (insert here the various formats: xxx      none of them really work well, but I am open to push back on this view) I don't like Moodle pages .  Once you click on a page, you loose all the navigation except the breadcrumbs.  There are subpage options that you have found.  The click to go somewhere, then click to come back is such an old school navigation. Snap has some of this built in but is now 2 versions behind on the plugin database John, orphaned categories, yes, but so complex and wearying!! My 2c -Derek

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding activities to a page - what do you think?
ResponsesInList.Text: An idea I have had is to enhance Collapsed Topics/Weeks so it recognizes indent levels and adds CSS show/hide controls at each indent level, like typical tree navigation. I have never figured out how to do it, though. Flexible Sections requires the instructor to collapse/expand topics, rather than letting the student do it, and also modifies course data when switching to and from the course format.

ResponsesInList.Title: Error in PHP - Unsure what to do
ResponsesInList.Text: Good morning. I'm using Moodle 1.9 and getting an error. Here's what I am trying to do. When I click Include a Topic Section in Front Page settings and go back to the home page, I get this error message: Fatal error : Call to undefined function iscomplete() in /home/seamensc/public_html/course/lib.php on line 1442 I've attached the PHP script file. I'm not sure where the error is. On another site, the code is the exact same and I don't get the error. Anyone had this issue before? Can someone help me figure out what the issue is?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Error in PHP - Unsure what to do
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Lisa - This question really doesn't have anything to do with usability . This was probably a better question for the "General help" discussion. In any case, Moodle 1.9 has been out of support since July 2012 . It will be difficult getting help with it any more. Looking at the file and line you have mentioned in the code repository , there is no "iscomplete()" function call. I searched that entire file and could not find an occurrence of that call anywhere. I also did a search of the entire 1.9 codebase and could not find any occurrence of the "iscomplete" function. My guess is that you have made customizations in your code. And somehow you have lost some of those customizations. If you have another site with the same code at that line number, and it is working, then it must still have the customizations you need. Looking at the attachment you provided, the file has definitely been customized. It looks like it has the old "Activity locking" hack added to it (probably this - https://docs.moodle.org/32/en/Development:Activity_Locking#Table_of_Versions ). The function that hack provided has been part of Moodle since some version in Moodle 2. It would be best if you upgraded to a the latest (3.2). Hope this helps.

ResponsesInList.Title: Partial Matching When Searching for Users to Enrol
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I'm a moodle administrator of an university in Japan. Thanks for welcoming in this forum. I have a question about manual enrolment. When searching for users to enrol, search engine of manual enrolment find exact string match or begins-with match, right? It doesn't find partial matches I guess. Is there any possibility that it can find partial matches? ex) When searching for users to enrol, if I search for "moodle" then I should be able to find "moodle" in the result. But in case I search for "odle" then also I should be able to find "moodle". Some faculty staff members inquired me on the topic above. They want to make partial matches possible. If you have any idea to make it possible, could you please tell me the way? Best regards,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Partial Matching When Searching for Users to Enrol
ResponsesInList.Text: I could solve this question by editing /enroll/manual/ ajax .php like this... $searchanywhere = get_user_preferences('userselector_searchanywhere', false); ↓ $searchanywhere = true; After editing and purging all caches, search engine of manual enrolment is able to find partial matches. Thanks,

ResponsesInList.Title: Badges Expiring Notification
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello All, I love Moodle and I do love the badge function. However, our training department does training that need to be repeated every 2 years. For example the CPR and First Aid class is held every week of the year. Students are required to take this course every 2 years. I thought the best solution was to award a badge that expires after two years. It works great but there is no functionality to send out periodic emails when the badge gets close to expiring. Is there a way to do this? If i had to develop this myself where would be the best place to start? Thank in advance, Casey

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Badges Expiring Notification
ResponsesInList.Text: Nobody wants to take a crack at this?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Badges Expiring Notification
ResponsesInList.Text: I had the same question and how I do it is rather than making the badge to expire, to date them. For example, somebody who passes the test for 2015 gets a badge "Yellow Belt 2015". That way the students are clear on the fact that the certification is limited in time, but they do keep the badge on their "wall of honor". I compare it to the scouts that collect badges on their shirt for all the years they are in the organisation. If they go on camp or to a jamboree, they sow that badge on, and it remains visibile.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Badges Expiring Notification
ResponsesInList.Text: We're looking at something similar Casey - did you find / develop a solution in the end (reminders when a qualification is due to expire)? Thanks,  BJ

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Badges Expiring Notification
ResponsesInList.Text: Take a look at the Reengagment plugin: https://moodle.org/plugins/mod_reengagement

ResponsesInList.Title: 3.1 After One Quarter of Use (Grades/Assignment tool).....
ResponsesInList.Text: We installed 3.1 before our Fall quarter. I feel that 3.1 is a good system and it has many wonderful updates. I have noticed a pattern of email, phone and in-person questions and comments about the new Gradebook (we had 2.7 before) and the new Assignment Grading tool. I am not sure who or how to share these comments besides in here. If there is a better place, please let me know. Gradebook 1) The Weight collumn doesn't have a total. Our faculty are confused that they don't see 100% at the bottom of the Weights column. It is making them question the weighting calculations. 2) when you weight, if you don't type in a value that equals 100%...the sysem will change the numbers to make it 100%. It would be nice if a message appeared or an error saying that their values don't equal 100 so they only need to change one or two weights. Now they would need to change most or all since Moodle changed them to make it 100. Assignment Grading Tool I like this tool, but I am seeing some issues that faculty are not liking... Issues / Comments more clicking sometimes when in the tool, the next arrow link will not work, freeze requiring the instructor to get out and back into the assignment each grade requires a save button click and the next button. The tool is a little slow and take time. 1) The View all submission button takes them to a page that will not allow instructors to enter grades. Instructors want to be able to enter a "quick" point value on this page. The other option is to go to the Grades > Single view and "override" all to type in the grades, but the "override" freaks them out. I hope this information is helpful. Tonia Malone, Cal Poly - SLO

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: 3.1 After One Quarter of Use (Grades/Assignment tool).....
ResponsesInList.Text: Tonia, For point #1 under Assignment Grading Tool: There should be a "quick grading" option at the bottom of the page that results from clicking "View all submissions": Checking "Quick grading" will provide a grade-entry box in the Grade column for each student (along with a feedback entry box a little further to the right): Quick grading won't work with Advanced grading methods (Rubric, marking guide). Here is the section in Moodle Docs : https://docs.moodle.org/31/en/Using_Assignment#Quick_grading I can't speak to the weighting issues, but I hope your instructors can use the quick-grading feature! David

ResponsesInList.Title: Participate In Moodle Usability Testing (Round 2)
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Moodle users, Thank you for participating in our prior usability test. Your valuable feedback provided the UX team at Moodle HQ with some great insights into how you navigate within a Moodle site. We are continuing with our usability testing and would love your help again. Seeking Volunteers for Moderated Usability Testing In addition to the research activity below, we are also seeking English speaking community forum members to sign up for future moderated usability test sessions. These sessions will be moderated by a member of the Moodle HQ User Experience team and will take approximately 15 to 30 minutes to complete. Times and dates for the sessions will be communicated at least one week beforehand. We’d like to hear from you if you are able to: Participate in the sessions online using Google Hangouts (which involves sharing your desktop screen and audio) Have access to a microphone and a broadband internet connection Provide consent for Moodle HQ to record video and audio of your interactions using Moodle on your desktop screen If you’re interested in participating to make Moodle better for all users please fill out the form below and we’ll reach out to you soon. Link: https://goo.gl/forms/XF3VAQqpIyzLh6jG2 Feedback on how you use Moodle We’re looking for volunteers to participate in a simple research activity to gain insight on how you use Moodle. To provide feedback, we have organised a short survey and a card sorting activity, which together, should take about 5 - 10 minutes to complete. The survey and card sorting activity will close UTC 27th of October 2016 16:00. Please click the link below to get started. Thank you in advance for your assistance. Link: https://moodle.optimalworkshop.com/optimalsort/03ki4055-0-0 Cheers Al

ResponsesInList.Title: Show question type icons in the quiz manual grading overview
ResponsesInList.Text:
Description: In the list of questions of the quiz manual
grading the question number (Q#) and the question name is displayed. It
would be very useful if the question type icon would be displayed, too. This would facilitate finding certain questions especially when
manual grading is used for many questions and different question types
(essay, file upload , short answer, numerical ,...). Usecase: We use this when grading summative examinations where we don't want students to loose points for typos or grammatical errors in short answer questions. We also use it for calculated, simple calculated and numerical questions where a wrong decimal separator (comma for english language or point for german language) leads to zero points - although the student gave the right answer. Feature request: There is a feature request regarding this on Moodle Tracker : MDL-53814 Vote, comment, conribute: If you feel this is a helpful feature please vote. If you have further suggestions or an even better solution how to facilitate finding the right question, please comment. And of course it would be greate if someone could come up with a code solution!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Show question type icons in the quiz manual grading overview
ResponsesInList.Text: Paul, I've just submitted a solution.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Show question type icons in the quiz manual grading overview
ResponsesInList.Text: The second usecase - giving points to students who entered the correct value with the wrong decimal separator in calculated, simple calculated and numerical questions - is no longer an issue. This is fixed at least since Moodle 3.0.4. However, there is another usecase where this feature would be helpful. There are question types (e.g. qtype_kprime) where students have to select options as in multiple choice questions. Even if teachers try hard to create unequivocal and unambiguous options, they sometimes only realize after the exam that an option specified as wrong in certain cases might be correct. To be able to give points to those students who selected this option, manual grading is needed.
