ResponsesInList.Title: Social Media links in profiles
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, When looking at the Optional fields in the user profile, I can't help but think that they look a bit last century.  With the exception of Skype, the rest are things that I haven't used in years (or ever!) and have never seen being used by a user. Wouldn't it be more appropriate to have a social media category including, for example, Facebook, Twitter, Google+, LinkedIn et al?  These are portals that are actually used by the majority of course participants nowadays. Yes, I know it's possible to put them in by hand, but I really think they should be available by default.  It would at least look a bit more up to date than ICQ, AIM and Yahoo.  I also can't imagine this would be hard or costly to implement. Interested to know what other people think. Andy

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Social Media links in profiles
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Andy, I agree that some of those labels are a little out of date, but have you considered changing them to something else via Language customization? Going this route would make them available for you right now, without having to wait for Moodle to change them, plus, changes via Language customization, as would adding new fields by  hand, will still be there after each Moodle update you make.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Social Media links in profiles
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Al, Of course you're right, and I've already created new fields, but that's not the point I'm making here. I simply believe it's time this section should be updated. The current fields are a throwback to another era and they simply make Moodle look outdated. Changing it is just keeping up with current standards. Moodle should reflect current practices as a default, and not rely on individual admins to implement this. Just my opinion, Andy

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Social Media links in profiles
ResponsesInList.Text: Touché to that Andy. I was in assumption they have been updated already. I even wonder if AIM and ICQ are still in use

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Social Media links in profiles
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Andy, Don't get me wrong as I agree with you, but I also see the point of keeping them as is. If someone is using them, and you go and change the next Moodle version to not include them, then you are going to break Moodle for some people.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Social Media links in profiles
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Al, Absolutely.  The new fields would need to be additions rather than replacements.  I'd suggest having a category, "Social Media" where all such fields could be placed.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Social Media links in profiles
ResponsesInList.Text: Maybe just need your Generico icons.txt file you recently posted, converted to a block. Or, see about getting Ankit Agarwal to add the other social media links to his Facebook comments block.

ResponsesInList.Title: Goto button on quiz review page
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello all, I created a survey on my moodle site. One feature that many users requested was a goto button on the quiz review page. They wanted a direct link to the next piece of content after the quiz in the course. Is this feature possible in moodle 3.1 ? Regards Gary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Goto button on quiz review page
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Gary, There are a couple of ways you can provide this, one just using current Moodle capability and one using a Generico filter. 1. The easiest to do, using current Moodle capability, is to just add an HTML link to the next activity, into each grade band of the Overall Feedback. 2. If you have the Generico filter installed, you can add a button similar to the Gradient Toggle, with HTML link to the next activity, also in each grade band of the Overall Feedback. Here is an example showing both:

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Goto button on quiz review page
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Al, Thanks for the prompt reply. I was considering the html link in the overall feedback or a simple form enclosing a button so its good to hear that you suggest that too. I did not know about the Generico filter though, so thank you for bringing it to my attention. Thanks again for your reply.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Goto button on quiz review page
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Gary, If you do decide to go the Generico filter route, you might also like to try out a random feedback filter that can be used in the overall feedback too. I have three of them, one for perfect scores, high praise, and moderate praise. Each, if triggered, will give one out of ten possible feedbacks into which ever grade band you set it up for. Plus, it's simple to come up with more.

ResponsesInList.Title: How do I make an automated functionality that keeps track of the last page I read in a course?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hallo, When a student logins into the online learning website, he/she wants to jump from the homepage immediately to the last page of a lesson he was reading in a particular course. Is there a feature in Moodle that keeps track of where someone left off, the previous time he logged out? How do I create an automated hyperlink-bookmark in Moodle of the last page I was studying in a lesson of a course? Can this functionality be available for every student that follows a course? Friendly Regards, Rolf Moodle 3.0

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How do I make an automated functionality that keeps track of the last page I read in a course?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Rolf, There is a Bookmark block plugin based off the Admin bookmark block, but unfortunately it is listed as being for Moodle 2.5 and lower. The maintainer does have a version for 2.7 on his github, but he has not released it or done any further development. Having said that, I do have the version for 2.7 running on Moodle 3.1.1+. It has a bunch (6) of missing language strings noticeable only when you check permissions, but otherwise does seem to work okay for admin, teachers, managers, and students. I usually fix those kinds of problems for myself, but haven't bothered to for this plugin, yet. I have one copy of the block installed on my Moodle front page , and have it configured to show on Any page, of my site. This makes it always available for everyone. Everyone can add or remove bookmarks, only for themselves, and the bookmarks they see are ones only they added.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How do I make an automated functionality that keeps track of the last page I read in a course?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hallo Al, Thank you for pointing me to the User_Bookmarks plug-in. I installed version 2.5 and it works quite nice, though the icons disappear when you hover with the mouse over a bookmark (in Windows Edge web-browser). I saw v.2.7 in the GIT hub, but I cannot find a way to download all files as a ZIP. How do I download the latest GIT version of the User_Bookmarks plug-in for standard installation in Moodle? Furthermore I found another kind of Bookmark plug-in in Moodle repository: Bookmarks (within book chapter) for Moodle v.2.8. I installed this too, but the installation crashed on a nasty error, which blocked all my Admin navigation possibilities. This plug-in needed an accessibility-subfolder (with certain files?) in the block-folder. I guess this is an obsolete function. So eventually, I found a way to deinstall and delete all traces of this plug-in. Friendly regards, Rolf Moodle 3.0 on WIMP

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How do I make an automated functionality that keeps track of the last page I read in a course?
ResponsesInList.Text: Remember to rename the zip when you upload to Moodle.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How do I make an automated functionality that keeps track of the last page I read in a course?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Rolf, There is no need to install that second Bookmark (within book chapter) as the User Bookmark block will let you create a bookmark to any place in a Moodle Book resource. As for the 2.7 github download, when you first go to the Source control URL , up and over to the right should be a button labeled, Clone or download. When you click it,  select download ZIP. When you extract everything in the Zip file, drill in until you see the folder named, user_bookmarks. It is that folder and it's contents that you need to replace the the version you already installed. If you care to wait until later today, I can give you a copy that includes the missing language strings. I also plan to change a couple of the original strings to make the wording "fit" better.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How do I make an automated functionality that keeps track of the last page I read in a course?
ResponsesInList.Text: I have an updated version that should work for Moodle 2.4 through Moodle 3.1.1+ that has the missing language strings. You can get it at: https://github.com/drachels/moodle-user_bookmarks Since the file is so small, I have included a zip file that if your installing from scratch, you can just drop it into the install plugins. If you are upgrading, you'll need to unzip and place the files in the correct location. As mentioned before, for the most versatile use of this plugin, install just one copy on the front page, then set it to show on Any page of the site. I also like to set it to always be on the top left for convenience.

ResponsesInList.Title: Participate In Moodle Usability Testing
ResponsesInList.Text: My name is Alberto and I’m the lead User Experience Designer at Moodle. I am based at the Moodle HQ in Perth, Western Australia. At Moodle, we want to empower our users to build the perfect education solution to fit your needs. At its core, Moodle will always be a highly tailored and configurable education platform that educators can deploy to create unique and amazing learning experiences. A number of users have been telling us that Moodle can be a little daunting and challenging to use. The team at Moodle have made it a goal to make Moodle an easy, intuitive but still powerful experience for all our users. We need your help and feedback to achieve this goal. Moodle Navigation Moodle’s default navigation experience has essentially been unchanged since Moodle’s first release more than a decade ago. We’d love your help to coordinate and navigate the content of Moodle for future releases by participating in a short survey and simple activity below. This activity shouldn't take you longer than 10 to 15 minutes to complete. Click the link below to get started. https://moodle.optimalworkshop.com/treejack/53bhb07w

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Participate In Moodle Usability Testing
ResponsesInList.Text: Just completed it, I like way it's set up to use a nav tree to find the options, makes it a pretty realistic experience. However I found a couple of questions didn't have enough info to really point me to where I should go. e.g. the one I remember best was the question on the calendar didn't say which course's calendar was to be changed. I guess it reflects reality when I couldn't find what I thought was the right place and just gave up and pick the closest thing I'd found, but it might also be skewing the results if that wasn't the intended effect (meaning the question becomes invalid).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Participate In Moodle Usability Testing
ResponsesInList.Text: One of the aspects of Moodle that has been frustrating in my support of faculty is the inconsistent behavior of the software's response to interaction. In some instances, you have to click "Save" in order for changes to take, in others, you don't. For example, in the gradebook, when you select assignments in order to move them into a category, you need only to choose the category you want to move them to in the "Choose..." list and it responds automatically with no "Save" or similar action required to initiate the action. Same goes for manual grades in the gradebook. You can click into the grid of students and change grades, but no "Save" is needed. Yet with other tasks related to course or assignment editing, a Save trigger is required. Make up your mind one way or the other. Otherwise we have to explain that certain procedures have an exception in the steps compared to other processes. Feature-related: If there was a way to do front-end editing for content text that would save us TONS of time instead of having to click through Edit links. If Labels had an option to prevent anyone but course designers to edit them, that would save a TON of time undoing the edits instructors make in places where they shouldn't be editing. Some faculty use a discussion forum for 1-to-1 private interaction with students. However, it setting these up takes a lot of time to manually edit the group names to match student names. Seems like there should be a better solution for this kind of interaction either in naming groups by student name or creating a new Forum type for this special need. Forums need to be graded with rubrics like submission assignments. This is a high priority for us.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Participate In Moodle Usability Testing
ResponsesInList.Text: I did get close to getting advanced grading(rubrics) in forums completed - the patch is still around and could be revived if someone was able to fund the work to complete it...( MDL-31860 )

José de Jesús.

ResponsesInList.Title: Alternative text WGAG
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi All, We've discovered an issue on our site as we were conducting an accessibility audit. the alt= tag does not seem to work when you add an image and provide a description. This has been confirmed by our provider who are just as puzzled as we are. Out moodle version is Moodle 2.6.2+ (Build: 20140424) After a bit of trouble shooting, I changed the code to title= and the description showed when you hover over the image. As it is important for us to be compliant, I am concerned that using this workaround is not suitable. 1. Is using title= ok? It does cause more work! 2. Why wouldn't the alt= be working as it should? Many thanks! Jamie

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Alternative text WGAG
ResponsesInList.Text: alt="..." is working exactly as it should. alt is short for 'altenative'. The text is there for people who cannot see the image. alt is nothing to do with tool-tips. title="" is for tool-tips, which are not very helpful for accessibility.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Alternative text WGAG
ResponsesInList.Text: Good Afternoon, I am having the same issue with the ALT tags not becoming visible on mouse roll over. I have checked and they are present however even the ALT tags embedded in the SCORM packages are not showing up. I have tried in Chrome, Firefox , Opera and IE but am running out of ideas. I know you have said the tags are working as they should, is there a setting on Moodle that may not be activated? Any information would be fantastic. With Hopes, Leticia

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Alternative text WGAG
ResponsesInList.Text: Alt tag is not the same as a tool tip. If you want a tool tip, use the title="" attribute.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Alternative text WGAG

ResponsesInList.Title: Help on Usability Test Development
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Moodle Community, Me and my partner are College Students majoring BS-Information Technology at Mindanao State University - Iligan Institute of Technology in the Philippines. We are doing an Undergrad Study on a Usability Analysis of our school's Online Learning Environment, MOLE which uses moodle as it's core and the Essentials theme . MOLE was created to be the primary e-learning tool for our university website however it is underused due to it's being intimidating, confusing and inefficient (we did a preliminary survey for this) for most students and teachers which is why they prefer using Edmodo or Google Classroom. As such, with our usability study, we wish to shed light on its lapses. Target for our study are both Teachers and Students as new MOLE users I am a complete novice to moodle, I am not familiar with it's functionalities nor with it's features. So I thought it would be a good idea to ask for help from you guys. Especially those who are familiar with usability tests and/or have done some themselves, as well as being experienced in using the Essentials Theme. We would like to ask for help in creating the tasks that would be make this Usability Test successful, as well as all and any reference materials you guys could redirect me to research on. The current goal of our study are as follows. To gain insight on MOLE and/or Moodle features. To conduct a usability test and identify areas that lead to user intimidation, complication and confusion To establish and recommend a list of changes for the improvement of the current usability of the MOLE. Now we have been reading the moodle usability documentation page, as well as the reference links there, along with other journals I found in google scholar and proquest. Though from our readings we have more unecessary questions than we would care to admit (ex. is moodle a LMS or LCMS or an online leaning environment?) so your feedback would be most helpful in directing us to the right tract. Also I have watched and read about the development of moodle 3.2. Their discussions regarding the design direction they should take moodle on have also been good reference materials. So, when this Usability study is finished, we plan on posting it here. Hopefully it will be an asset to the moodle community. I will be posting an .rar file containing screenshots of MOLE for those interested. Here is also our unviersity website. https://www.msuiit.edu.ph/

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Help on Usability Test Development
ResponsesInList.Text: 'Essential' theme!

ResponsesInList.Title: View as group/grouping
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, Just a thought and maybe one that isn't worth that much attention, but I was wondering whether anyone else saw a possible benefit (assuming it's possible) to being able to log in as a generic group or grouping member. I am using groups and groupings and have had occasions where students weren't able to log in as I thought they would. I try to be careful to log in as one of the students in each group or grouping to see what they can see, but I obviously have missed things. Besides, I need to log out and in again each time. Changing my role to student doesn't show me which groupings are set. Having said that, the information provided for the teacher view is getting better all the time, with the lines added for activities saying which group or grouping you need to be a member of in order to see them. The ability to hide activities so only particular group/ings can see them is really useful, too. Also, this way also leads to featuritis, I suppose. Also, today's class went pretty will with everything working the way I expected it to. I had students sign up for particular groups which then made URLs for three links I wanted to jigsaw to appear to only the students I wanted it to. It went without a hitch this time, but that wasn't the case for another class I tried to set up. I think I overdid it with limitations set to particular groupings and to particular time frames. Which reminds me that the settings regarding availability wouldn't be easy to simulate logging in as. Hmmm. Just wondering. Probably I'm just missing something obvious, which would be good to know. Steve

If anyone having  a real hand on the tracker can see to this, I think many would benefit Cheers

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: View as group/grouping

Lately, I have been using two separate computers (not just two screens) in order to check my progress. With reference to the dates on these messages, I guess this is not all that much of a problem for others,....  (:

ResponsesInList.Title: Points for enrolling in a course
ResponsesInList.Text: We are using Moodle v3.1 and want to know if there is a way (via core Moodle or plugins) to assign and accumulate points for a student based on enrollment. ResponsesInList.Title: Longevity of HTML (& Adobe Captivate)
ResponsesInList.Text: I have a client who is hesitant to use Adobe Captivate with HTML inserted in Moodle because of concerns from an IT expert of the possibility of Moodle or Adobe doing an update that will render the work done in captivate unusable with Moodle. The project is a big investment but for what we want, Captivate would make the whole thing look more professional than using the native Moodle tools for question creation, formatting, etc. Does anyone have any experience, sources, experts or articles that may shed light on the long-term usability of Moodle with Captivate and if there is any basis of these concerns of HTML5 not functioning in the near future?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Longevity of HTML5 (& Adobe Captivate)
ResponsesInList.Text: I'd be asking this IT "expert" to clarify his or her concerns. (I assume the title of the thread should be HTML5 not just HTML?) No one can predict the future, especially advances in technology, with absolute certainty but the reality is: HTML5 is likely to be around for a fairly long time given the uptake of mobile computing it is silly not to develop responsive assets Captivate can be published as SCORM or xAPI (which is likely to be around for a long time) the whole idea of specifications like SCORM and xAPI is to be platform agnostic therefore, Moodle isn't really a factor other than if it decided to completely ignore such specifications (which would be a fatal flaw and not even likely) in which case you would ditch Moodle not the package developed in Captivate. So again, I'd be asking on what basis an "expert" would be raising such concerns and what the suggested alternative is. Technology will always keep changing, I don't expect to be able to open a document produced in Pagemaker 1 in InDesign CC without issues ... does that mean I should never have used Pagemaker back in the day? ----- BTW , the above is not an endorsement for using Captivate

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Longevity of HTML5 (& Adobe Captivate)
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks a lot for your response. I was thinking the same way. I would understand if it was for Flash which has a ton of death threats on its existence but HTML is supposed to be the go to for the future of the Internet... Of course Captivate will change and update but as long as you keep the same edition and don't go backwards, it shouldn't be a problem to edit or add to Moodle.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Longevity of HTML5 (& Adobe Captivate)
ResponsesInList.Text: No worries, reading between the lines of my initial post you may have picked up I've had run ins before with so called experts which tend to get my back up First up, and please don't take this the wrong way, with the matter in hand when speaking to your expert or others please be specific; there is a difference between talking about "HTML" and "HTML5".  In my experience "experts" try to score points on any small ambiguities. HTML has been around for around 25 years, the numbers after it (e.g. HTML5) basically indicate standards the version complies with. Although people had been using components of HTML5 for a few years prior, between HTML4 and the new standard HTML5 being recommended by W3C was a 15 year gap. The standards for HTML5 where only finalised in 2014 so whenever the next version will be standardised is anyone's guess but I'd wager on it being years rather than months. A Google search will bring up plenty of hits stating HTML5 is the future; not many (if any) will say you're wrong to use it. To reiterate, Moodle is basically irrelevant to your issue. What you develop in Captivate is platform agnostic, to not publish a cross-platform learning object (which is where your reference to HTML5 comes in) from Captivate at this time based on doubts re "the longevity of HTML5" is illogical IMHO . If , and that is a ridiculous "if", HTML5 died tomorrow, simply open the project in Captivate and republish to another option; there's plenty of them (see here for example). I really would love to hear what alternatives this expert is putting forward, as I said in the original reply I'm not endorsing Captivate (it's just one tool of many) but I don't see what the issue with HTML5 could possibly be. Sounds to me his/her issue is using Captivate more than anything else.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Longevity of HTML5 (& Adobe Captivate)
ResponsesInList.Text: I agree... Unfortunately that was from the start. HTML5 is definitely being put advertised as the future all over the place. I think his problem is with Captivate. He doesn't trust Adobe to support itself and while I agree that they love to change very small things and not make things backward compatible, it's not exactly the same as the HTML code it creates not being able to run on the internet. I also use Storyline among other visual HTML authoring programs but that's just another thing for him to disagree with. I'm going to try again once more to convince them not to throw away something easy and very good looking because it might die in the next 25 years... believe it or not I almost put "expert" in quotations! His experience is more of web programming, and Moodle and Captivate are new concepts for him. He knows a lot and is doing this mostly out of concern for the investment but I suppose I will have to do a module, time it, and calculate the cost vs the longevity of the language. At least if they see that it will break even after 3 years or so, they won't be so hesitant to make the investment. I can foresee the next argument being HTML6 will force us to do it all over again. Anyway thanks for the advice.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Longevity of HTML5 (& Adobe Captivate)
ResponsesInList.Text: I was editing my post when you replied (adding a bit about "if" HTML5 died tomorrow with a link to the various publishing options). I have no doubt he has a wealth of knowledge in certain areas but I think we've gotten to the nub of the issue which as I suspected is basically "fear" of new technology. We have a new instructional designer here who refuses to use Captivate which is down to being conversant with Storyline rather than thinking of the end user ("Storyline is easier to use"; this to me does not negate the fact it still doesn't do responsive at this time therefore has a negative impact on the end user IMHO) . Good luck working through this little hurdle.

ResponsesInList.Title: Duplicating tabs in Onetopic format
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi! Is there a way to duplicate a tab in Onetopic format so that I don't have to recreate similar pages one piece at a time? Right now, in order to duplicate pages, I change the course format to Weekly format, duplicate each piece, and then drag them down to the new page. Or, is there a way to import information from one tab to another within the same course, or can one import info only from one course to a separate one?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Duplicating tabs in Onetopic format
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi... In Onetopic format, you have the "Duplicate current topic" functionality. It is available in "Tabs edition utilities" section (bottom of the topic) when you enable edition in a course. Saludos

ResponsesInList.Title: Discussion about the Usability of the new grading interface
ResponsesInList.Text: There is an interesting discussion about the usability of the Moodle 3.1 grading interface going on int he Assignment forum. https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=333583

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Discussion about the Usability of the new grading interface
ResponsesInList.Text: It's definitely been an issue brought up by our faculty. The 3.1.1 fix for the panels was helpful, but, part of the issue is with the auto-pdf generator. Moodle complements our face-to-face/on-site program, and many of the faculty prefer to do writing annotations on paper. We are a language program so many of the levels only do short amounts (e.g. a paragraph is quite long for some low-levels) and the ability here is simply not as necessary (or as fast) as doing it by hand. I prefer the electronic method either way, but, I'm not teaching the courses so I defer to their preferences. We also have many assignment submissions with Poodll, also making the auto-pdf generator unnecessary. Each time you move through a submission, you have to accept the warning message that a file is corrupt or missing when there simply is no document file in the first place. As a student who has taken many online courses in Moodle as a graduate student, I completely understand that the majority of asynchronous coursework will be document based, but even when turning in links to something like a Google Doc, or a website, the auto-pdf viewer pane is just completely out of place. The dynamic editing/collaboration ability through Google Docs is far better than just a one way annotation. I wonder if there would be a way for developers to turn that pain into a web-browser (the way Doctopus and Goobric work) to really put everything in once place if the submission was in fact a link. It has potential for sure, but there is some design work that needs to be done .

ResponsesInList.Text: I have a course that is active on my moodle site.  Another instructor wanted to duplicate what I have and then modify it for his own needs for his course section.  If I go into the target course, and select Import, I know I can bring things from my course into his.  My question is this.  In my course, there are many files that are available and are linked from a file repository (I told it to create a link to the file, rather than a copy into the course).  The import into his course is taking a LONG time.  When importing into the target course, are these links re-created (ideally, this is how I would like it work), or are all of the files being copied locally into the target course? Any help would be much appreciated!  The import currently does not work, and I get the dreaded " error/cannot_finish_ui_if_not_setting_ui" error.  I have tried increasing my max execution time without success. Thank you!

ResponsesInList.Title: Changing images on Essential theme login page
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello all. I would like to add images to the placeholders on the essential theme login page, but am unsure how to do so. Can anyone give me some guidance?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Changing images on Essential theme login page
ResponsesInList.Text: Site administration > Appearance > Themes > Essential > Front page for the marketing spots Site administration > Appearance > Themes > Essential > Slideshow for the slideshow. One recommendation: put an Admin bookmarks block on the front page if you plan on changing them often. You can put direct links to these pages in the Admin bookmarks block, which makes life much easier .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Changing images on Essential theme login page
ResponsesInList.Text: Just realised you meant login page, not front page. Go to Site administration > Plugins > Authentication > Manage authentication and scroll down to the "Instructions" text box to add your info there.

ResponsesInList.Title: SCORM displayed in pop-up in other LMS
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi again.  I would like to give users of a non Moodle LMS access to SCORMs within my Moodle LMS. All users exist in both systems.  From the non Moodle LMS users are created and enrolled on courses by Moodle web services. Ideally Moodle would be invisible to these users with the SCORM popping up in a pop up. But I do need my Moodle LMS to keep track of progress, grades, number of attempts, etc. Has anyone any thoughts on the best approach to this or if there are any extentions that might help? Cheers Nigel

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: SCORM displayed in pop-up in other LMS
ResponsesInList.Text: LTI ; if the other LMS can handle it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: SCORM displayed in pop-up in other LMS
ResponsesInList.Text: Just H tx for that.  The other LMS is a bespoke .net C# application and not LTI functional. But we do have full access to the source code and the development team so all things are possible. However our requirement is very precise and will not change in the future.  The resources in Moodle will always be single activity SCORMs.  The users will always be known to both LMSs.  Enrollment on to the Moodle courses is a hidden (to the user) process driven through the Moodle webservice. So I wouldn't want to use a sledge hammer to crack a nut as it were.  But equally wouldn't want to reinvent the wheel. Any thoughts on time taken to implement LTI would be welcome but in my experience these things are never as simple as they might seem in theory due to their generic nature. I was thinking more of having a link from the non Moodle LMS and automating the logon and opening of the relevant course.  As the Moodle instance will only have this task (the running of single activity SCORMs from this one non Moodle LMS) we do not have to be concerned by other types of processing, types of resource, and/or other requirements.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: SCORM displayed in pop-up in other LMS
ResponsesInList.Text: Sadly development is not my forte but from what I gather from browsing various sites, for a developer it may not be as much as a black box as it appears to be to me. It may well be a sledge hammer approach but given your setup is half way there (from the Moodle side) might be worth your development team having a quick look to see how complex it would be. A couple of links that may be useful: https://www.edu-apps.org/code.html https://github.com/andyfmiller/LtiLibrary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: SCORM displayed in pop-up in other LMS
ResponsesInList.Text: Just H links much appreciated. Yes for sure we cannot discount it as, as you say, we are half way there. And as we have the web services to register and enrol users, and to create courses we at the moment are not looking at changing Moodle code.  The only slightly against political correctness thing we have planned is dragging the results out of the Moodle database but that is of course read only.  So one advantage of LTi would be that it leaves our Moodle with code clean.

ResponsesInList.Title: Username and real name
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi.  Moodle seems to want to display real names (or is it just me ).  On the surface a nice touch.  But real names are not unique. Is there any add in or option that allows tool tips to easily display both (ie. hover over real name and see username) or if not as second best the option to display Moodle username and not real name? Cheers for any input. Nigel

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Username and real name
ResponsesInList.Text: Site administration -> Users -> Permissions -> User policies -> Show user identity.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Username and real name
ResponsesInList.Text: Tim thanks so much for a precise and rapid reply.  Must be too much burning the candle at both ends because I hunted but clearly missed that. Still would like tool tips but that solves our problem. Cheers

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Username and real name
ResponsesInList.Text: Or have I spoken too soon? That option allows Show user identity ID number Email address Phone Mobile phone Department Institution but not username.  Is that available in Moodle 3 I wonder? Cheers

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Username and real name
ResponsesInList.Text: Some Moodle developers think that revealing username is a security issue. Therefore, they do not offer that option in the user-interface. However, if you force the setting in your config.php file, for example with $CFG->showuseridentity = 'email,idnumber,username'; then you can make it appear.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Username and real name
ResponsesInList.Text: Tim again thanks for your guidance.  Sadly that option applies to certain places where usernames appear but not all. And I'm sure you'd know if a tooltip option existed so I guess we will have to develop one.  But shouldn't be too difficult. Not sure I understand the security issue as for that to be the case the password would have had to be compromised. ps I'm sounding like a grump when in truth I'm very pleased with Moodle

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Username and real name
ResponsesInList.Text: The world of protecting identities can be a little odd. It has become widely accepted for example that revealing your name and bank account number is very foolish and will result in your bank being unable to stop random individuals emptying your account. Yet for about 100 years this was the only way of making a non cash payment, i.e. you wrote a cheque with your name, signature, bank account number and sort code and gave it to anyone you wanted to pay. And somehow, banks managed to (mostly) not give the contents of your account to any random stranger with this information. I used to work for a company  selling "Identity Protection" (or snake oil as it is sometimes known)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Username and real name
ResponsesInList.Text: The user profile has several alternate name settings (phonetics or alternative) which can be used by then setting the Full name format and Alternative name format on the Users > Policies > User Policies page e.g. firstname lastname, alternatename might give something like Admin User, Richard or Mohammed Mohammed, Tahir and Mohammed Mohammed, Ali (I once taught a class with 7 "Mohammed Mohammed"s out of 17 boys, but all with different 'known as' names )

ResponsesInList.Title: Fixing the main menu block
ResponsesInList.Text: Recently a fix has been introduced into the main menu block which changes the behaviour of the block. This has been introduced in MDL-50956 and it is an understandable fix.  The old behaviour showed section 0 of the current course; and not the proper main menu. However some environments I manage have become reliant on this behaviour. So I re-introduced the old code in these environments in the form of a hack. However I propose the old behaviour to become a block setting in the main menu block. This topic aims to find (counter) arguments to such a setting. What do you think of the new behaviour versus the old?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Fixing the main menu block
ResponsesInList.Text: For me I think the fix makes the block work as it was always intended to. There is perhaps a case for developing another block to replace the 'unintentional' functionality you have been using, to display a course Section-0 in a sidebar block, but for me that shouldn't be the site_main_menu. That's just my personal opinion though and those who have been using this bug/feature will have different views

ResponsesInList.Title: Example: prompt to continue before performing an operation
We have to stop doing this! (Silly settings)
ResponsesInList.Text: The new recycle bin feature that was just integrated ready for Moodle 3.1 is awesome. However ... One of the new admin settings it adds is: Auto hide ( tool_recyclebin | autohide ) Automatically hides the recycle bin link when the bin is empty. Why is that a setting? Just decide which of the two possible options is better usability , then implement that for everyone without adding yet another unnecessary setting to Moodle! We have to stop doing this.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: We have to stop doing this! (Silly settings)
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, just my "two cents" here. I do not think there is always a "one size fits all". As the moodle user base is huge, we may consider people have diffrent opinions and likes and is better if we could provide choices for people. I think one of the major problems with Moodle development nowadays is that "fear" of adding new settings. We already have more than a thousand, a few more cannot be a real problem. Of course Moodle is open-sourceand everyone can make the needed chances to adapt to his/her own way, but I think a good software is made of good defaults and when it cannot have only one way, it provides options. Options are good. Kind regards, Daniel

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: We have to stop doing this! (Silly settings)
ResponsesInList.Text: Have to say I agree with Daniel, IMHO what we have to do is stop dumbing things down just because some people can't handle "too many" settings (obviously don't include you in the "some people" Tim). Given some of the people I work with, I can see people complaining about it being hidden at times and others complaining about it being shown when it's empty; way I see it, it should be up to the "owner" of the Moodle install as to what would suit their organisation rather than developers therefore, I have no issue with another admin setting. H

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: We have to stop doing this! (Silly settings)
ResponsesInList.Text: I am not saying "never all any options". The new recycle bin functionality adds 5 new settings. 2 are clearly sensible: how long to keep things in the recycle bin before deleting the old data so that cannot be restored any more. Certainly one size does not fit all here. 2 are borderline: to let you turn off the functionality. I actually wonder if this is necessary. It is clearly a good feature, so why would you want to turn it off? (Answer, because it uses backup and restore, so that might make deleting a course much slower.) 1 is (in my opinion) clearly a pointless thing to let admins change, as I explained above. It is not about 'dumbing down'. It is about not wasting peoples time with things they don't need to be bothered with. Where possible, developers should get things right (or good enough) once and for all, rather than giving up and leaving it up to admins. It is not just admins. If you have different settings, then you have to start testing with all possible values of the settings. That is only worthwhile if the different values of the setting are really useful.

(Is it needed when not editing?) Marcus suggests that to many people the pages are already too cluttered, so go with that, they can be cluttered, ugly anyway. Most developers recognize that the end user is likely to be closely related to Neanderthal, so tend to over control things. Most admins I know believe that users want to just break things, so want as much control as they can get, to prevent stuff from happening. Whilst I do know users who should never have been allowed out of the creche, the majority are hard working, conscientious, and almost completely ignorant of what tools they use. They only use the bits they know, and rarely seek to reach beyond their comfort zone. They become banshees when something goes wrong, wearing admins down with their incessant bleatings about how they have deleted something and want it back as it is irreplaceable. They rarely acknowledge my question of "If it was so important, why delete it?", usually with a sniff and a look that tells me I am treading on dangerous ground. Our Moodle is hosted by a 3rd party, so any code tweaking will have to be done by that organisation. Does anyone have a 'solution' please? Moodle 2.7.5 'Essential' theme

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: HTML block visibility
ResponsesInList.Text: Perhaps the first few items in Blocks FAQ might give you some help?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: HTML block visibility
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Mary Thanks for the pointer.  Using the method described in ' How do I make a front page block visible to teachers but not students ', I'd have to individually identify by name each user who I'd want to view this front page block, and to remember to do so for each subsequent new user assigned a 'Teacher' role on a course.  In addition, a user with a 'Teacher' role' on some courses, might be enrolled on other courses with a 'Student' role, and I wouldn't want that user to then see the block. Although this would seem to be a partial solution, I was hoping that, by preventing or prohibiting users from viewing a block on the block's Permissions page, Moodle would automatically hide or display the block, depending on whether a user was enrolled on a course as a 'Student' or 'Teacher' respectively.  Is this something that Moodle can't do?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: HTML block visibility
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Russell, You probably have fixed this by now but just in case you didn't, or if there are others with the same problem ... On the front page you don't really have people enrolled as teachers or students which makes this not-so-straight-forward as you've found out yourself. I resolved this as follows: Create a cohort called 'teachersandadminsonly' Using 'Bulk User Actions', add anyone who is enrolled as a teacher in any course to that 'teachersandadminsonly' cohort Create a new user role at system level, also called called 'teachersandadminsonly' Using the 'Cohort role synchronization' plugin, sync the 'teachersandadminsonly' cohort with the 'teachersandadminsonly' role On the html block, only allow the teachersandadminsonly user role to view the plugin. Every few months, repeat step 2 in case there are any new teachers in any of the courses. Catherine

ResponsesInList.Title: Why do we have to create our own navigation buttons in lessons?

The most glaring is that I have to create our own navigation buttons for each lesson page. Each page needs either a back or next button, and all requiring custom naming of buttons. I understand that you can create custom internal links to select pages within the lesson, but can't the back and next navigation buttons be automatically generated? Surely it doesn't seem very complicated to implement, but would be extremely time-saving. Just a pretty big usability issue in my mind. Thanks!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Why do we have to create our own navigation buttons in lessons?
ResponsesInList.Text: Why not use the module book for this purpose?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Why do we have to create our own navigation buttons in lessons?
ResponsesInList.Text: I presume its because the Lesson module isn't designed to only/primarily support a single path through the content where Next/Previous would be most appropriate. The Lesson module allows multiple paths through the learning to be created depending on selections made on different pages, so a previous button may need to take two different users back to a different place, while a next button may lead to one of a number of options.

ResponsesInList.Title: Edit Menu Items in Gradebook setup
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm noticing some inconsistencies in the location of certain actions within the edit menus I consider the module edit menu in the course page as the standard. Now looking at the menus for outcomes and grade items in Gradebook setup, I recognized that these menus have the Show/Hide action below the Delete action. Outcome edit menu Grade item edit menu Although this may appear minor for most, I feel this is a usability problem and would prefer to see consistency between these types of menus and a predictable hierarchy of these actions. Having plenty of experience using the delete and hide/show actions, I can easily see someone quickly selecting the Delete action for an outcome or grade item when they wanted to only hide it or vice versa. I think 'Delete' should always be the last of the menu items. And in these cases the Hide/Show should be second on the list (above the Edit calculation for grade item).

ResponsesInList.Title: Popups in folders and decent file manager
ResponsesInList.Text: I have a pretty long thread here https://moodle.org/mod/forum/user.php?id=2074405 where I detail my struggles with organizing course structure while enabling say pdf popups. The gist of it is, why on earth?!!! can we not enable popups for e.g. pdfs, docx, images etc in anything other than main topics pages? The second whinge if you like, it really would be ideal if we could change file behavior from withing a file manager. Migrating from a 10+ year old platform, which although has a really diabolically ugly GUI, actually does all of the aforementioned pretty competently. Have had a look at plugins for enabling web-viewing of pdfs and word within the browser, as far as I can tell there are only a couple, which are reliant on third-party cloud hosting of files. Word is less important (and guess licensing issues apply), but pdf's are nearly universally viewable on most browsers regardless of platform (win, android, mapple, etc)...why is this such a problem for developers to address? At present, it looks as though you need a separate 'topic' for each subject where you want to enable pdf popups or on a separate browser tab. Thus instead of a course structure where you have say..main subject/theme/topic/subtopic (with pdfs, quizzes, external links, media etc), you end up with 100+ Topic/( activities , quizzes, documents, media etc). This structure may well work for 'week to week' course structures, but is far from ideal when you want the whole course accessible and navigable for students. Any ideas? Is it just me or do others find this laughable? How hard can it be to implement pop-up functionality of items within a folder/subfolder? Otherwise am really impressed with the platform...have used Blackboard and It's Learning way back when in undergrad and grad school (10+ years ago). Just not looking forward to having to restructuring the course into one 50+ topic long mess just to enable pop-ups. Doing this for a friend/client who doesn't want to deal with pages/atto editor...and with a lot of mathematical symbols, copying from word, can understand why. Copy/paste is not an option for maritime navigation course with associated charts etc! Would take months... Any plugins or suggestions very welcome! Just need students to be able to view pdfs in pop-ups, and have quizzes linked or in same secton.  Of course caveat being...around 5-7 'chapters', with 3-10 subtopics. 50+ topics with no organization seems pretty messy. Thanks appreciate feedback.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Popups in folders and decent file manager
ResponsesInList.Text: Addendun: for me at least, (and would think for many others), this limitation is almost a deal-breaker. Guess will have to make some calls to blackboard, it's learning etc to see what they want in licensing fees (which my clients really can't afford most likely!)...but as they say, money talks and bs walks! A shame as it seems this is pretty much one of the few limitations which prevents moodle from eclipsing aforementioned altogether.  The rest of the platform is really solid, and well thought out. But this (idiotic!) oversight is really holding it back... Essentially it limits moodle to short courses organized week-by-week, or where there just isn't that much content to be distributed. Am well aware it's free! and kudos to developers! Not all of us have access to institutional MS and Adobe licences tho.....!! Would be nice if the developer community could fix this...

Forum threads filtered by date or user. Sidebars inestead of blocks. Jquery effects Etc... In a few words, they want to use something that is not like a classic Moodle, but keeping all Moodle inner funtionality. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle UI customizations
ResponsesInList.Text: Some of your request are implemented in Adaptable , a new moodle theme that try to break the classic moodle structure. Add custom pages is easy but adding these pages to the custom menu could be messy. Adaptable has several menus to add these pages. Add any content in the course page without blocks is really difficult due the moodle layout. We need to use the regions to add this content using blocks. And normally there are no regions in the course page. We are working to add some regions in this page. Sidebars instead of blocks? I think is better the opposite. In Adaptable you can add information in the frontpage without sidebars, using a configurable grid layout. And all the modern Moodle Themes could allow the use of the default JQuery elements. ResponsesInList.Title: Adding Custom Grading Calculations
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello all! I want to use Moodle to create a quiz but then "plug in" my own method for grading the quiz. I've done some digging into the source code and looked at add ons but I wanted to check in with the community to see if there are any recommendations or just "why in the world would you want to do that?" The reason for wanting to do this: I want to be able to analyze not just one answer but a collection of answers and then formulate a result from that collection. I will actually be creating a customized report from the analysis. Thank you in advance for your help! Best regards, Keith

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding Custom Grading Calculations
ResponsesInList.Text: What sort of answers are you thinking of? Some existing question types already accept multiple inputs, and do the grading by combining them. E.g. https://moodle.org/plugins/qtype_formulas or https://moodle.org/plugins/qtype_stack . But, if you are not teaching maths, those won't be very interesting. So, option 1: consider making a new question type plugin: https://docs.moodle.org/dev/Question_types Alternatively, if you want to re-use exiting question types (e.g. have an activity that combines answers to multiple choice questions in an interesting way, then you probably need to build a new activity module that uses questions: https://docs.moodle.org/dev/Using_the_question_engine_from_module

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding Custom Grading Calculations
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Tim, thank you for the reply. I'm actually building an assessment where the user is asked to provide process results in terms of percentages. For example, "what percentage of widgets in your company can you locate at any given time?" So I take these answers, groups them into buckets that make up the system and then generate a report containing ratings of each of the buckets using statistics analysis. The challenge for me is being able to look at the answers in each bucket individually and as a whole and compare to other buckets. I hope I haven't lost you at this point! The questions types are more the sufficient to support what I need. It's the grading process I'm hoping to either customize or re-use something that is out there. Once again, thank you for your response. I will be looking into the links your provided in more detail.

ResponsesInList.Title: tracking the time spent by students on course/activity
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, I would like to use Moodle for our flight school but there is a requirement so that the teachers/admins can track each student's time spent on the courses/ activities (text material needed to be read by students). As far as I've searched I couldn't find something which would fit this requirement. I've looked here: https://docs.moodle.org/23/en/Tracking_progress and also googled a bit but nothing popped-up. The time spent is considered for the interval where the student had the page opened. Is there something like this or a similar time tracking plugin/feature? Thank you!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: tracking the time spent by students on course/activity
ResponsesInList.Text: The short answer is no and the longer is that there is not a lot of benefit to doing it anyway. (I know its not your idea but bear with me). The web is stateless, it will only ever record when something is requested. If a person goes on holiday, or falls asleep after opening a page with that page it will never record when they "finished" with the page. Then there is the question of what value it would provide even if you could report on this information. Imagine you have a 20 page document and one person moved through the pages three hours, gradually moving through the pages. Then another person moved through the pages in 30 minutes at an intermittent pace. Perhaps one person was watching TV and idly clicking on each new page without looking at it, might be the one person or it might be the other. You would not know anything useful. The good news is that Moodle has the best quiz engine in existence and you could use that to find out if the students have actually learned what you hoped. I don't mean to be negative, plenty of other people have asked similar questions. This issues around this have been expressed better than I have on these forums previously but I can't seem to find any links at the moment. Ahh I have just found this one https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=198764 And at the end is this link https://moodle.org/plugins/pluginversions.php?plugin=mod_attendanceregister

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: tracking the time spent by students on course/activity
ResponsesInList.Text: Meanwhile I started installing Moodle to a small webserver fort testing purposes and also found this: https://moodle.org/plugins/view/report_trainingsessions Indeed, you are right, the idea is kinda silly, I will try to clarify the requirement and maybe have another tracking concept. I knew about the time-boxed quizzes, they are really useful and I will propose those also. Also, thanks for the other links, funny thing that when I've googled those didn't came up, just some old topic from 2007/2009 Thanks again!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: tracking the time spent by students on course/activity
ResponsesInList.Text: I was surprised how hard it was to find comments on this topic as I feel like I have been reading about it for a long time. Learning Analytics is a popular concept at the moment.  One of the reasons is that organisations hope to be able to use it to improve retention, i.e. find out why students leave. However there is a certain amount of "snake oil" on the market and misuse of data and statistics. This presentation from Elizabeth Dalton is interesting and snake oil free

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: URL's in folders?

ResponsesInList.Title: Questions on Enforcements in Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Everybody, I would like to ask a few questions about presentation/quiz enforcement as it relates to our business.  The company that I work for market is in providing continuing education to folks that originate loans, sell insurance, prepare mortgages, etc.  We do online courses that have presentations and webinars too.  We are contemplating making the switch from Atrixware to Moodle however do not know if it can customized to fit our business.   Our students are #1 priority however out students are either nationally or state licensed which means that we have to enforce a lot of disparate regulations to adhere to in order to provide accreditation.  For example, a real estate student has to stay on a slide for 5 minutes before moving o the next one or a insurance student needs to spend  x minutes on the entire presentation to meet a time allotment requirement.  When it comes to tests and test taking the time allotted is different per state as is the variations of the test we are to deliver, etc.  These examples are just a tip of the iceberg for regulations, and each state is quite different so I was wondering if anyone could tell me or point me to a section that discussed these mechanisms.  In my mind, I picture our dev team developing a content delivery framework that enforces these regulations when the course is built that we can build our and edit at anytime at the course level.  Are their a set of hooks that my guys can write to that perform such tasks?  Are these hooks robust or pretty limited?  Prone to problems or solid as a rock?  Anything you can share in regards to these mechanism would be helpful. Thanks for sharing. -Jon

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Questions on Enforcements in Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: These sorts of rules are really annoying to have to deal with, because what has " stay on a slide for 5 minutes before moving o the next one " got to do with learning? The only real effect will be to annoy students, who will probably start doing thing like opening the next slide, then switching to Facebook for 5 mins, or making a cup of coffee before clicking next, which will not help them concentrate. (It also implies that the learning is made up of 'slides', which is a bit limited.) Anyway, you don't make these rules, you just have to enforce them. Or be seen to enforce them enough to satisfy the regulators. (If you are forced to implement silly rules, it seems perfectly reasonable to do the minimum required to meet them ) So, all that aside, can you do this in Moodle? You can do almost anything if you write custom PHP code. Moodle is designed to be both an out-of-the-box LMS, but also a platform that is a good basis for customising if you want. However, you do have to learn the best ways to customise it. It might be worth asking a Moodle Partner, or other Moodle consultant, to come and give your developers some training on the specifics of Moodle development, and then also go through your list of requirements and discuss the best Moodle 'hooks', or plugin types, to implement them. Or, the developer docs start here: https://docs.moodle.org/dev/ In terms of the content, do you know about the SCORM standard? If you develop your content as SCORM, then you can use it in any LMS, not just Moodle (if you decided to change again in future) SCORM content is basically just HTML + JavaScript , so it is easy to create, and you can certainly do things like arbitrary time-limits. For testing, the Moodle Quiz is very flexible. For example, you can give different time limits to different groups of students .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: drag and drop questions on a small screen device
ResponsesInList.Text: Well, suppose a learning outcome of your course is "Be able to identify a bacteria on a microscope slide" or "Be able to recognise a church with a steeple on a map" If that is a learning outcome, then a question like drag-and-drop markers is ideal to assess it. However, it is fundamentally a visual task, so it is never going to be accessible to a blind user. So, we have to ask what we mean by these question types being accessible. They are in many ways as accessible as possible. For example, they do not require the use o a mouse, or touch-screen. They can all be done using only keyboard. That is one ADA requirement. There is a known problem with drag-and-drop into text. The labels are not as good as the could probably be, so it is not as easy to complete these questions while using a screen reader as perhaps it could be. However, Moodle's existing Cloze question type suffers the same problem, and I have never been able to work out a good solution. Suggestions welcome.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle Authentication Figures
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm trying to work out for a project how accessible Moodle is by trying to see how many of the 64761 sites require authentication.  I have emailed Moodle, but had no response. Does anyone have any idea how to find out such information?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Authentication Figures
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Katherine. Just to let you know I deleted your duplicate post because if you post in more than one forum, it fragments any support you might get. There is actually a forum dedicated to usability and accessiblity if you would like me to move this thread there? I don't know which email you used for emailing Moodle, but I'm not sure how we would find out which sites require authentication (but I'm not the statistics person anyway!) However, I would suspect most of them do - because without authentication, Moodle is simply another website. If you view Moodle courses without being logged in (authenticated) then that is all you can do - view them, read the information, etc. As Moodle is a VLE/LMS, it requires people to have accounts to be able to access activities , participate and handle sensitive materials. (As you can see from our Mission, Moodle is 'open in every way but can be private'.) There is a lot of work going on regarding accessibility so feel free to ask more and explore the documentation (example: Accessibility) and forums more.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Authentication Figures
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Mary, Please could you move it over to the dedicated usability and accessibility forum, and my apologies for cross-posting. I was wondering whether the statistics that are collected by the registration process contain any information about how many installations require authentication when accessing pages.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Authentication Figures
ResponsesInList.Text: Done You have now moved forums. Perhaps you can explain why it is important to know about which sites require authentication when researching accessibity?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Authentication Figures
ResponsesInList.Text: The reason why I'm interested to know is that while Moodle is a global information environment as a platform and in principle (i.e accessible from any location with an internet connection), that it is not necessarily globally accessible to all users e.g. if sites are requiring authentication through LDAP etc. then there are restrictions are in place that make it 'less' accessible. While I'm aware that a lot of this comes down to sites being run by universities and that as a result of this they aren't going to make teaching material free when they are simultaneously charging students, and also restrictions on copyright across countries. Background: I'm writing an essay on “The prospect of a paperless, global information environment arriving is about as likely as that of the paperless office – thank goodness!” Do you agree? Discuss the technical and social considerations and constraints on both the feasibility and desirability of such a scenario. Present evidence both for and against this assertion, and argue your own point of view. - I hope this helps shed some light

ResponsesInList.Title: Bluejeans & Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: We have been using Adobe Connect with Moodle for a number of years as our web conferencing software.  We have recently been informed that Adobe Connect is to be phased out and our IT department is pushing Bluejeans as the alternative.  Is anyone using Bluejeans with Moodle?  If you are, what type of functionality does it offer?  What, if any, issues do you have with it?  How well does it integrate with Moodle?  Would you recommend using Bluejeans with Moodle? About a year ago, we trialed Big Blue Button and while we liked the functionality, couldn't justify switching from Adobe Connect.  Has anyone used both Bluejeans and BBB?  If you have, which would you recommend? Thank you for your feedback, Susan

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Bluejeans & Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Susan, We use BigBlueButton.  We host our own BBB server , so we have total control over it.  BBB does have its limitations, if you are hosting your own installation.  Moodle is a very simple integration into Moodle with the plugin.  It is easy for both instructors to setup and students to use.  Desktop sharing works simply as does the whiteboard.  There is a large BBB community. Hosting our server does have its limitations in the number of users who can login at once, right around 60 seems to be our limit.  One other thing I really ask that the students who are going to use BBB get a headset microphone combination, otherwise the instructor is constantly playing traffic cop muting and unmutting students due to feedback. We have looked at Adobe Connect, it is nice, and decided it was just too costly. As for Bluejeans, I never heard of it until your posting.  So I cannot offer any guidance there.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Bluejeans & Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: We like BigBlueButton.  It is nicely integrated and the Moodle users are automatically allowed to enter into the meeting. We also use G Hangouts for small meetings but it isn't integrated like BBB.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Bluejeans & Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Interested to see what is your outcome.. did you manage to go with Bluejeans ? We're in the same process of researching for a live virtual classroom approach..

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Bluejeans & Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Samuel So far we are still waiting on our IT Department and no decision has been made.  I am guessing we are looking at January at the earliest to conclude our investigation of options and possibly next summer.  We did do a fairly thorough trial of Big Blue Button and really liked how it integrated with Moodle, but couldn't get enough buy-in through our shared service to have it implemented. Susan

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Bluejeans & Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for the reply Hope you find a good approach with success !!

ResponsesInList.Title: Calculated Simple question type variables reset
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello all - I have a faculty member who is having troubles editing Calculated Simple question types.  He indicates that when trying to edit any aspect of existing question, the variable limits are reset to 1 and 10, rendering the calculated answers incorrect because they don't match the originals.  This feels like a bug to me, but perhaps there's some aspect of the question type design that makes it a necessity?  I thought before filing a bug report I'd see if anyone here had seen similar behavior. To ensure I haven't misconstrued something, here's his original report to me: The bug present in this version of moodle is easily reproducible. It appears to be an error specific to the Calculated Simple type under the “Create a new question…” option in the Question Bank section of a course. When any question of this type is made you must set limits for the variables the question will use. The default setting for these variables is 1 to 10. If you modify these variables to fit your question and save, the question appears to work just fine with the variables you have set; however, if you go back and try to modify ANY characteristic of a question of this type ( name of question, a typo in the question text, the tolerance of answer that it is willing to accept, etc.), these variables revert back to the defaults of 1 to 10. This then renders the calculated answers incorrect, as they do not match the set put forward by the original calculations. I assume this is an error in either how the variables are stored, or how they are indexed to the particular question. Thanks much for any guidance you may have!  We're running Moodle 2.8.7+ Brian

ResponsesInList.Title: PHP inside SCORM
ResponsesInList.Text: In my website, the xml file for flash is dynamically generated using php by combining few other xml files, based on url. So, if url says course=1&module=5, then php will combine xml file for course 1 and xml file for module 5 to generate the resultant xml. Is it possible to convert this into SCORM format. The main challenge I am facing is the PHP will not work inside SCORM format and url based manipulation will also be difficult. Could anybody suggest a workaround for this please? -Many Thanks, Abhilash

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: PHP inside SCORM
ResponsesInList.Text: SCORM packages are designed to be static/self-contained content. You cannot add PHP to SCORM packages. You could potentially use AICC HACP by setting up a server that hosts the content and uses AICC HACP to communicate results etc with the LMS but I haven't seen any useful documentation on how to do this on your own.

ResponsesInList.Title: Edit conflicts
ResponsesInList.Text: How does Moodle handle edit conflicts? If more than one person has edit rights to an item of content which can be edited, like a page or a lesson , what happens when more than one person attempts to edit the same item at the same time? Is the item locked for additional edits as long as it is open for one editor, or is it possible for two editors to have the item open simultaneously? In the latter case, what happens when they save? Does the first save get priority, or the last save, or does it crash? (It hasn't happened to me yet, but it could.)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Edit conflicts
ResponsesInList.Text: Two people could have the same edit page open at the same time. In that case, whoever saves second 'wins'. Their changes are the ones that will persist. However, given how most Moodle sites are used, this is probably a very rare occurrence.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Edit conflicts
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks, We will have to be careful.

ResponsesInList.Title: Can I save a topic in Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello everyone, I have this topic-based course in Moodle and I'm building up another one, also topic-based. I'd love to borrow some topics from my old one to use in my new one. Each topic is a bunch of quizzes plus a couple of pages with some reference information. I have two questions: 1) Is there an elegant solution to 'copy-paste'-'save-and-load' or whatever a topic so it could become easily transferrable? 2) If no, is there any other solution besides manually (export qs - create a new quiz - import qs) x N ? Thanks.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Can I save a topic in Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Alexander I created a hidden course called "Warehouse" which is only accessible for teachers and above.  Usually staff create all materials there (or at least import them there if they put something together directly in a course).  Then if I need anything in a new course, I just import it from the Warehouse.  It's quick and easy, and you can use the topics in the warehouse course to create an index which will help you track things down.  Using the recent activity block in the course lets teachers know when new materials have been added and a forum allows for discussion about future wishes and requirements. Hope this helps, Andy

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Can I save a topic in Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Andy, >> Then if I need anything in a new course, I just import it from the Warehouse.  It's quick and easy Could you please elaborate on how you do it? I have a course which I want to use later on as the Warehouse. How exactly do you transfer a topic from the Warehouse to other courses? Thanks.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Can I save a topic in Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Alexander, You open the course where you want to import the items to.  In the Administration block you select Import and then you choose your storage course.  Then you select the items you want from that course and import them. Hope this helps! Andy

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Can I save a topic in Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks a bunch, Andy, that does help oodles! Great feature I hadn't known before!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Can I save a topic in Moodle?
ResponsesInList.Text: You may also ask your site admin to install the Sharing Cart block. It does more or less what the import function but it is more handy to use.

ResponsesInList.Title: Unlocking Badges based on Course Total
ResponsesInList.Text: I would like to setup a system where students unlock a badge by reaching a certain number of points in the course (using Natural).  It seems as though the system isn't set up to do this normally.  It either wants to rely on Activity Completion or Course Completion. I suppose my question is, what are the consequences if I were to use "Course Completion" to unlock different badges even if the whole course was not complete at that point?  I could have a badge at 50% of points, one at 75%, etc, that students work obtain progressively.  This seems, intuitively, like a bad idea because the student will not have completed the course and be done with it yet. My work around has been to tie the badge to an activity the student gets access to based on point total then can self complete, something as simple as a previously hidden Label.  This is okay but seems a little clunky.  I could end up with a whole bunch of Labels to stash somewhere in the course. Any thoughts? Josh

ResponsesInList.Title: Usability Suggestion - Standard content in new courses
ResponsesInList.Text:
One of the barriers to usability for students is that resources in courses may be in very different places and have very different names. This would be improved if a system wide template course could be used to populate every new course. For example it might have content describing the plagiarism policy and links to the reading list.  This could be done by code that caused the template course to be backed up and restored into each new course. This might be something like for hand created courses in the edit.php file you would add ... $bc = new
backup_controller(backup::TYPE_1COURSE, $templatecourseid, backup::FORMAT_MOODLE, backup::INTERACTIVE_NO,
backup::MODE_IMPORT, $USER->id); Then execution code and $rc = new
restore_controller($backupid, $course->id, bla bla bla What do you think?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Usability Suggestion - Standard content in new courses
ResponsesInList.Text: Good idea, Marcus, but isn't that a template? I haven't tried it, but is setting up templates easy or not that straightforward in Moodle? I think most of us would be familiar with the idea of templates, long before we get ti know Moodle, so how difficult is it to extend that idea into our Moodle courses? EDIT: Then I find this in the Docs and after a quick scan see, that Admins are going to have to teach their course creators how to do that, then provide them with the agreed template. In an environment where such standardization is a demand of the workplace, it will work nicely, but where it is not, or where the people who are leaders and are not Moodlers, they are just not going to demand it. They wouldn't even understand the efficacy of such a solution, just looks complicated and for more than a few Admins, I suspect the same would apply. I work in an environment where "diversity" is "encouraged"... sort of... well- not really, it is actually "anything new is dangerous". For the Teachers... oh a Maths Moodle is not the same as a Humanities Moodle... they have different priorities and what worksd ... blah blah... into a round of endless blabbering descending into inaction and meaningless drivel. Or am I being too cynical?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Usability Suggestion - Standard content in new courses
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes it is a template, and oddly it is only when uploading a course with .CSV do you get content. With other ways of creating content, e.g. by hand or with authentication such as LDAP you only get the course settings (e.g. the format such as Topic or Date).  I suspect there are more courses created with those technologies than by CSV. With LDAP the course is created when the first person enrolled on the course logged in, zero teaching of course creators and so rather attractive to admins. You don't get template content when creating by hand either. I think it would be very easy for Admins to overdo the use of templates and there are only so many commonalities between subjects. Some examples that spring to my mind is having a link to a reading list and details of course re-take policies and contact details of course tutors. This would be blanks requiring completion once the course is created. It's easy to imagine some tutors forgetting to do it and ending up with text such as "Course Tutor Details go here" or similar, but you could do a database scan to nudge on these. " Or am I being too cynical? " Possibly, or you might be an experienced realist?

ResponsesInList.Title: Usability that is too clever for its own trousers

It had some lovely animations on the registration form. Unfortunatly the text entry boxes were hidden and it was close to impossible to use. Never mind I will try it with another browser, MS IE to be precise. No joy, cannot see fields properly. Finally I fired it up in my trusty Firefox and I could see the fields. It turns out that the only problem was the lightness of the background combined with no field borders, but the impact on usability was massive and I am a geek who does little but play with web apps.
